社会工程学

Social Engineering

社会工程学

Social Engineering

群主、网络黑客和网络喷子如何创造出一种新的操纵性沟通方式

How Crowdmasters, Phreaks, Hackers, and Trolls Created a New Form of Manipulative Communication

罗伯特·W·盖尔和肖恩·T·劳森

Robert W. Gehl and Sean T. Lawson

麻省理工学院出版社

The MIT Press

马萨诸塞州剑桥 | 英国伦敦

Cambridge, Massachusetts | London, England

© 2022 Robert W. Gehl 和 Sean T. Lawson

© 2022 Robert W. Gehl and Sean T. Lawson

保留所有权利。未经出版商书面许可，不得以任何电子或机械方式（包括影印、录制或信息存储和检索）复制本书的任何部分。

All rights reserved. No part of this book may be reproduced in any form by any electronic or mechanical means (including photocopying, recording, or information storage and retrieval) without permission in writing from the publisher.

麻省理工学院出版社感谢对本书草稿提供评论的匿名同行评审员。学术专家的慷慨工作对于建立我们出版物的权威性和质量至关重要。我们衷心感谢这些未署名读者的贡献。

The MIT Press would like to thank the anonymous peer reviewers who provided comments on drafts of this book. The generous work of academic experts is essential for establishing the authority and quality of our publications. We acknowledge with gratitude the contributions of these otherwise uncredited readers.

致谢

Acknowledgments

任何一本书的作者都会深深感激那些一路上提供建议、鼓励、支持和反馈的人。我们也不例外。如果没有同事、朋友和家人的慷慨解囊，这个项目就不可能实现。我们特别要感谢阿拉巴马大学名誉教授 Margot Opdycke Lamme 提供了多丽丝弗莱施曼 1935 年演讲的副本。麦吉尔大学的 Biella Coleman 和圣母大学的 Walter Scheier 在这个过程的早期就提供了反馈和鼓励。Hector Postigo 提供的反馈至关重要，帮助我们决定如何称呼我们将在后面几页中讨论的现象：大规模个人社会工程学。杨国斌慷慨地与我们分享了他的章节“沟通即翻译”，帮助我们塑造了思维。最后，Emma Briant 和 Cory Wimberly 都与我们分享了他们关于宣传的优秀书籍。

The authors of any book are always deeply indebted to all of those folks along the way who provided advice, encouragement, support, and feedback. We are no exception. This project would not have been possible without the generosity of colleagues, friends, and family. We would especially like to thank Margot Opdycke Lamme, Professor Emerita at the University of Alabama, for providing a copy of Doris Fleischman’s 1935 speech. Biella Coleman of McGill University offered feedback and encouragement early in the process, as did Walter Scheier at Notre Dame. Hector Postigo provided feedback that was critical in helping us decide just what to call the phenomenon we discuss in the pages that follow: masspersonal social engineering. Guobin Yang helped to shape our thinking by generously sharing with us his chapter, “Communication as Translation.” Finally, both Emma Briant and Cory Wimberly shared their excellent books on propaganda with us.

我们也感谢几场活动的观众和组织者，我们很荣幸能在这些活动中展示这项工作的早期草稿。这些活动包括 2020 年地球黑客 (HOPE) 会议、国防部战略多层评估和关键谱系研讨会。在后者，我们特别感谢 Bonnie Sheehey、Ashley Gorham、Verena Erlenbusch-Anderson、Cory Wimberly 和 Colin Koopman 的详尽评论。

We are also thankful to the audience and organizers of several events at which we were honored to present early drafts of this work. These included the 2020 Hackers on Planet Earth (HOPE) conference, the Department of Defense Strategic Multilayer Assessment, and the Critical Genealogies Workshop. At the latter, we especially thank Bonnie Sheehey, Ashley Gorham, Verena Erlenbusch-Anderson, Cory Wimberly, and Colin Koopman for their extensive comments.

最后，我们当然要感谢麻省理工学院出版社编辑 Gita Manaktala 的耐心和帮助，以及匿名评论者的评论，他们的评论帮助本书得以成型和完善。不过，任何错误或遗漏当然都是我们自己的。

Finally, of course, we are grateful for the patience and assistance provided by our editor at the MIT Press, Gita Manaktala, as well as the anonymous reviewers whose comments helped shape and improve this book. Nonetheless, of course, any errors or omissions are all our own.

我要感谢路易斯安那州董事会杰出学者捐赠讲座计划为该项目提供资金。卡尔加里大学传播、媒体和电影系以及路易斯安那理工大学传播系在我获得富布赖特奖学金期间对早期版本提供了宝贵的意见。我还与克莱尔·埃文斯就 Susy Thunder 和电话盗打进行了一次精彩的交谈。

I would like to thank the Louisiana Board of Regents Endowed Chairs for Eminent Scholars program, which provided funding for this project. The University of Calgary Communication, Media, and Film Department and the Louisiana Tech Communication faculty provided valuable comments on an early version during my Fulbright fellowship. I also had a great conversation with Claire Evans about Susy Thunder and phone phreaking.

一如既往，我深深感激我的新老朋友（Ry、Mony、Brian 和 Dan）。在撰写本书的过程中，我结下了新的深厚友谊：肖恩，谢谢你（还有辛西娅！）不仅容忍我，还在灾难发生时帮助我。

I am, as always, in deep debt to my friends, old (Ry, Mony, Brian, and Dan) and new. A new and deep friendship has been made during the writing of this book: Sean, thank you (and Cynthia!) for not only putting up with me but also putting me up during a time of disasters.

家人的爱让我即使在艰难时期也能坚持下去。我妈妈、我弟弟、霍夫一家。除了 TJ 船长和 TJ 领航员，我想不出还有谁比我更愿意和他们一起度过难关。

Love from my family keeps me going even in the midst of bleak times. My mom, my little brother, the Houf family. And I cannot think of anyone I’d rather weather the storm with than Captain TJ and Navigator TJ.

罗伯特·W·盖尔

Robert W. Gehl

2021 年 6 月

June 2021

我要感谢我的亲朋好友在撰写本书的过程中给予的耐心和支持，其中大部分都是在全球疫情的挑战下完成的。首先，我要感谢我的妻子辛西娅，她的建议和鼓励让我一直我走了。Rob，我的合著者和朋友：感谢你邀请我参与这个项目，也感谢你一路以来的耐心。我永远感激有机会通过我们的合作学习和成长为一名作家。最后，我也必须感谢船长兼领航员 TJ，在项目初期的一些艰难时期，他帮助我们吃饱喝好，保持理智。

I would like to thank my close friends and family for their patience and support during the process of writing this book, most of which took place during the challenge of a global pandemic. First and foremost, my wife, Cynthia, whose advice and encouragement keeps me going. Rob, my coauthor and friend: thank you for inviting me to be a part of this project and for your patience along the way. I’m ever grateful for the chance to learn and grow as a writer through our collaboration. Finally, I, too, must thank Captain and Navigator TJ, who helped keep us all well fed and sane during some tough times early in the project.

肖恩·劳森

Sean Lawson

2021 年 6 月

June 2021

引言：大规模个人社会工程的出现

Introduction: The Emergence of Masspersonal Social Engineering

美国正处于一个令人迷惑甚至有时致命的数字媒体环境中。人们分享着各种操纵性信息，从选举结果到医疗效果，有时是故意的，有时是无意的。国内政治领导人试图利用由此产生的偏执和混乱来获得更大的权力，而外国政府则兴高采烈地煽动分裂和不满。

The United States is awash in a disorienting and sometimes deadly digital media environment. People are sharing—sometimes purposely, other times without knowing any better—manipulative information about everything from election results to the effectiveness of medical treatments. Domestic political leaders seek to ride the resulting paranoia and confusion to ever greater power, while foreign governments gleefully stoke divisions and discontent.

操纵性沟通在企业社交媒体中大行其道，尤其是 Facebook、Facebook 的子公司 Instagram 和 Twitter。这些系统旨在放大吸引注意力的信息，无论这些信息是可爱的猫咪视频还是 QAnon 的最新“阴谋论”。事实证明，Facebook 尤其愿意成为操纵性沟通的载体，它利用有关我们的喜好和偏好的海量数据，向我们提供满足我们肯定愿望的信息。无论你的政治或社会品味如何，Facebook 都会提供一个证实你观点的表情包——即使这个表情包是胡说八道。如果 Facebook 自己的算法无法将信息传递给目标受众，那么信息的创建者只需支付少量费用，就可以将他们的想法微定位到可能同意他们观点的受众。

Manipulative communication found a home in corporate social media, especially Facebook, Facebook’s child company Instagram, and Twitter. These systems were designed to amplify attention-getting messages, whether those messages are cute cat videos or the latest QAnon “drops” of conspiracy theorizing. Facebook has especially proven to be a willing vehicle for manipulative communication, using its vast data on our likes and preferences to route to us the information that satisfies our desire for affirmation. No matter your political or social tastes, Facebook will deliver a meme that confirms your views—even if the meme is bullshit. And if Facebook’s own algorithms don’t deliver a message to its intended audience, the creators of the message can simply pay a small fee to microtarget their ideas to audiences likely to agree with them.

2021 年 1 月 6 日，这种操纵性的沟通引发了一场暴力冲突。当天，唐纳德·特朗普支持者暴乱占领了美国国会大厦。暴乱的起因是特朗普及其几位盟友（尤其是参议员乔什·霍利和特德·克鲁兹）发起的一场公然的虚假信息运动，他们都在散布有关 2020 年美国总统大选中猖獗的选举舞弊的胡说八道。1这场国会大厦暴乱的目的是让唐纳德·特朗普继续掌权。有五人死亡——四名暴徒和一名警察——但有报道表明，如果暴徒能够找到他们所谓的敌人，包括副总统迈克·彭斯、众议院议长南希·佩洛西和众议员亚历山大·奥卡西奥-科尔特斯，死亡人数可能会更高。2

Such manipulative communication erupted in a paroxysm of violence on January 6, 2021. That day, a riotous mob of Donald Trump supporters occupied the US Capitol building. The mob was spurred on by a blatant misinformation campaign, run by Trump and several of his allies (notably Senators Josh Hawley and Ted Cruz), all of whom peddled bullshit about rampant election fraud in the 2020 US presidential campaign.1 This Capitol insurrection was meant to keep Donald Trump in power. Five people died—four rioters and one police officer—but reports indicate that the death toll may have been higher if the rioters had been able to find their perceived enemies, including Vice President Mike Pence, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.2

国会暴动是操纵性政治传播危险的一个警示性例子。但是，正如我们将要论证的那样，引发 2021 年 1 月 6 日事件的操纵性传播并不是什么新鲜事。例如，2016 年美国总统大选，民主党候选人希拉里·克林顿与真人秀明星转为共和党候选人的唐纳德·J·特朗普对决。现在有两种有据可查的操纵活动发生在那次选举前夕。

The Capitol insurrection is a cautionary example of the dangers of manipulative political communication. But, as we will argue, the sorts of manipulative communication that fueled the events of January 6, 2021 are nothing new. Consider, for example, the 2016 US presidential election, which pitted the Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton against the reality-television-star-turned-Republican Donald J. Trump. There are now two well-documented types of manipulation campaigns that took place in the run-up to that election.

首先，外国政府俄罗斯试图破坏人们对选举的信心，支持特朗普而反对克林顿，并煽动美国人之间的种族和政治分歧。多亏了几次调查，这场竞选活动得到了充分的记录，其复杂性也显露出来。该行动涉及黑客入侵民主党全国委员会和希拉里·克林顿竞选团队的电子邮件账户、窃取数据以及将这些数据泄露给维基解密等第三方。俄罗斯国家媒体RT和Sputnik帮助推动了泄密。3位于圣彼得堡的互联网研究机构的员工通过人为控制和机器人控制的账户操纵 Facebook、Instagram 和 Twitter，帮助放大了这些信息。4他们搭载了 4chan 的“Great Meme”战争”，放大了支持特朗普和反对克林顿的模因。5互联网研究机构的工作人员还假扮真正的美国人，盗用“黑人的命也是命”活动人士和保守派专家的在线对话。6所有这些努力都是为了支持唐纳德·特朗普这位不太可能的候选人，他当然会赢得大选。

First, there were attempts by a foreign government, Russia, to undermine confidence in the election, support Trump at the expense of Clinton, and stoke racial and political divisions among Americans. Thanks to several investigations, the campaign is well documented, its complexity revealed. The operation involved the hacking of email accounts associated with the Democratic National Committee and the Hillary Clinton campaign, theft of data, and the leaking of those data to third parties like WikiLeaks. Russian state media outlets RT and Sputnik helped to promote the leaks.3 The employees of the Saint Petersburg–based Internet Research Agency helped amplify these messages by manipulating Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter through human-controlled and bot-controlled accounts.4 They piggybacked on 4chan’s “Great Meme War,” amplifying pro-Trump and anti-Clinton memes.5 The Internet Research Agency operatives also posed as real Americans, appropriating the online conversations of Black Lives Matter activists and conservative pundits alike.6 All of this effort was in support of the unlikely candidacy of Donald Trump, who would of course go on to win the election.

但外国势力并非唯一利用企业社交媒体操纵 2016 年大选民主审议的势力。另一个众所周知的操纵性传播活动则来自西方。借助 Facebook 提供的大量数据（有时是可以通过不道德的方式获取），战略传播公司剑桥分析公司 (Cambridge Analytica) 声称能够根据一系列“心理”向量瞄准美国人，并通过社交媒体巧妙地塑造他们的观点。剑桥分析公司由当时的首席执行官亚历山大·尼克斯 (Alexander Nix) 领导，他被《连线》杂志誉为“天才”，该公司承诺利用目标选民的个性特征。7特朗普的总统竞选团队与他们签约，制作和定向广告，以吸引选民远离克林顿，转而支持这位真人秀明星。

But foreign actors weren’t the only ones taking to corporate social media to manipulate democratic deliberation during the 2016 election. The other well-known manipulative communication campaign was based in the West. Thanks to the glut of data available—and sometimes unethically obtainable—from Facebook, the strategic communication firm Cambridge Analytica claimed to be able to target Americans along a range of “psychographic” vectors and subtly shape their opinions via social media. Led by its then-CEO, Alexander Nix, a man Wired magazine proclaimed a “genius,” Cambridge Analytica promised to exploit personality traits of targeted voters.7 Trump’s presidential campaign contracted with them to create and target advertisements to sway voters away from Clinton and towards the reality star.

不过，我们需要提出一个警告。目前，关于俄罗斯试图影响特朗普的选举结果，以及剑桥分析公司在影响投票行为方面所起的作用，争论十分激烈。8在任何一次选举中，都有无数因素在起作用——我们不能将社会变革归结为单一原因。例如，我们不应忘记广泛而持续的选民压制努力，或者克林顿选择在大选期间不在关键摇摆州威斯康星州竞选的简单事实。尽管如此，2016 年的选举提醒我们，出现了令人不安的操纵性传播的新做法。在 2021 年国会大厦暴动之后，操纵性传播的危险性更加明显。

We need to offer a caveat, though. A debate is currently raging about the effectiveness of either the Russian effort to sway the election towards Trump or Cambridge Analytica’s role in shaping voting behaviors.8 In any given election, there are countless factors at play—we cannot reduce social change to a single cause. For example, we should not forget the widespread and ongoing efforts at voter suppression, or the simple fact that Clinton chose not to campaign in the key swing state of Wisconsin during the general election. Nonetheless, the election of 2016 alerts us to the emergence of disturbing new practices of manipulative communication. And the danger of manipulative communication is all the more apparent in the wake of the 2021 Capitol insurrection.

从 2010 年代中期开始，我们看到了新的操纵形式：电子邮件账户黑客入侵和泄露行动、军事投资于社交媒体操纵能力，看似来自邻居但实际上在俄罗斯制造的消息，从互联网的不知名部分收集的表情包并贴在 Facebook 和 Instagram 上，实验性帖子旨在引发和利用特定的情绪反应。许多这些操纵性通信都是由数据收集工作推动的，并以虚假账户和掩护组织为特色，隐藏了他们的真实身份。操纵者与他们的目标进行人际交往，然后当他们看到他们的操纵信息在大众媒体上被放大时宣称胜利。

Starting in the mid-2010s, we saw new, emerging forms of manipulation: email account hack-and-leak operations, military investment in social media manipulation capabilities, messages appearing to come from neighbors but actually made in Russia, memes picked up from obscure parts of the internet and plastered over Facebook and Instagram, experimental posts meant to elicit and exploit particular emotional responses. Many of these manipulative communications were driven by data collection efforts and featured operatives hiding their true identities behind fake accounts and front organizations. The manipulators interpersonally engaged with their targets and then claimed victory when they saw their manipulative messages amplified across mass media.

这些操纵手段显然已经融合成了一种新的东西：大规模个人社会工程。我们将大规模个人社会工程定义为

There has been a clear convergence of these tactics of manipulation into something new: masspersonal social engineering. We define masspersonal social engineering as

一种新兴的操纵性传播形式，得益于互联网和社交媒体平台的独特功能。它汇集了黑客和宣传者、人际传播和大众传播各自的工具和技术，试图塑造受众的看法和行为。为了操纵，大众社会工程师会收集目标数据；创建虚假角色来分享信息；在与目标接触时混合欺骗、准确和友好；并渗透通信系统。在这种情况下，操纵可能涉及一系列目标，其中可能包括试图改变行为和信念。但它也可能包括阻止行动（例如投票）和放大或强化先前存在的信念（例如种族主义、性别歧视或其他社会分歧），只要这样做符合大众社会工程师或其客户的利益。

an emerging form of manipulative communication enabled by the unique affordances of the internet and social media platforms. It brings together the respective tools and techniques of hackers and propagandists, interpersonal and mass communication, in an attempt to shape the perceptions and actions of audiences. To manipulate, masspersonal social engineers gather data on their targets; create fake personas to share messages; mix deception, accuracy, and friendliness as they engage with targets; and penetrate communication systems. Manipulation, in this case, can involve a range of goals, which might include attempts to change actions and beliefs. But it could also include discouraging action (e.g., voting) and amplifying or intensifying preexisting beliefs (e.g., racism, sexism, or other social divisions) when doing so is in the perceived interests of the masspersonal social engineers or their clients.

自 2016 年大选以来，大规模个人社会工程愈演愈烈。尽管对俄罗斯干预大选进行了多次调查，尽管有举报、调查报道，尽管剑桥分析公司最终被解散，但外国政府和国内政治咨询机构对民主审议的操纵仍在继续。俄罗斯政府并没有停止寻求利用数字媒体制造混乱在美国选民中。俄罗斯机构继续在 2018 年中期选举和 2020 年总统选举中使用他们的技术。9虽然剑桥分析公司已不复存在，但它的技术已被 Phunware 和 Rally Forge 等公司采用，主要用于保守派事业和政客——尽管左翼组织也部署了这些策略。10研究人员甚至发现了一个新兴的地下“虚假信息即服务”市场，供应商出售操纵数字媒体的服务，以吹捧某个事业或打压和贬低竞争对手。11

Masspersonal social engineering has only intensified since the 2016 election. Despite several investigations into the Russian meddling, and despite whistleblowing, investigative reporting, and ultimately the dissolution of Cambridge Analytica, manipulation of democratic deliberation by both foreign governments and domestic political consultancies continues apace. The Russian government has not stopped seeking to use digital media to engineer chaos within the American electorate. Russian agencies continued to apply their techniques in both the 2018 midterm elections and the 2020 presidential election.9 And while Cambridge Analytica is no more, its techniques have been taken up by firms such as Phunware and Rally Forge, predominantly in service to conservative causes and politicians—although left organizations have also deployed these tactics.10 Researchers have even identified a nascent market for underground “disinformation as a service,” where vendors sell services to manipulate digital media to either puff up a cause or tear down and disparage a rival.11

总之，从 2016 年大选开始直至今天，一种新的操纵性沟通形式、一种新的社会工程形式日益受到关注。

In sum, starting with the 2016 election and continuing to today, a new form of manipulative communication, a new form of social engineering, has increasingly come into focus.

为什么“社会工程学”是一个恰当的标签

Why “Social Engineering” Is a Good Label

我们并不是唯一担心媒体操纵的人。很多人都在努力理解这些新形式的错误信息和虚假信息，而词汇尚未确定。12

We’re not the only ones concerned about media manipulation. Many people are trying to understand these new forms of misinformation and disinformation, and the vocabulary has yet to be decided upon.12

最常用的短语之一是“假新闻”，它具有穿透迷雾的吸引力，可以揭穿俄罗斯支持的帖子、放大的模因和心理广告的真面目：虚伪和误导。同样，正如最近一本学术书籍的标题所说，也许我们看到的是“谎言机器”，即开发用来欺骗我们的谎言的系统。13

One of the more common phrases being used is “fake news,” which has the appeal of cutting through the fog and labeling Russian-backed posts, amplified memes, and psychographic ads for what they are: disingenuous and misleading. Similarly, as the title of a recent academic book puts it, maybe what we’re seeing are “lie machines,” systems developed to pump out falsehoods that fool us.13

但“假新闻”或“谎言”这个标签似乎有些不足，未能把握操纵性沟通的复杂性。正如许多人指出的那样，“假新闻”将一切都简化为一个鲜明的真/假二元论。“谎言机器”的概念也是如此——人们会想象一个庞大的机器人和巨魔网络，不断散布奥古斯丁式的谎言。如果操纵性沟通真的是在说纯粹的谎言，揭穿谎言和维护真相应该是一件容易的事。但尽管所有的事实核查人员都指出了谎言，操纵仍在继续。此外，真/假二分法并不完全适用于操纵性沟通的许多做法。一条旨在引起你同情心的信息是谎言吗？一个有趣的模因是假的吗？你朋友支持的赞助帖子是不真实的吗？

But something about the “fake” or “lie” label seems to fall short, failing to grasp the complexity of manipulative communication. “Fake news,” as many others have pointed out, reduces everything to a stark true/false binary. The same is true of the concept of “lie machines”—one gets the vision of a vast network of bots and trolls churning out Augustinian lies. If manipulative communication was really an exercise in telling pure lies, it should have been an easy matter to debunk lies and hold up truths. But despite all the fact-checkers pointing out falsehoods, manipulation continues apace. Moreover, the true/false dichotomy doesn’t quite map onto a lot of the practices of manipulative communication. Is a message meant to elicit your sense of sympathy a lie? Is a funny meme a falsehood? Is a sponsored post that your friend endorses untrue?

“宣传”似乎是一个显而易见的术语，尽管它的含义多年来一直很模糊。14最近出版的一本书《计算宣传》旨在更新数字时代的术语，探讨算法和自动化在现代操纵性传播中的应用。15然而，宣传——现在通常被称为“公共关系”——只涉及传播的大众方面。16事实上，另一项最近的宣传研究《网络宣传》实际上将人际操纵与宣传区分开来，从而排除了现在社交媒体中可能出现的许多操纵性一对一互动。17

“Propaganda” seems to be an obvious term to use, even though its meaning has been muddied over the years.14 A recent book, Computational Propaganda, purports to update the term for the digital age, addressing the use of algorithms and automation in modern manipulative communication.15 However, propaganda—which is now more often called “public relations”—only invokes the mass side of communication.16 Indeed, another recent study of propaganda, Networked Propaganda, actually excludes interpersonal manipulation as distinct from propaganda, thus excluding many of the manipulative, one-on-one interactions now possible in social media.17

更接近事实的可能是“黑客攻击”。2016 年大选之后和 2020 年美国总统大选前夕，许多评论员使用了诸如“俄罗斯人正试图破解大选”之类的短语。但这一术语也不足为奇。“黑客攻击”让人联想到身穿连帽衫的独行侠，坐在发光的键盘上，疯狂地进行黑客攻击……究竟是什么？数字投票机的可黑客性一直是美国长期以来关注的问题。但 2016 年和 2020 年发生的事情与黑客攻击投票机无关——并不是说人们没有尝试过。18相反，评论员用“认知”来修饰“黑客攻击”，例如“黑客攻击我们的思想”。19这更接近于操纵性的大规模个人社会工程学发生时的情况。尤其是剑桥分析公司声称，它掌握了每个美国选民的数千个数据点，这让它能够找到微妙的心理杠杆来影响舆论。尽管剑桥分析公司可能夸大了其能力，其微目标定位品牌现已成为当代政治传播的固定手段。20

Closer to the mark might be “hacking.” After the 2016 election and in the run-up to the 2020 US presidential election, many commentators used phrases such as “the Russians are seeking to hack the election.” But this term is also inadequate. “Hacking” invokes the image of the hoodie-clad loner, sitting above a glowing keyboard and furiously hacking . . . what, exactly? The hackability of digital voting machines has been a longstanding concern in the US. But what happened in 2016 and again in 2020 wasn’t about hacking voting machines—not that people didn’t try.18 Instead, commentators modify “hacking” with “cognitive,” as in “hacking our minds.”19 This gets a bit closer to what happens when manipulative masspersonal social engineering occurs. Cambridge Analytica, in particular, claimed that it had thousands of data points on every American voter, allowing it to find the subtle mental levers to press in order to shape opinions. And while Cambridge Analytica may have exaggerated its abilities, its brand of microtargeting is now a fixture of contemporary political communication.20

但“黑客”一词似乎过于工具化。就像“谎言机器”一样，它非常明显：例如，如果恶意黑客获得计算机的 root 访问权限，他们就会获得完全控制权，这与 2016 年大选期间及之后试图进行的微妙操纵并不完全一致。没有人能获得他人思想的 root 访问权限。即使有数千个数据点，剑桥分析公司也无法控制任何人的思想。沟通——相互构建现实的复杂过程——不能简化为计算隐喻。

But “hacking” seems too instrumental. Like “lie machines,” it’s stark: if, for example, a malicious hacker gains root access to a computer, they get total control, which does not quite map onto the subtle manipulations attempted during the 2016 election and after. No one gets root access to someone else’s mind. Even with thousands of data points, Cambridge Analytica could not control anyone’s mind. Communication—the messy process of mutually building reality—cannot be reduced to a computational metaphor.

“网络战”是另一个术语，最著名的用途是作为传播学学者凯瑟琳·霍尔·杰米森的最新著作的标题。在《网络战：俄罗斯黑客和网络水军如何协助选举总统》一书中，杰米森认为，由于互联网研究机构的努力是由一个国家（俄罗斯）赞助的，针对另一个国家（美国），目的是干涉政治进程，因此我们必须将这一努力视为战争行为并作出相应反应。21因此，与“黑客攻击选举”不同（后者指的是个别黑客操纵目标机器或人员），杰米森的概念承认了俄罗斯人持续干涉民主审议的社会和政治规模。

“Cyberwar” is another term, most notably used as the title for communication scholar Kathleen Hall Jamieson’s latest book. In Cyberwar: How Russian Hackers and Trolls Helped Elect a President, Jamieson argues that because the Internet Research Agency efforts were sponsored by a state, Russia, and directed at another state, the US, and intended to interfere in a political process, we must therefore consider the effort an act of war and respond accordingly.21 Thus, unlike “hacking an election,” which invokes individual hackers manipulating targeted machines or people, Jamieson’s conception acknowledges the societal, political scale of the continued effort by Russians to interfere in democratic deliberation.

尽管“网络战”可能是俄罗斯国家支持的行动的一个诱人的标签，但我们认为，它既不适合俄罗斯的行动，也不适合剑桥分析公司等公司的行为。声称俄罗斯 2016 年的网络行动是一种“战争”，在现有的网络冲突法律或学术研究中并没有很好的依据。22即使“网络战”标签适用于俄罗斯在 2016 年、2018 年和 2020 年大选期间的尝试，我们该如何称呼剑桥分析公司或其他国内行为者的类似努力？23我们把咨询公司剑桥分析公司——毕竟它是受特朗普总统竞选团队聘用的——称为国家行为者吗？总部位于德克萨斯州奥斯汀的 Phunware 公司与 2020 年特朗普竞选团队合作，它在发动战争吗？24评论人士认为剑桥分析公司等公司“武器化”数据。25但我们不能基于战争隐喻来宣战。将网上的每一次恶意行为都称为“网络战争”只会进一步导致互联网军事化。26

Though “cyberwar” might be a tempting label for Russian state-sponsored operations, we argue that it is neither a good fit for Russia’s actions nor for the actions of firms like Cambridge Analytica. The claim that Russian cyber operations in 2016 were a type of “war” is not well rooted in existing law or scholarship on cyber conflict.22 Even if the “cyberwar” label applies to what Russia attempted during the 2016, 2018, and 2020 elections, what do we call similar efforts by Cambridge Analytica or other domestic actors?23 Do we call the consulting firm Cambridge Analytica—which was hired, after all, by the Trump presidential campaign—a state actor? Is Phunware, an Austin, Texas–based firm which worked with the 2020 Trump campaign, waging war?24 Commentators have argued that firms such as Cambridge Analytica “weaponize” data.25 But we cannot declare war based on a war metaphor. Calling every malicious act online “cyberwar” only invites further militarization of the internet.26

大多数用于对抗操纵性传播的概念都不够准确。但有一个术语被使用过，尽管它比“假新闻”、“谎言机器”、“宣传”、“认知黑客”或“网络战争”等词少得多，但我们发现它足够复杂和灵活，可以描述 2016 年出现并在当今数字媒体中继续猖獗的新型操纵性传播。

Most of the concepts used to wrestle with manipulative communication fall short. But there is one term that’s been used, albeit much less frequently than “fake news,” “lie machines,” “propaganda,” “cognitive hacking,” or “cyberwar,” that we find to be complex and flexible enough to describe the new form of manipulative communication that emerged in 2016 and continues to run rampant in digital media today.

这个术语就是“社会工程学”。

That term is “social engineering.”

这个词本身就很形象，没有定义，但让人联想到：通过系统化的技术来设计社交、塑造社交互动。这个词暗示着一个梦想：如果有技术可以让我们控制人性，就像我们可以通过工程来控制自然世界一样，那会怎样？事实上，这个术语确实指那些实践，我们将展示这一点。但“社会工程”不仅仅是形象，它有着悠久的历史，它超越了安全黑客和政治传播宣传者的领域，超越了针对个人的欺骗和塑造国家意识的愿望，超越了事实与谎言、友好与恶意、真诚行善与玩世不恭的机会主义以及对沟通的简单理解与复杂理解之间的模糊界限。

The term alone, with no definition in mind, is evocative: engineering the social, shaping social interactions through systematized techniques. The term hints at a dream: what if there are techniques that could allow us to control human nature, just as we could control the natural world through engineering? Indeed, the term does refer to those practices, as we will show. But “social engineering” is not just evocative; it has a deep history, one that extends past the realms of security hackers and political communication propagandists, beyond the targeting of individuals for con artistry and the desire to shape the consciousness of a nation, and across the blurry lines between fact and falsehood, friendliness and maliciousness, earnest do-goodism and cynical opportunism, and simplistic and complex understandings of communication.

论社会工程学

On Social Engineering

首先，让我们回顾一下一些将新的操纵性沟通与社会工程学概念联系起来的评论家。

First, let’s review some commentators who have connected the new manipulative communication to the concept of social engineering.

安全顾问将社会工程学与俄罗斯选举干预行动联系起来凯文·米特尼克。作为自封的“世界最著名黑客”，米特尼克将在我们的书中占据重要地位。米特尼克是著名的黑客，他最擅长使用欺诈手段获取受限制的计算机系统的访问权限。米特尼克不会从技术层面攻击网络（例如，试图突破网络加密或暴力破解密码），而是将目标对准人类：他会打电话给计算机操作员，直接询问密码。

One connection between social engineering and the Russian election interference operations was made by security consultant Kevin Mitnick. As the self-proclaimed “World’s Most Famous Hacker,” Mitnick will figure heavily in the pages of our book. Mitnick is notable as the hacker most associated with a specific practice of using con artistry to gain access to restricted computer systems. Rather than attack a network at a technical level—say, by trying to break through network encryption or brute force a password—Mitnick would target humans: he would call computer operators up on the phone and simply ask for the password.

他将这种做法称为“社会工程学”，这是黑客在 20 世纪 70 年代中期开始使用的一个术语。正如安全顾问 Sharon Conheady 所定义的那样，黑客社会工程学“涉及说服人们做出他们通常不会做的事情。” 27这些行动包括泄露密码、让人们随意进入公司园区的禁区、提供对受限信息或财务能力的访问权限，或访问恶意网站。对于黑客社会工程师来说，社会工程学的目标是个人：秘书、IT 员工、首席执行官、政治竞选工作人员。

He called this practice “social engineering,” a term that hackers started using in the mid-1970s. As security consultant Sharon Conheady defines it, hacker social engineering “involves convincing people to perform actions they would not normally do.”27 These actions include giving out passwords, letting people roam around restricted areas of a corporate campus, providing access to restricted information or financial capacities, or visiting a malicious website. For hacker social engineers, the target of social engineering is the individual: a secretary, an IT employee, a CEO, a political campaign staffer.

如今，米特尼克式的社会工程攻击主要通过电子邮件进行。我们称之为网络钓鱼。其基本手法是试图说服人们点击他们通常不应该点击的链接，这些链接可能会将恶意软件加载到用户的计算机上，或引导用户进入旨在窃取密码的欺骗性网站。您几乎肯定会收到这样的电子邮件。

These days, Mitnick’s style of social engineering happens predominantly over email. We call it phishing. The basic technique is to try to convince people to click links they normally should not, links that might either load malware onto the person’s computer or lead to spoofed websites meant to harvest passwords. You’ve almost certainly gotten such an email.

网络钓鱼是 2016 年大选的核心，因为俄罗斯人利用网络钓鱼攻击了希拉里·克林顿竞选团队主席约翰·波德斯塔的电脑。据美联社报道，在向前克林顿竞选团队工作人员发送了一系列未成功的网络钓鱼电子邮件后，俄罗斯人将目标锁定在了波德斯塔身上。2016 年 3 月 19 日，“莫斯科时间上午 11:28，有人为波德斯塔生成了一个恶意链接。维基解密随后发布的文件显示，这封恶意电子邮件六分钟后到达了他的收件箱。该链接被点击了两次。” 28

Phishing was central to the 2016 election, because the Russians used phishing to compromise the computer of John Podesta, then the chair of Hillary Clinton’s election campaign. According to AP News, after a series of unsuccessful phishing emails were sent to former Clinton campaign staffers, the Russians homed in on Podesta. On March 19, 2016, “a malicious link was generated for Podesta at 11:28 a.m. Moscow time. Documents subsequently published by WikiLeaks show that the rogue email arrived in his inbox six minutes later. The link was clicked twice.”28

回顾这次网络钓鱼攻击，米特尼克指出

Reflecting on this phishing attack, Mitnick notes that

有趣的是，俄罗斯人入侵民主党全国委员会所用的方法与普通民众（无论是骗子还是像我们这样进行安全测试的人）的方法其实没什么不同——我们都使用相同的鱼叉式网络钓鱼方法。这是社会工程学。29

what was interesting is that the methodology the Russians used to hack the DNC is really no different from what civilians, whether crooks or people like us doing security testing—we use the same method of spearphishing. It’s social engineering.29

但波德斯塔网络钓鱼攻击的目的不仅仅是让波德斯塔支付赎金或骗取他的钱财，大多数网络钓鱼攻击的目的都是如此。这些电子邮件被泄露给维基解密，目的是公开传播。在这里，网络钓鱼被用来揭露克林顿竞选团队的内部运作，煽动阴谋论，进一步玷污克林顿在选举期间的声誉。30

But the Podesta phishing attack was not just meant to get Podesta to pay a ransom or to con him out of money, as most phishing is meant to do. The emails were leaked to Wikileaks, with the goal being their public dissemination. Here, phishing was used to expose the inner workings of the Clinton campaign, fomenting conspiracy theories and further tarnishing Clinton’s reputation during the election.30

我们在这里看到的是“黑客攻击选举”，但我们希望更精确：这是对克林顿工作人员的网络钓鱼攻击，而不是对整个选举的攻击。考虑到结果——克林顿竞选团队的内部讨论被发布在维基解密上——这次特定的攻击肯定对选举产生了巨大的影响。这些电子邮件不仅成为媒体的素材，也成为支持特朗普的表情包战士的素材，他们的表情包会被俄罗斯人利用社交媒体放大。所以，我们可以说，2016 年大选是黑客意义上的社会工程，即人际欺骗，即说服某人做他们不应该做的事情，从而导致计算机安全漏洞。

Here we see “hacking an election,” but we want to be more precise: it was a phishing hack of a Clinton staffer, not the election as a whole. Given what resulted—the Clinton campaign’s internal deliberations being posted on WikiLeaks—this specific attack certainly had massive ramifications for the election. The emails became fodder not just for media outlets but also for pro-Trump meme warriors, whose memes would be amplified by Russians using social media. So, we may say that the 2016 election was socially engineered in the hacker sense of an interpersonal con job, the convincing of someone to do something they should not, resulting in a computer security breach.

但归根结底，这只是针对一个人的一种黑客技术，可以说，这种社会工程学只是一种策略，用于支持一项在全国范围内实施的更大战略，该战略包括宣传活动、政治沟通和社交媒体攻击。那么问题来了：“社会工程学”一词能否涵盖这种规模，还是说它还不够？

But ultimately, it was one person targeted with one hacker technique, and arguably such social engineering was only one tactic used in support of a larger strategy that played out on a national scale, a strategy that included propaganda campaigns, political communication, and social media trolling. The question then becomes: can the term “social engineering” capture this scale, or is it inadequate?

简而言之，它可以。让我们再看看安全研究人员在讨论俄罗斯行动时使用“社会工程”标签的另一种方式。正如领先的安全学者托马斯·里德所说，俄罗斯的行动始于 2016 年，一直持续到今天，是“战略层面的政治工程、社会工程”。31至于剑桥分析公司等政治传播公司，一些评论员将他们的传播实践称为社会工程。一位安全研究人员使用这个标签来指“像剑桥分析公司和 [特朗普顾问] 史蒂夫·班农的宣传机器这样的公司”通过社会工程进行“社会入侵”。32其他人称之为“极端社会工程”——使用大型数据集进行“大规模的非法欺骗活动”。33最明确的谴责来自剑桥分析公司告密者克里斯托弗·怀利的书《Mindf*ck》，其中将该公司试图操纵社会比作修建铁路。34

In short, it can. Consider another use of the label “social engineering” to discuss the Russian operation, this time by security researchers. As Thomas Rid, a leading security scholar, put it, the Russian operation that started in 2016 and continues to this day is “political engineering, social engineering on a strategic level.”31 As for political communication firms, such as Cambridge Analytica, several commentators referred to their communication practices as social engineering. One security researcher used the label to refer to “companies like Cambridge Analytica and the propaganda machine of [Trump advisor] Steve Bannon” as engaging in “social inception” via social engineering.32 Others called it “extreme social engineering”—the use of large datasets allowing for “illicit deception campaigns on a large scale.”33 The most explicit condemnation comes from Cambridge Analytica whistleblower Christopher Wylie’s book Mindf*ck, which likened the firm’s attempted manipulation of society to engineering a railroad.34

这些对俄罗斯互联网研究机构和剑桥分析公司的批评借鉴了黑客对社会工程学的理解（例如，网络钓鱼、骗取人们的密码），但略有不同。这些行动不是针对个人，而是大规模地进行，声称针对的是人群。事实上，一个安全研究团队明确指出了这一点：“虽然[黑客社会工程学]过去是通过面对面、电话或书面形式进行的，但现在社会工程学可以通过社交媒体和其他互联网平台在社会规模上发生。” 35

These critiques of Russia’s Internet Research Agency and Cambridge Analytica draw on the hacker sense of social engineering (e.g., phishing, conning people out of passwords), but with a twist. Instead of targeting individuals, these operations worked on a massive scale, claiming to target populations. Indeed, one team of security researchers makes this point explicitly: “while [hacker social engineering] was historically practiced face-to-face, over the phone, or through printed writing, social engineering can now occur on societal scales through social media and other internet platforms.”35

虽然这些评论者可能主要借鉴了“社会工程”一词的黑客含义，但在引起人们对这些努力的社会规模的关注时，他们援引了“社会工程”的不同含义，这种含义可以追溯到 19 世纪末，并在 20 世纪 20 年代至 50 年代达到顶峰。社会工程的这种含义与大众媒体、宣传和公共关系有关。夫妻档爱德华·伯内斯和多丽丝·弗莱施曼最能说明这一点，他们将 20 世纪早期的宣传工作称为“同意工程”。伯内斯和弗莱施曼这样的同意工程师为当代的同意工程领域奠定了基础。公共关系——以前称为“宣传”。36在这种形式的社会工程学中，其目标不是集中精力让个人采取行动（比如像计算机黑客那样泄露密码），而是掌握人群，影响他们购买更多产品、尊重公司领导者或支持战争努力。

While they may be drawing largely on the hacker sense of the term “social engineering,” in drawing attention to the societal scale of these efforts, these commentators invoke a different meaning of “social engineering,” an older one that dates back to the late nineteenth century and reached its apogee in the 1920s to 1950s. This meaning of social engineering is associated with mass media, propaganda, and public relations. It is best illustrated by the husband-and-wife team Edward Bernays and Doris Fleischman, who referred to their early twentieth-century work on propaganda as the “engineering of consent.” Consent engineers like Bernays and Fleishman laid the groundwork for the contemporary field of public relations—previously called “propaganda.”36 In this version of social engineering, rather than concentrating on getting an individual to take an action—like giving out a password, as a computer hacker might—the goal is to master crowds of people, influencing them to buy more products, respect their corporate betters, or support a war effort.

就像使用网络钓鱼这种黑客社会工程技术一样，俄罗斯的行动也包括使用大众宣传。美国国家情报总监办公室 (ODNI) 在 2017 年报告称，“俄罗斯的国家宣传机器——由其国内媒体机构、面向全球受众的媒体机构（如RT和Sputnik）以及准政府巨魔网络组成——为影响力运动做出了贡献，成为克里姆林宫向俄罗斯和国际受众传递信息的平台。” 37

And just as it used the hacker social engineering technique of phishing, the Russian operation has included the use of mass propaganda. The US Office of the Director National Intelligence (ODNI) reported in 2017 that “Russia’s state-run propaganda machine—comprised of its domestic media apparatus, outlets targeting global audiences such as RT and Sputnik, and a network of quasi-government trolls—contributed to the influence campaign by serving as a platform for Kremlin messaging to Russian and international audiences.”37

这种社会工程形式在很多方面都是经典的宣传，20 世纪早期的传播理论家很容易将其识别为“通过操纵重要符号来管理集体态度”。38国家情报总监的报告评估称， RT和Sputnik放大了美国国内现有的争议，例如有关警察权力的争论、对使用水力压裂的担忧以及对银行救助的抗议，以进一步煽动不满情绪。39总体目标是通过将俄罗斯描绘成一个理智、慎重的世界领导者，将美国描绘成一个虚伪、充满异议的帝国主义强国，来提高人们对俄罗斯地缘政治政策的接受度。40从这个意义上说，俄罗斯的努力是伯内斯和弗莱施曼所说的较老的“同意工程”意义上的社会工程尝试。41

This form of social engineering is in many ways classic propaganda, a form early twentieth-century communication theorists would have easily recognized as “the management of collective attitudes by the manipulation of significant symbols.”38 RT and Sputnik, the DNI report assessed, amplified existing domestic controversies in the United States, such as debates over police power, concerns over the use of fracking, and protests over bank bailouts, in order to sow further discontent.39 The overall goal was to increase acceptance of Russian geopolitical policies by presenting Russia as a sane, measured world leader and the United States as a hypocritical, dissent-laden imperialist power.40 In this sense, the Russian effort was an attempt at social engineering in the older, “engineering of consent” sense of Bernays and Fleischman.41

此类尝试并不仅限于俄罗斯行动。随着剑桥分析公司在 2010 年代初声名鹊起，它向其客户的政治竞选活动承诺，它可以影响全国选举，使其对他们有利。正如剑桥分析公司举报人布列塔尼·凯泽 (Brittany Kaiser) 在她的回忆录中回忆的那样，该公司“积累了大量武器库剑桥分析公司为特朗普 2016 年的总统竞选部署了这一庞大的数据库。与之前的伯内斯和弗莱施曼一样，剑桥分析公司认为其工作是操纵选民的同意，影响人们做出决定，正如凯撒所说，“违背他们的惯常判断，改变他们的习惯行为”，并影响历史进程。

Such attempts weren’t limited to the Russian operation. As Cambridge Analytica grew in stature in the early 2010s, it promised the political campaigns it took on as clients that it could shape national elections in their favor. As Cambridge Analytica whistleblower Brittany Kaiser recalls in her memoir, the firm “had amassed an arsenal of data on the American public of unprecedented size and scope, the largest, as far as [they] knew, anyone had every assembled.”42 This massive database was deployed by Cambridge Analytica on behalf of Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign. Like Bernays and Fleischman before it, Cambridge Analytica saw its job as engineering the consent of voters, swaying people to make decisions, as Kaiser puts it, “against their usual judgment, and to change their habitual behavior” and affect the course of history.43

因此，我们在这里看到了“社会工程”一词，它至少有两层含义，都阐明了新的操纵性传播实践。黑客含义是指个性化的欺骗，就像俄罗斯人对克林顿竞选团队的约翰·波德斯塔所做的那样。政治含义是指通过媒体进行大规模、大众的社会操纵，就像俄罗斯互联网研究机构和政治传播公司尝试过的那样。

Here, then, we have a term, “social engineering,” that at the very least bears two meanings, both of which illuminate new manipulative communication practices. The hacker meaning invokes personalized con artistry, the sort of thing the Russians did to the Clinton campaign’s John Podesta. The political meaning invokes large-scale, mass societal manipulation via media, the sort of thing attempted by the Russian Internet Research Agency and political communication firms.

但正如我们将要展示的，社会工程学并非仅仅具有双重含义。相反，它可以同时涵盖人际和大众媒介。我们可以将新兴的操纵性信息传递实践比作大规模的社会工程宣传实践，但这并不能完全体现所发生的事情的全部意义。大规模社会工程学——宣传者和公共关系从业者的艺术——针对的是大群体和人口。这种形式采用了 20 世纪初发展起来的社会科学，具有宏大的社会抱负，将人群或群众作为操纵的中心对象。因此，这个含义无疑抓住了 2016 年以来出现的新型操纵性传播的规模。

But as we will show, social engineering does not simply have a split meaning. Instead, it can encompass both interpersonal and mass vectors. We could liken emerging practices of manipulative messaging to the large-scale social engineering practice of propaganda, but that does not quite capture the full sense of what happened. Mass social engineering—the art of propagandists and public relations practitioners—targeted large groups and populations. Taking up the social sciences developed at the turn of the twentieth century, this form had grand societal ambitions and held crowds or masses as the central object to manipulate. So, this meaning certainly captures the scale of the new form of manipulative communication that emerged since 2016.

但这种新形式的独特之处在于试图通过社交媒体针对个人，以期产生社会规模的影响。

But much of what makes that new form unique was the attempted targeting of individuals via social media with the ambition of having societal-scale effects.

因此，社会工程学的另一个含义，即人际黑客的含义，往往看起来更接近事实，因为这种方法主要针对个人目标。回到上文引用的国家情报总监的话，请注意旧宣传主题的现代演绎：使用“准政府巨魔网络”。44这些巨魔在干什么？互联网研究机构的巨魔亲自控制社交媒体账户，这些账户“自发且反应灵敏，与真实用户（著名的影响者和媒体以及普通人）互动，参与实时对话，创建民意调查，玩标签游戏。” 45这不是群发信息，而是高度个性化，更像是黑客开发的社会工程形式。

Thus, the other meaning of social engineering, the interpersonal hacker meaning, often appears to come closer to the mark, since that approach is predominantly directed at individual targets. Returning to the Director of National Intelligence quote cited above, note a modern twist on the older propaganda theme: the use of “a network of quasi-government trolls.”44 What were these trolls up to? The Internet Research Agency trolls were personally controlling social media accounts that “were spontaneous and responsive, engaging with real users (famous influencers and media as well as regular people), participating in real-time conversations, creating polls, and playing hashtag games.”45 This is not mass messaging, but highly personalized, more like the form of social engineering developed by hackers.

此外，剑桥分析公司等公司向客户推销的宣传显然不是要掌握人群和群众。例如，剑桥分析公司庞大的美国选民数据库并非针对他们所认为的“全面广告……旨在向广大受众发送信息，并以巨大的、同质化的爆炸式传播”。46相反，剑桥分析公司以“微定位”的精确性来吸引客户，他们获取客户的数据并使用“自己的算法对其进行扫描，识别可能的政治信仰和个性特征[选民]。然后，他们可以决定针对谁，并制作可能吸引这些人的信息。” 47从这个意义上说，该公司与过去几年的大众宣传者形成了鲜明对比，声称将心理统计学与当代社交媒体的分析和定位功能融合在一起。微定位并没有随着剑桥分析公司的倒闭而消失：特朗普 2020 年竞选活动也试图利用 Facebook 的广告工具对选民进行微定位。48同样，就像俄罗斯人个人控制的社交媒体账户一样，这种方法听起来更像是人际黑客社会工程，而不是同意工程师的群发信息。

Moreover, the sales pitch that firms like Cambridge Analytica bring to clients is decidedly not about mastering crowds and masses. Cambridge Analytica’s massive database on American voters, for example, was not geared towards what they dismissed as “blanket advertising . . . messaging intended for a broad audience and sent out in a giant, homogeneous blast.”46 Instead, Cambridge Analytica wooed clients with the promise of the precision of “microtargeting,” taking their data and using “its own algorithm to scan them, identifying likely political persuasions and personality traits [of voters]. They could then decide who to target and craft their messages that was likely to appeal to them for those individuals.”47 In this sense, the firm contrasted itself with the mass propagandists of years past, claiming to fuse the science of psychographics with the profiling and targeting capabilities of contemporary social media. Microtargeting has not gone away with Cambridge Analytica’s demise, either: the Trump 2020 campaign also sought to microtarget voters using Facebook’s advertising tools.48 Again, like the personally controlled social media accounts of the Russians, this approach sounds far more like interpersonal hacker social engineering than the mass messaging of the consent engineers.

总体而言，俄罗斯的选举干预行动和政治传播微目标活动表明大众形式的社会工程与人际黑客社会工程之间的界限已经变得模糊。如果我们将最近干涉或操纵美国选民的企图视为社会工程，并且如果“社会工程”一词同时涉及大众和人际传播实践，那么“大众”和“人际”之间的旧有界限可能不再有用。因此，我们转向一种更新、趋同的传播过程概念，即大众-人际传播，然后是我们的最终概念目标，即大众-人际社会工程。

Overall, the Russian election interference operations and the political communication microtargeting campaigns reveal that the lines between a mass form of social engineering and the more interpersonal hacker social engineering have become blurry. If we consider the recent attempts to interfere with or manipulate the American electorate as social engineering, and if the term “social engineering” invokes both mass and interpersonal communicative practices, the older divisions between “mass” and “interpersonal” may no longer be useful. We thus turn to a newer, convergent conception of the communication process, masspersonal communication, and then our ultimate conceptual goal, masspersonal social engineering.

论大众传播

On Masspersonal Communication

传播学传统上观察到一条明显的界限。一方面是人际传播：人们面对面、通过电话或通过电子邮件或短信等数字媒体相互交谈。另一方面是大众传播：一对多模式。印刷机、电影、广播和电视等技术的出现，使得大规模的一对多、非个人和异步通信成为可能。因此，在整个二十世纪，传播理论家根据这两种主要的传播模式的不同“渠道”来区分它们：直接和同步，或大众媒介。时至今日，美国许多传播学院和系都专注于大众传播（通常专攻新闻学）或人际传播。49

Communication studies has traditionally observed a stark boundary. On one side, there’s interpersonal communication: people talking to each other, either face to face, over the phone, or through digital media such as email or texting. The other side is mass communication: a one-to-many model. The advent of technologies like the printing press, and later cinema, radio, and television, allowed for one-to-many, impersonal, and asynchronous communication on a mass scale. Through the twentieth century, then, communication theorists distinguished between these two dominant models of communication based on the different “channels” by which they occurred: direct and synchronous, or mass mediated. To this day, many schools and departments of communication in the United States focus on either mass communication (typically specializing in journalism) or interpersonal communication.49

但随着 20 世纪下半叶计算机媒介通信技术的出现，这一区别以及其他许多区别开始变得模糊。随着互联网的日益普及，这一进程在 20 世纪 90 年代和 21 世纪初加速。这些技术变革与同一时期，西方国家出现了后现代和后工业社会。到了 20 世纪 90 年代，流行评论家们开始赞扬信息革命及其所谓的“新经济”的优点，这种新经济允许即时生产和大规模定制。在新经济中，信息和通信技术将允许大规模生产符合买家要求的个性化商品。50

But this distinction, along with many others, began to blur with the advent of computer-mediated communication technologies in the latter half of the twentieth century. That process was accelerated in the 1990s and early 2000s with the growing popularization of the internet. These same technological changes were linked to the emergence of postmodern and postindustrial societies in Western nations during this same period. By the 1990s, popular commentators were extolling the virtues of the information revolution and its supposedly “new economy” that allowed for just-in-time production and mass customization. In the new economy, information and communication technologies would allow for the mass production of goods personalized to the buyer’s specifications.50

鉴于这些变化，学者们开始质疑大众传播和人际传播之间的传统区别。51他们开始注意到，互联网不仅允许此前无法使用大众广播技术的个人进行一对多的交流，而且还允许他们以虚拟和远程的方式进行传统上在面对面的情况下被认为是人际的交流。

In light of these changes, scholars began to question the traditional distinction between mass and interpersonal communication.51 They began to note that the internet not only allowed individuals heretofore lacking access to the technologies of mass broadcast to engage in one-to-many communications of their own but also to engage virtually and remotely in communications that would traditionally have been considered interpersonal had they occurred face-to-face.

尽管大众/人际之间的区别正在逐渐消失，这一点越来越明显，但学者们仍然很难完全解释这种变化。2018 年，传播理论家帕特里克·奥沙利文 (Patrick O'Sullivan) 和卡勒布·卡尔 (Caleb Carr) 认为，这是因为学者们仍然主要根据传播发生的“渠道”来定义两种主要的传播模式——例如，电话是人际的，电视是大众的。52大众-人际传播理论家认为，我们应该关注发送者的“可访问性感知，即可以查看消息的人数”，以及“接收者对个性化的主观判断，即消息在多大程度上被认为是针对他们个人量身定制的”，而不是渠道。53大众传播信息旨在让广大受众广泛接受，而人际传播信息则恰恰相反。很大程度上取决于信息如何根据接收者的“独特性或独特性”进行量身定制，这通常基于对接收者的“兴趣、历史、关系网络等”的分析。54

Though it was becoming increasingly clear that the mass/interpersonal distinction was dissolving, it remained difficult for scholars to fully account for this change. In 2018, communication theorists Patrick O’Sullivan and Caleb Carr argued that this was because scholars had continued to define the two dominant models of communication primarily based on the “channel” by which such communication occurred—phones are interpersonal, television is mass, for example.52 Instead of channels, masspersonal communication theorists argue we should focus on the sender’s “perception of accessibility, or the perceived number of people who can view a message,” and “the receiver’s subjective judgments of personalization, or the extent to which a message is perceived as tailored to them personally.”53 While mass communication messages are intended to be widely accessible by a large audience, interpersonal messages are intended to be the opposite. Much hinges on how the message is tailored to the “uniqueness or distinctiveness” of the receiver, often based on an analysis of the receivers’ “interests, history, relationship network, and so on.”54

当我们关注信息的可及性和个性化而非渠道时，我们开始发现许多信息介于大众和人际之间。一条发给某个人的推文可能会被数百万人看到，一通电话可以被录音并重播，一位政客的儿子可以在电视演讲中衷心地请求父亲的爱。对于奥沙利文和卡尔来说，这种介于个性化和大众之间的流动性就是“大众个人交流”。

When we focus on accessibility and personalization of messages rather than channel, we start to see that many messages fall in between mass and interpersonal. A tweet directed at a particular person might be seen by millions, a phone call can be recorded and rebroadcast, a politician’s son could make a heartfelt plea for his father’s affection during a televised speech. This fluidity between personalized and mass spectrum is, for O’Sullivan and Carr, “masspersonal communication.”

尽管 O'Sullivan 和 Carr 指出，这种交流的例子在历史上随处可见，但大众个人交流的典型代表当然是社交媒体。例如，他们提供 Twitter 提及、Facebook 评论和点赞、个性化视频或更恶意的“定制垃圾邮件”。他们解释说，这种定制或个性化是通过跟踪和汇编有关人们在线活动的数据来实现的，然后传播者可以向个人或小群体“定向传播”他们的个性化信息。55

Though O’Sullivan and Carr note that examples of such communication can be found throughout history, the poster child for masspersonal communication is, of course, social media. As examples, they offer Twitter mentions, Facebook comments and likes, personalized video, or the more malicious “tailored spam.” This tailoring or personalization, they explain, is enabled by tracking and compiling data about people’s online activities, which then allows communicators to “narrowcast” their personalized messages to individuals or small groups.55

信息的个性化程度也会影响接收者的反应，从而导致互动或单向接收。56 这种个性化可能涉及针对个人或小群体发送信息，该信息可以被更多受众广泛接受，但专门设计用于引起接收者的某种反应。正如 O'Sullivan 和 Carr 解释的那样，

The degree to which the message is personalized also affects how the receiver of the message might respond, leading to interactions or one-way reception of the message.56 Such personalization can involve targeting an individual or small group with a message that is widely accessible to larger audiences and yet is specifically designed to elicit some kind of response on the part of the receiver. As O’Sullivan and Carr explain,

...个性化互动可供广大受众使用，但其目的是提供个性化信息，因为其内容仅适用于预期接收者，而预期接收者可能是个人或特定受众（例如追随者）。此外，大众个人交流通常有助于（非）预期接收者做出私人或公开回应。57

. . . a personalized interaction is accessible to a large audience, yet is intended as a personalized message in that its content is applicable only to the intended recipient, which may be an individual or select audience (e.g., followers). Moreover, masspersonal communication often facilitates either a private or public response from the (un)intended receiver(s).57

大众传播中的个性化，或者将传统的人际传播扩大到更大的规模，是数字媒体生活的现实。社交媒体影响者让与粉丝建立真实的联系。一小群人为自己消费而制作表情包，他们的表情包逐渐进入大众意识。58原本发给某人的电子邮件泄露成为新闻头条。企业社交媒体中的个性化广告信息作为全球广告活动的一部分增加了销量。当然，其不利之处是以前的大众信息策略的个性化：营销人员希望客户与大规模生产的品牌建立个人关系。大型活动被分解为针对越来越细的受众群体进行信息的“A/B”测试。59总而言之，传播领域旧有的学科分工不再适用。同样，在数字时代，大众操纵和人际欺骗之间的界限也变得模糊。

Personalization in mass communication, or the scaling up of traditionally interpersonal communication to a larger scale, is the reality of life with digital media. Social media influencers make authentic connections with their fans. Small groups of people making memes for their own consumption see their memes bubble up into popular consciousness.58 Emails meant for one person leak and become news headlines. Personalized advertising messages in corporate social media increase sales as part of a global advertising campaign. And, of course, the flipside is the personalization of previous mass messaging tactics: marketers want customers to have personal relationships with mass-produced brands. Large campaigns get decomposed into “A/B” testing of messages on increasingly granular audience segments.59 In sum, the old disciplinary division in the field of communication is no longer useful. Likewise, the division between mass manipulation and interpersonal con artistry is also blurring in the digital age.

大规模个人社会工程学

Masspersonal Social Engineering

大众个人传播包括多种传播实践。我们感兴趣的是社会工程学的具体传播实践，我们将展示这种实践是信息收集、欺骗和无视真相的陈述的混合体，所有这些都是为了让人们采取社会工程师希望他们采取的行动。

Masspersonal communication includes many communicative practices. Our interest is in the specific communicative practice of social engineering, a practice we will show to be a mixture of information gathering, deception, and truth-indifferent statements, all with the instrumental goal of getting people to take actions the social engineer wants them to take.

我们认为，俄罗斯正在进行的行动、剑桥分析公司以及随后类似的操纵性沟通尝试，凸显出这样一个事实：社会工程学的双重含义——旧式的大众同意工程学和新式的个性化黑客骗局——与其说是一种二分法，不如说是一种错误的二分法。正如大众和人际沟通模式之间的区别从未像某些人所认为的那样明显一样，大众和人际形式的社会工程学之间一直存在重叠。尽管这两种含义是独立发展的，但事实并非如此。尽管两种含义在时间上是分开的，并且有着不同的历史，但伯内斯和弗莱施曼在20世纪初提出的“同意工程”，利用大众媒体技术说服目标公众采取特定的立场，与凯文·米特尼克 (Kevin Mitnick) 旨在让目标用户交出计算机密码的人际骗术风格并无太大区别。

We argue that the ongoing Russian operations, Cambridge Analytica, and subsequent, similar attempts at manipulative communication bring into stark relief the fact that the dual-meaning of social engineering—older, mass consent engineering and the newer, individualized hacker con artistry—was not so much a bifurcation as a false dichotomy. Just as the distinction between mass and interpersonal models of communication were never as stark as some had assumed, there has always been an overlap between mass and interpersonal forms of social engineering. This is in spite of the fact that the two meanings developed independently of one another. While the two meanings are separated in time and have distinct histories, the “consent engineering” Bernays and Fleischman proposed in the early twentieth century, with its focus on mass media technologies to persuade targeted publics to adopt specific positions, is not too distinct from Kevin Mitnick’s style of interpersonal con artistry intended to get a targeted user to give up a computer password.

我们采纳了美国海军情报官约瑟夫·哈特菲尔德的观察，即大规模社会工程和人际黑客社会工程“在概念和语义上都是相互关联的”。60最终，就像通信一样，社会工程已经朝着我们称之为大规模个人社会工程的方向融合。在这本书中，我们将这种新的操纵性通信形式概念化，追踪较旧的大规模社会工程和较新的人际黑客社会工程如何在当今的数字媒体中融合。

We take up US Naval intelligence officer Joseph Hatfield’s observation that mass social engineering and interpersonal hacker social engineering are “both conceptually and semantically interrelated.”60 Ultimately, social engineering has converged just as communication has in the direction of what we will call masspersonal social engineering. In this book, we conceptualize this new form of manipulative communication, tracing how older mass social engineering and more recent interpersonal hacker social engineering are converging in today’s digital media.

本书的计划

Plan of the Book

在第一部分“社会工程”中，我们将讨论 20 世纪早期较早的大众社会工程。这种社会工程形式在 20 世纪 20 年代至 50 年代达到鼎盛，历史学家对此已有详尽的记录。61大众社会工程师有一个宏伟的愿景：社会科学得出的见解可以应用于缓解特定的社会弊病，例如种族关系、阶级关系或对新消费品缺乏认识。如果我们必须用一种传播技术来象征大众社会工程，那就是报纸。它的主要实践者是公共关系顾问，一位 20 世纪早期的传播评论家将这一角色称为“群众大师” 。62

In part I, Engineering the Social, we will discuss the older mass social engineering of the early twentieth century. This form of social engineering, which saw its heyday from the 1920s through 1950s, has been well documented by historians.61 The mass social engineers had a grand vision: that the insights derived by social sciences could be applied to alleviate specific social ills, such as race relations, class relations, or the lack of awareness of new consumer goods. If we had to symbolize mass social engineering with a single communication technology, it would be the newspaper. Its key practitioner is the public relations consultant, a persona dubbed by one early twentieth-century communication critic the “crowd master.”62

然而，正如我们将要展示的，到了二十世纪中叶，大规模社会工程学不再那么受重视，甚至变得令人恐惧。自 20 世纪 70 年代以来，激进个人主义的兴起引发了人们对社会层面改善社会问题的尝试的深切担忧。无论是右翼政治还是左翼政治，前者提倡对国家心存恐惧的自由主义经济思想，后者认​​为大规模的企业和政府行为是一种只会推崇消费主义或发动战争的僵化官僚机构。

However, as we will show, by the mid-twentieth century, mass social engineering becomes far less valued; it even becomes feared. The radical individualism emphasized from the 1970s on brought about deep anxieties about societal-scale attempts to ameliorate social problems. This is true of both the political right, which fostered libertarian economic thinking that is fearful of the state, and the political left, which saw large-scale corporate and government practices as a deadening bureaucracy dedicated only to consumerism or war-making.

“社会工程”的另一层含义出现在 20 世纪 70 年代，当时旧形式似乎已消亡。这种形式就是黑客社会工程。我们所有的历史研究表明，黑客（最初被称为“电话飞客”，我们将在下文讨论）创造了“社会工程”一词来指代他们在人际交往中实施的欺骗和胡说八道的行为，但他们并不知道前几代社会改革者使用这个术语的方式截然不同。我们认为，电话飞客和黑客将继续将这种社会工程形式系统化，形成我们所说的人际或黑客社会工程。如果我们必须用一种技术来象征电话飞客/黑客社会工程，那就是电话。当然，它的实践者就是电话飞客或黑客。

Another meaning of “social engineering” emerged in the 1970s, right as the older form appeared to die. This form is hacker social engineering. All our historical research indicates that the hackers (originally known as “phone phreaks,” as we will discuss) coined “social engineering” as a name for their interpersonal practices of con artistry and bullshitting with no knowledge of the fact that the social reformers of previous generations used that term in a very different way. We argue that the phreaks and hackers would go on to systematize this form of social engineering into what we call interpersonal or hacker social engineering. If we had to symbolize phone phreak/hacker social engineering with a single technology, it would be the telephone. Its practitioner, of course, would be the phreak or hacker.

由于我们的最终目标是研究 2016 年及以后大规模个人社会工程的出现，因此我们的任务是概念化什么是社会工程。我们在本书中采取的方法是特别关注黑客社会工程所使用的概念和术语。我们这样做有两个原因。首先，因为与大规模社会工程的学术研究相比，黑客社会工程的学术研究较少。如果我们专注于不太知名的黑客社会工程，我们的工作可以做出更大的贡献。但更重要的是，我们发现黑客社会工程已经开发出极其诚实——甚至是令人愉快的诚实——的语言来描述他们的工作，他们使用的概念是复杂的、富有智慧的和令人大开眼界的。举一个关键的例子，黑客社会工程最初提到社会工程学就是“胡说八道”。我们可能会本能地拒绝使用“胡说八道”这个词，因为它很粗俗——听起来不像学术——但正如我们将要展示的那样，哲学家们非常认真地对待“胡说八道”的概念，我们也会如此。此外，有了黑客胡说八道的概念，我们就有了一个新的视角来重新审视老式的大众社会工程师本身，认为他们都是能干的胡说八道者，我们可以认为最近的操纵性交流充斥着胡说八道。我们也可以对其他有趣的黑客概念做同样的事情，比如破坏和渗透。

Since our ultimate goal is to consider the emergence of masspersonal social engineering in 2016 and beyond, our task is to conceptualize what social engineering is. The course we have taken in this book is to pay special attention to the concepts and terms used by the hacker social engineers. We do so for two reasons. First, because in comparison to the scholarship on mass social engineering, there is less scholarship available on hacker social engineering. Our work can make a bigger contribution if we concentrate on the less well-known hacker social engineering. But more importantly, we find that hacker social engineers have developed brutally honest—even enjoyably honest—language for what they do and the concepts they use are sophisticated, intellectually rich, and eye-opening. For one key example, hacker social engineers initially referred to social engineering as “bullshitting.” Our impulse might be to reject the term “bullshitting” because it is crude—it doesn’t sound academic—but as we will show, philosophers have taken the idea of “bullshit” very seriously, and we will, too. Moreover, armed with the hacker concept of bullshitting, we gain a new lens to reconsider the older, mass social engineers themselves as able bullshitters, and we can consider more recent manipulative communication as rife with bullshit. We can do the same with other fascinating hacker concepts, like trashing and penetrating.

因此，本书将是对社会工程学的谱系，而不是逐年的历史。我们的方法是使用电话飞客和黑客社会工程学的概念，如破坏、借口、胡说八道和渗透，以更好地理解 20 世纪早期的大规模社会工程学和 21 世纪早期大规模个人社会工程学的出现。虽然我们对过去几年所目睹的一切感到震惊，虽然我们对这种大规模个人社会工程学的新兴实践感到担忧，但我们不想将这种实践视为全新的。我们在黑客社会工程学中看到了一组概念线索，将我们现在的时刻与过去联系起来，包括更早的大规模社会工程学。通过将当代操纵性沟通追溯到以前的社会工程学形式，也许震惊会逐渐消退，改善的可能性会变得更加清晰。

So, this book will be a genealogy of social engineering, rather than a year-by-year history. Our approach is to use the phone phreak and hacker social engineering concepts of trashing, pretexting, bullshitting, and penetrating to better understand both mass social engineering of the early twentieth century and the emergence of masspersonal social engineering in the early twenty-first century. While we are shocked by what we’ve witnessed these past few years, while we are concerned about this emergent practice of masspersonal social engineering, we do not want to treat the practice as entirely new. We see in hacker social engineering a set of conceptual threads that connects our current moment to the past, including the older mass social engineers. By tracing contemporary manipulative communication to previous forms of social engineering, perhaps the shock wears off and the possibilities for amelioration become clearer.

因此，本书的第二部分将围绕黑客概念展开。在第 4 章中，我们将从 20 世纪 70 年代到 90 年代黑客和电话窃贼收集情报的特殊方式开始：翻垃圾。我们将翻垃圾箱的行为与当代翻查互联网大数据的做法联系起来，我们还将回顾大众社会工程师，看看他们也翻垃圾的时刻。接下来，我们将解释借口的概念，或者黑客社会工程师在与目标交战时所扮演的角色，在第 5 章中，我们将发现爱德华·伯内斯 (Edward Bernays)、他的搭档多丽丝·弗莱施曼 (Doris Fleischman) 以及他们同时代的艾维·李 (Ivy Lee) 也依赖借口。我们接下来将介绍概念丰富、极具说服力的胡说八道实践，我们认为胡说八道是欺骗、准确性和社交性的无视真相的混合体，我们将在第 6 章中讨论。最好的黑客社会工程师会自豪地声称自己是优秀的胡说八道者。大众社会工程师永远不会这样称呼自己，但他们的胡说八道非常出色。然后，在第 7 章中，我们将转向渗透，这是黑客社会工程的目标，社会工程师可以控制那些控制系统和网络的所谓非理性的他人。我们将考虑大众和人际社会工程师提供的渗透隐喻。

Thus, part II of the book will be organized around the hacker concepts. In chapter 4, we will start with the peculiar way hackers and phone phreaks gathered intelligence in the 1970s through 1990s: going through trash. We connect the act of diving into a dumpster to contemporary practices of wading through Big Data culled from the internet, and we will also look back to the mass social engineers to see moments when they, too, looked through garbage. We will next explain the concept of the pretext, or the role a hacker social engineer plays during an engagement with a target, in chapter 5. We will find that consent engineers like Edward Bernays, his partner Doris Fleischman, and their contemporary Ivy Lee also relied on pretexts. We follow with the conceptually rich and profoundly compelling practice of bullshitting, which we see as a truth-indifferent mix of deception, accuracy, and sociability, discussed in chapter 6. The best hacker social engineers will proudly claim to be excellent bullshitters. Mass social engineers would never refer to themselves that way, but they bullshitted admirably. Then, in chapter 7, we will turn to penetration, the goal of hacker social engineering, where social engineers get control over the supposedly irrational Others who control systems and networks. We will consider the penetration metaphors offered by both mass and interpersonal social engineers.

在此过程中，本节还将展示社会工程学如何与更广泛的文化动态相结合，包括网络上爆炸式增长的数字数据过剩、种族刻板印象和性别角色。

Along the way, this section will also show how social engineering articulates with broader cultural dynamics, including the glut of digital data exploding across networks, racial stereotypes, and gender roles.

最后，第三部分将人际社会工程和大规模社会工程整合到大规模个人社会工程的新实践中。在第 8 章中，我们回到本导言的主题——一种新的操纵性沟通形式的出现——但新的形式配备了黑客社会工程师的概念和实践。我们从诋毁、借口、胡说八道和渗透的角度来考虑 2016 年的俄罗斯行动和剑桥分析公司。我们关注这两个是因为它们有充分的记录，但我们也会指出更近期的例子，这些例子符合大规模个人社会工程的模式。我们的目标是阐明黑客的人际社会工程实践是如何扩大规模以满足大规模社会工程师的社会野心的。我们看到这种情况发生在互联网上，带来了一种不信任、焦虑和衰败的政治环境。如果我们必须用一种通信技术来象征这种形式的社会工程，那就是社交媒体。其实践者包括心理营销人员和试图操纵选举的俄罗斯特工。

Finally, part III brings interpersonal social engineering and mass social engineering together into the new practice of masspersonal social engineering. In chapter 8, we return to the themes of this introduction—the emergence of a new form of manipulative communication—but freshly equipped with concepts and practices from hacker social engineers. We consider the 2016 Russian operation and Cambridge Analytica from the perspectives of trashing, pretexting, bullshitting, and penetrating. We focus on those two because they are well documented, but we will also point to more recent examples that fit the mold of masspersonal social engineering. Our goal is to illuminate the ways in which the interpersonal social engineering practices of hackers were scaled up to meet the societal ambitions of mass social engineers. We see this happening on the internet, bringing with it a political milieu of distrust, anxiety, and decay. If we had to symbolize this form of social engineering with a communication technology, it would be social media. And its practitioners include people like psychographic marketers and Russian operatives seeking to manipulate elections.

最后，我们将提出一些建议，说明如何破坏大规模个人社会工程。我们将再次使用飞客和黑客的概念，即破坏、借口、胡说八道和渗透，作为压力点，以找到大规模个人社会工程中的漏洞。虽然大规模个人社会工程是一种复杂的操纵性沟通实践，但我们可以找到破坏它的方法，并朝着更健康的民主协商迈进。

We will conclude with recommendations for ways to undermine masspersonal social engineering. Once again, we will use the phreak and hacker concepts of trashing, pretexting, bullshitting, and penetrating as pressure points to find vulnerabilities in masspersonal social engineering. While masspersonal social engineering is a complex manipulative communication practice, we can find ways to undermine it and move towards healthier democratic deliberation.

我

I

社会工程

Engineering the Social

1

1

群体大师：大规模社会工程的兴衰，1920-1976

Crowdmasters: The Rise and Fall of Mass Social Engineering, 1920–1976

我想尝试表达这样一种现代人……他们即将证明自己是我们现代世界的真正统治者，是群体想法的沉默主人。

I would like to try to express the type of modern man who . . . is about to prove himself the real ruler of our modern world, the silent master of what the crowds shall think.

——杰拉德·斯坦利·李谈“群众人”，《群众：民主的动态图》1

—Gerald Stanley Lee on “The Crowd-Man,” Crowds: A Moving-Picture of Democracy1

1990 年，在马萨诸塞州剑桥的一所房子里，一位 40 多岁的马克思主义消费主义批判学者采访了一位年近百岁的老人，这位老人正是这位学者所批评的消费社会的缔造者。这位年轻人是亨特学院电影与媒体研究教授斯图尔特·埃文。年长者是 20 世纪最重要的公共关系先驱之一爱德华·伯内斯。

In a house in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in 1990, a 40-something Marxian critical scholar of consumerism interviewed a wizened man of nearly 100 years, a man who had helped build the very consumer society the scholar was criticizing. The younger man was Stuart Ewen, a professor of film and media studies at Hunter College. The older was Edward Bernays, one of the most important public relations pioneers of the twentieth century.

尽管两人的背景不同，伯内斯对尤恩还是很热情，认为他是“少数聪明人”中的一员，肩负着“思考和影响历史潮流的责任”。2尤恩毕竟是一位出版过作品的作家和教授。伯内斯认为自己是一名知识分子，一名公共关系理论家——这是他在 20 世纪 20 年代帮助创建的领域。

Although their backgrounds were different, Bernays warmed up to Ewen, seeing him as a member of an “intelligent few” who was “charged with the responsibility of contemplating and influencing the tide of history.”2 Ewen was, after all, a published author and a professor. Bernays saw himself as an intellectual, a theorist of public relations—the field he had helped create in the 1920s.

在接受尤恩采访时，伯内斯解释了他对公共关系在社会中的作用的理论。由于尤恩是“少数聪明人”中的一员，伯内斯觉得他可以坦率地谈论这个领域的精英主义。尤恩写道：

In his interview with Ewen, Bernays explained his theory of the role of public relations in society. Since Ewen was a member of the “intelligent few,” Bernays felt that he could be frank about the field’s elitism. Ewen writes:

伯内斯解释说，作为指导社会命运的知识精英，[公共关系]“专业人士”的目标受众是本质上不加思考地被动反应的普通公众。在幕后工作、远离公众视线的公共关系专家是一名“应用社会科学家”，他们受过教育，能够运用对“社会学、心理学、社会心理学和经济学”的理解来影响和引导公众态度。在我们的整个谈话过程中，伯内斯表达了他对民主的幻想：一群受过高等教育的舆论塑造战术家不断工作，分析社会地形并调整公众思维的心理环境，而公众思维以其有限的智力从中得出自己的观点。3

As a member of that intellectual elite who guides the destiny of society, the [public relations] “professional,” Bernays explained, aims his craft at a general public that is essentially, and unreflectively, reactive. Working behind the scenes, out of public view, the public relations expert is an “applied social scientist,” educated to employ an understanding of “sociology, psychology, social psychology, and economics” to influence and direct public attitudes. Throughout our conversation, Bernays conveyed his hallucination of democracy: A highly educated class of opinion-molding tacticians is continuously at work, analyzing the social terrain and adjusting the mental scenery from which the public mind, with its limited intellect, derives its opinions.3

尤恩多年来一直研究伯内斯的著作，并撰写过有关“意识队长”和同意工程的书籍，因此，听到这种社会等级森严的观点，他可能并不感到惊讶，即“掌权的人……塑造了普通民众的态度” 。4

Ewen, who had studied the writing of Bernays for years and had authored books on “captains of consciousness” and consent engineering, was probably not surprised to hear this hierarchical vision of society, where “people in power . . . shape the attitudes of the general population.”4

如今，伯内斯的精英主义听起​​来已经过时，甚至危险地反民主。尤其是当我们被告知我们的意见很重要、社会运动可以利用当代媒体传播信息、我们终于可以向权力说出真相时，情况就更是如此了。即使在 20 世纪 90 年代，当尤恩采访伯内斯时，这位老人的想法似乎也令人反感。

Today, Bernays’s elitism sounds out of date, even dangerously anti-democratic. This is especially so when we are told that our opinions matter, that social movements can use contemporary media to spread their messages, and that we can finally speak truth to power. Even in the 1990s, when Ewen interviewed Bernays, the old man’s ideas seemed offensive.

事实上，伯内斯是另一个时代的产物，即 20 世纪初，当时精英专家（尤其是工程师）被视为人类的救世主。直到生命尽头（伯内斯于 1995 年去世，即埃文到访几年后），他都坚信群众需要领导力，而领导力将来自少数精英、技术官僚，他们将塑造群众的现实，从而创造一个更好的社会。

Indeed, Bernays was a product of another time, the early twentieth century, a time when elite experts—especially engineers—were seen as humanity’s saviors. Right up to the end of his life (Bernays died in 1995, a few years after Ewen’s visit), he held fast to his belief that the masses needed leadership, and that leadership would come from an elite, technocratic few who would shape the masses’ reality and thus produce a better society.

这些精英给自己起了各种各样的名字：“公共关系专家”、“新闻工程师”、“共识工程师”、“群众工”。我们称他们为大众社会工程师。他们的根源可以追溯到 20 世纪初，当时工程学备受推崇，以至于人们相信社会本身可以像桥梁或运河一样轻松地进行工程设计。

These elites used a variety of names for themselves: “public relations professional,” “news engineers,” “engineers of consent,” “crowd-men.” We will call them mass social engineers. Their roots lie in the turn of the twentieth century, a period when engineering was held in high esteem, so much so that people believed society itself could be engineered just as easily as a bridge or canal could be.

工程学会

Engineering Society

土木工程师兼作家塞缪尔·C·弗洛曼 (Samuel C. Florman) 于 1976 年撰文，怀念“工程黄金时代”——他将这段时期定义为 1850 年至 1950 年。5在这个黄金时代，尤其是 20 世纪初，工程师们渴望成为“人类的恩人”。6 工程师们对运河、桥梁、水坝和公共基础设施等巨大成就感到自豪，他们开始相信，他们的职业将为全人类带来民主分配的繁荣。“由于普通人的命运传统上一直是无情的艰辛，”弗洛曼写道，“黄金时代的工程师

Writing in 1976, civil engineer and author Samuel C. Florman pined for the “Golden Age of Engineering”—a period he defined as 1850 to 1950.5 During this Golden Age, especially in the early 1900s, engineers aspired to be “benefactors to mankind.”6 Flush with pride over massive successes—canals, bridges, dams, and public infrastructures—engineers came to believe that their profession would lead to democratically distributed prosperity for all of mankind. “Since the lot of the common man had traditionally been one of unrelenting hardship,” Florman writes, “engineers during the golden age

他们将自己的工作视为人类“摆脱令人绝望的苦差事和劳作的救赎者”。工程师们推断，一旦普通人从苦差事中解脱出来，他们必然会变得有教养、有文化、高尚，而人类的这种进步也将归功于工程师这个职业。当然，进步的人类会成为更幸福的人类。7

looked upon their works as man’s “redeemer from despairing drudgery and labor.” Once the common man was released from drudgery, the engineers reasoned, he would inevitably become educated, cultured and enobled, and this improvement in the race would also be to the credit of the engineering profession. Improved human beings, of course, would be happier human beings.7

因此，世纪之交的工程师们渴望将他们的技能应用于科学知识的实际应用中，改善人类的命运。可以说，他们做到了——例如，新的卫生系统对城市环境的健康做出了巨大贡献。8

Hence, turn-of-the-century engineers aspired to take their skills in practical application of scientific knowledge and improve the lot of humanity. Arguably, they did—for example, new sanitation systems contributed greatly to the health of urban environments.8

鉴于工程学看似无穷的力量，以及其将科学知识应用于实际问题的核心方法的灵活性，“工程师”这个标签开始在民用领域之外使用或许并不奇怪。起初二十世纪，我们看到了该领域的专业化：电气工程、市政工程、卫生工程和工业工程等等。

Given the seemingly boundless power of engineering and the flexibility of its central approach of applying scientific knowledge to practical problems, perhaps it is no surprise that the label “engineer” began to be used beyond the civil domain. At the beginning of the twentieth century, we see specializations of the field: electrical engineering, municipal engineering, sanitary engineering, and industrial engineering, to name a few.

当然，所有工程都是社会性的，都会影响社会的运作方式。有些工程学分支比其他分支更直接地针对人类行为。例如，卫生工程影响了城市中心的浪费和消费习惯。通过建设污水处理系统等基础设施这一看似政治中立的过程，工程师们开始看到他们的工作如何直接影响社会。正如弗洛曼所指出的，

All engineering is social, of course, affecting how societies function. Some subfields of engineering are more directly targeted at human action than others. Sanitary engineering, for example, affected habits of waste and consumption in urban centers. Through a seemingly politically neutral process of building infrastructures such as sewage systems, engineers started to see how their work could directly shape society. As Florman notes,

如果工程师能够以开放的心态和不带偏见的态度解决问题，即应用科学方法，那么是不是所有人都可以学会用这种方式思考，然后无知、迷信和偏见不就消失了？“我们是新时代的牧师，”一位工程学领袖在 1895 年告诉他的同事，“没有迷信。”

If engineers could solve problems by being open-minded and free of prejudices—by applying scientific methods—could not all men [sic] learn to think in this mode, and then would not ignorance, superstition and bigotry vanish? “We are the priests of the new epoch,” an engineering leader told his colleagues in 1895, “without superstitions.”

因此，在 20 世纪初，一种工程思维，即一种以科学为基础的关于如何以实用和中立的方式塑造社会的愿景，应运而生。随之而来的是一个新的想法：社会本身是可以被工程化的。

Thus, an engineering mindset, a scientifically informed vision of how to practically and neutrally shape society, emerged around the turn of the twentieth century. And along with it came a new idea: that society itself could be engineered.

这种社会工程思维最直接的表达出现在 20 世纪初，“社会工程师”这个称号再清楚不过了。19 世纪末和 20 世纪初，出现了一批新的专家。他们寻求事实，传播美国中产阶级白人价值观，努力使一切变得更有效率。他们将专业知识和精英知识置于大众民主决策之上。他们使用“社会工程师”这个称号，通过利用土木工程和机械工程的成功，帮助他们获得了合法性。他们认为科学思维可以应用于社会。9

The most direct expression of this engineering-of-society mindset that appeared in the early 1900s could not be clearer: the title of “social engineer.” In the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, a new wave of experts emerged. They sought facts, spread middle-class white American values, and worked to make everything more efficient. They placed expertise and elite knowledge above mass democratic decision-making. Their use of the title “social engineer” helped them gain legitimacy by appropriating the successes of civil and mechanical engineering. They argued that scientific thinking could be applied to society.9

这一时期的社会工程师分为三类。一类是社会改革者——社会福音基督教活动家和早期社会学家——他们试图改革社会。另一类是管理者理论家们研究工业资本主义下工人的管理方法。后来，出现了公共关系专家，他们将社会改革的语言与管理精英主义相结合，并利用新大众媒体塑造整个社会。这就是我们所说的大众社会工程师。

Social engineers of this period came in three varieties. There were social reformers—Social Gospel Christian activists and early sociologists—who sought to reform society. There were management theorists, who were studying ways to manage workers in industrial capitalism. And later, there were public relations specialists, who mixed the language of social reform with the elitism of management and took to new mass media to shape society as a whole. This is the group we call mass social engineers.

社会改革家

Social Reformers

正如多位历史学家所指出的，十九世纪末和二十世纪初的美国充满了焦虑：人们认为来自东欧的新移民正在稀释美国的价值观。罢工的工人和社会主义者与自由放任的资本家发生冲突，以相互竞争的政治经济观点引发社会动荡。由于缺乏消费者，生产增长导致市场效率低下。10也许这些焦虑的最佳表达来自人群的象征——由于压倒性的激情、歇斯底里和缺乏一致性，无法自我管理的非理性人群。世纪之交的思想家，如古斯塔夫·勒庞、沃尔特·李普曼和杰拉尔德·斯坦利·李警告了这些人群的危险。11正如勒庞的著名论点，“群众的神圣权利即将取代国王的神圣权利。” 12人群正在取代传统领导者，引发对暴民统治的担忧。

As multiple historians have noted, late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century America was marked by anxieties: new immigrants from Eastern Europe were thought to be diluting American values. Striking workers and socialists clashed with laissez-faire capitalists, causing social unrest with competing visions of political economy. And growth in production was leading to inefficiencies in the market because of a lack of consumers.10 Perhaps the best expression of these anxieties came in the symbol of the crowd—the irrational masses of humanity who could not govern themselves due to their overwhelming passions, hysteria, and lack of conformity. Turn-of-the-century thinkers such as Gustave Le Bon, Walter Lippmann, and Gerald Stanley Lee warned of the dangers of these crowds.11 As Le Bon famously argued, “the divine right of the masses is about to replace the divine right of kings.”12 The crowd was supplanting traditional leaders, bringing about fears of mob rule.

为了应对不守规矩的人群，社会理论家开始探索建设更好社会的方法。这种实证主义观点在一定程度上受到 20 世纪初新社会科学的推动，尤其是社会学、经济学和心理学，它们有望照亮以前混乱的人类行为世界。基本思想是将从社会学调查、经济分析或心理理论中收集到的专业知识应用到旨在指导新兴大众的特定社会计划中。正如美国总统统计协会在 1937 年提出，将社会科学应用于社会弊病就是社会工程，就像将物理学应用于桥梁建设被称为工程一样。13

As an antidote to the unruly crowd, social theorists began to explore ways to engineer a better society. This positivist vision was fueled in part by the advent of new social sciences at the turn of the twentieth century, particularly sociology, economics, and psychology, which promised to illuminate the previously messy world of human action. The basic idea was to implement the expert knowledge gleaned from sociological surveys, economic analysis, or psychological theorizing into specific social programs meant to guide the newly ascendant masses. As the president of the American Statistical Association put it in 1937, the application of social science to social ills would be social engineering, just as the application of physics to bridge-building was called engineering.13

这种思路的一个早期例子是德鲁神学院基督教社会学教授埃德温·厄普的作品。厄普在 1911 年出版的《社会工程师》一书中将卫理公会神学和社会科学融为一体，提倡“在教育中更加重视应用科学，重视那些将使人们既能做事又能了解事物的机械和工程学研究”。14这种社会科学知识的实际应用——结合基督教神学的道德指导——将缓解一系列社会问题，包括阶级冲突、种族冲突、“妇女和童工”、离婚、“赌徒与人民”，以及最重要的失业。15对于厄普来说，

An early example of this line of thinking is found in the work of Edwin Earp, a professor of Christian sociology at the Drew Theological Seminary. Blending together Methodist theology and social science, Earp’s 1911 book The Social Engineer promoted “greater emphasis in education upon applied science, upon those studies in mechanics and engineering that will equip men for doing things as well as knowing things.”14 Such practical application of social scientific knowledge—mixed with the moral guidance of Christian theology—would alleviate a range of social problems, including class conflict, racial strife, “woman and child labor,” divorce, “gamblers versus the people,” and above all, unemployment.15 For Earp,

社会工程不仅意味着慈善事业和慈善行为关爱罪恶和贫困的受害者，也意味着有组织、有智慧的努力，以消除导致这些慈善行为必要的原因，它还意味着通过明智的政治家通过社会控制对我们的经济和工业体系进行调整的尝试，以便社会生产的利润能够更公平地分配给社会中所有合法因素。16

Social engineering means not merely charities and philanthropies that care for the victims of vice and poverty, but also intelligent organized effort to eliminate the causes that make these philanthropies necessary, and it means also an attempt at a readjustment of our economic and industrial system by wise statesmanship through social control, so that the profits of social production may be more equitably distributed to all the legitimate factors in society.16

“社会控制”确实是社会改革者的口号，也是我们将在下文讨论的大众社会工程师的核心口号。

“Social control” was indeed a watchword of the social reformers, a watchword that would remain central to the mass social engineers we will discuss below.

通过社会工程进行社会控制在美国中产阶级中得到了拥护，他们担心将以东欧为主的移民浪潮融入美国社会。定居之家运动就是一个典型例子。定居之家位于芝加哥、纽约和波士顿等城市，这些城市位于新移民居住的廉租房社区，这些新移民来工厂工作。在定居之家里，富裕的年轻男女会“与城市贫民同住，分享他们的命运，帮助他们改善生活”。17这些社会改革者开设英语课程，幼儿园、艺术、手工艺和音乐课程以及讨论沙龙，所有这些都是为了让移民“美国化”。

Social control through social engineering found advocates among middle-class Americans concerned about integrating the waves of predominantly Eastern European immigrants into US society. The Settlement House Movement is a key example. Found in cities such as Chicago, New York, and Boston, settlement houses were located in tenement neighborhoods populated by new immigrants who came to work in factories. In them, affluent young men and women would settle “among the urban poor, share their lot, and help them improve their lives.”17 These social reformers ran English classes, kindergartens, arts, crafts, and music classes, and discussion salons, all with the intention of “Americanizing” the immigrants.

最初，安置所运动是由社会福音传教的追随者推动的，但随着时间的推移，它变得世俗化和专业化。安置所的管理者和参与者开始参加大学项目，并开始收集他们所在社区居民的数据，寻找贫困和无法融入美国主流社会的社会原因，并提出解决这一问题的方法。18这种数据收集最终以著名的匹兹堡调查或 1919 年报告《辛辛那提的社会工程》的形式从社区扩展到大都市层面。19正如一位历史学家所说，“社会工程师以‘事实’为荣。无论问题是什么，他们的首要建议总是收集信息。” 20此类社会数据收集、分析和干预成为“社会工程职业的门户”。21数据收集为社会改革者提供了丰富的职业机会，并为社会工程干预市政政治提供了平台。

Initially, the settlement house movement was driven by followers of Social Gospel evangelism, but over time, it became secularized and professionalized. The administrators and participants of settlement houses started college programs and began collecting data on the inhabitants of the neighborhoods they were located in, seeking out social causes for poverty and failures to assimilate into mainstream US society, and offering solutions to this problem.18 This data collection was eventually scaled up from neighborhoods to the metropolitan level in the form of the famous Pittsburgh Survey or the 1919 report Social Engineering in Cincinnati.19 As one historian argues, “social engineers gloried in ‘facts.’ Their first recommendation, no matter what the issue, was invariably the collection of information.”20 Such sociological data gathering, analysis, and intervention became a “gateway to careers in social engineering.”21 Data gathering provided a wealth of professional opportunities for social reformers and a platform for social engineering intervention in municipal politics.

第一次世界大战期间，这些社会改革者开始通过政府官僚机构将整个社会作为社会工程的目标，他们认为他们的专业知识对战争努力是无价的。22然而，随着社会改革者将他们的努力扩大到大都市甚至国家规模，他们发现仅靠他们的社会专业知识是不够的；他们需要与强大的利益集团合作，以实现他们对仁慈社会控制的愿景。23他们在另一群具有工程师思维的人中找到了这样的合作伙伴：科学管理者，他们也采用了社会工程这一术语。
