Paul and his Masters of Deception compatriots were continuing the long and honored phone phreak and hacker practice of trashing—“climbing around in garbage, where you hope to find computer printouts that list secret passwords and logons.”4 Trashing has been used by phone phreaks and hackers since at least the mid-1970s, and its intricacies have been discussed in zines such as Telephone Electronics Line, Technological Assistance Program, and 2600, and in computer bulletin board posts.5

1982 年，杰拉尔多·里维拉 (Geraldo Rivera) 警告美国，有“电子罪犯”（计算机黑客和电话盗贼，包括苏西·“雷霆”·海德利 (Susy “Thunder” Headley)）侵入计算机，垃圾甚至在国家电视台上大放异彩。里维拉在 ABC 的20/20节目中对着镜头说道，

Trashing even enjoyed a moment on national television in 1982 when Geraldo Rivera warned the United States about the “electronic delinquents” (computer hackers and phone phreaks, including Susy “Thunder” Headley) breaking into computers. As Rivera intoned to the camera during an episode of ABC’s 20/20,

你可能会问自己，一群没有接受过正式计算机培训的 16 或 17 岁孩子是如何获得访问电话公司计算机系统所需的复杂代码的。好吧，根据孩子们自己的说法，答案就在这里：电话公司大楼后面的垃圾箱。没错，就是垃圾箱。他们在这里找到了一些包含所需信息的过时手册。6

You might be asking yourself how a group of 16- or 17-year-old kids with no formal computer training got ahold of the sophisticated codes needed to give them access to the telephone company’s computer system. Well, according to the kids themselves, the answer comes from right here: the trash bins located behind the phone company building. That’s right, the trash bins. It was here that they found some out-of-date manuals that contained the information they needed.6

Rivera 的说法得到了 Headley 本人的支持，她在 1983 年向美国参议院作证时表示，她和她的同事会通过“各种研究方法”获取密码。垃圾学是它的一个委婉说法；翻查公司的垃圾，找到上面有密码的计算机打印件，找到人们记下的笔记。” 7

Rivera’s claims were supported by none other than Headley herself, who testified to the United States Senate in 1983 that she and her colleagues would get passwords through “various research methods. Garbology is a polite term for it; going through the garbage of a company and finding computer printouts that have passwords on them, finding notes that people have jotted down.”7

垃圾处理是黑客与私家侦探、狗仔队、拾荒者和城市自由主义者共有的一种做法，他们都将垃圾桶视为宝贵的材料来源，从轻度使用过的物品到食物、艺术品到信息。8至于保罗和黑客组织“欺骗大师”，他们能够利用垃圾中获得的知识进行一些人际社交活动工程师对电话接线员进行攻击。他们从那天晚上的破坏行动中收集到的信息包括一份“纽约电话公司内部号码的秘密清单”。有了这份清单，他们可以打电话给纽约电信公司的营业厅，假装自己是

Trashing is a practice that hackers share with private detectives, paparazzi, scavengers, and urban freegans, all of whom see garbage cans as a valuable source of materials ranging from gently used goods to food to art supplies to information.8 As for Paul and the hacker group Masters of Deception, they were able to use their trash-begotten knowledge to do some interpersonal social engineering on a telephone operator. The information they gleaned from that night’s trashing run included a “secret list of internal New York Telephone Company numbers.” With this, they could call up the New York telco business office and pretend to be

Lou 在 Provisioning 工作，[并且] 透露您对某个电话号码上的某台计算机了如指掌。您是伟大的贝尔家族的一员，当然，商务办公室会为您提供 [您要求的信息]。您听起来好像认识这个人：“Barry，你不记得我了吗？我们以前聊过，伙计。” 9

Lou in Provisioning [and] let it drop that you know all about a certain computer at a certain phone number. You’re a part of the great Bell family, and of course the business office is going to give you the information [you’re asking for]. You sound like you know the person: “Don’t you remember me, Barry? We’ve talked before, fella.”9

就像免费素食主义者在垃圾桶里找到可食用的食物、自行车或完好的鞋子一样，电话飞客或黑客能够将贬值的东西转换成非常有价值的东西：更深入地了解甚至不受限制地访问庞大的计算机和电话通信网络。

Like a freegan dumpster diver finding edible food, a bicycle, or perfectly good shoes, phone phreaks or hackers are able to convert something that was devalued into something very valuable: deeper insight into and even unfettered access to a vast communications network of computers and telephones.

我们从“垃圾”开始，因为将丢弃或忽略的信息转化为有价值的知识的过程是所有形式的社会工程学中的关键实践。为了完成他们的工作——操纵人们以实现社会控制——社会工程师需要有关他们所针对的人群、组织或人员的信息。当然，如今他们可以上网收集大数据。在大规模社会工程师时代，像伯内斯、李和弗莱施曼这样的“同意工程师”利用新社会科学的技术进行调查或家庭消费者观察。例如，正如 1942 年的一篇关于“广告工程”的文章所建议的那样，应该每周对家庭进行数年的研究，以获得足够的信息。10

We start with trashing because the process of converting discarded or overlooked information into valuable knowledge is a key practice in all forms of social engineering. In order to do their job—manipulate people for purposes of social control—social engineers need information on the crowds, organizations, or people they are targeting. These days, of course, they can go online and gather Big Data. In the days of the mass social engineers, the “engineers of consent” like Bernays, Lee, and Fleischman did surveys or in-home consumer observation, drawing on techniques of the new social sciences. For example, as a 1942 article on “advertising engineering” suggests, families should be studied on a weekly basis for years in order to gain enough information about them.10

但调查数据或大数据集与 20 世纪 70 年代至 90 年代电话窃贼和黑客的卑鄙破坏行为有许多联系。如果我们将垃圾而不是更枯燥的“数据”视为知识来源，那么将被忽视的信息转化为社会控制的认识论实践就会得到鲜明的体现。无论他们是想控制个人或大众，社会工程师必须翻看垃圾。在这里，我们探讨黑客社会工程垃圾处理，首先解释它是如何成为可能的，它与旧的大众社会工程有何关系，然后解释垃圾处理思维方式在大数据和开源情报 (OSINT) 时代是如何转变的。黑客和飞客向我们展示了调查、大数据、在线研究和垃圾都比表面上看起来更相似。

But data from surveys or big datasets shares many links with the down-and-dirty trashing practices of the phone phreaks and hackers of the 1970s through 1990s. The epistemological practice of turning overlooked information into social control is brought into sharp relief if we consider trash, rather than the more sterile “data,” as a source of knowledge. Whether they seek to control individuals or masses, social engineers have to go through the trash. Here, we explore hacker social engineering trashing, first explaining how it came to be possible, how it relates to the older mass social engineering, and then how the trashing way of thinking has been transformed in a time of Big Data and Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT). Hackers and phreaks show us that surveys, Big Data, online research, and garbage are all more alike than it seems.

什么使得社会工程学破坏成为可能？

What Makes Social Engineering Trashing Possible?

有许多指南可帮助您针对黑客的社会工程目的删除文件。有些是由电话飞客在 20 世纪 70 年代的杂志上发布的，有些是由计算机黑客在 20 世纪 80 年代的计算机公告板服务上发布的。还有一些则发布在在线论坛上（有些至今仍然存在）。如今，甚至还有专业的资料来源，整本书都专门讨论这个主题。所有这些资料来源都会告诉您，删除文件非常简单：您只需要跳进垃圾箱，开始寻找可能有用的文档即可。

There’s a host of guides to trashing for hacker social engineering purposes. Some were published by phone phreaks in 1970s zines, others by computer hackers in 1980s-era computer bulletin board services. Still others were in online forums (some still in existence to this day). These days, there are even professional sources, entire books dedicated to the topic. All of these sources will tell you that trashing is pretty straightforward: you jump into a dumpster and start looking for potentially useful documents.

但这并没有回答一个关键问题：我们是如何到达历史节点的，使得这种做法变得可行、可想象、可实践？

But this does not answer a key question: how did we arrive at a point in history when such a practice is even viable, thinkable, and practicable?

有两个关键答案。首先，工程师在美国开发了浪费的基础设施和社会习惯。基础设施是由进步时代的卫生工程师开发的。但仅凭这一点还不够。20 世纪早期至中期的大量社会工程师也帮助确立了浪费是美国新兴消费驱动型经济的必要组成部分。

There are two key answers. The first is that engineers developed both an infrastructure for and a social habit of wasting in the United States. The infrastructure was developed by Progressive Era sanitary engineers. But that alone is not enough. The mass social engineers of the early- to mid-twentieth century also helped established wasting as a necessary part of the emerging consumer-driven economy of America.

第二个答案更具哲学性：垃圾的产生在某种程度上是一种遗忘行为。我们总是在遗忘，扔掉不再需要的旧物品，不再去想它们。但这不仅与消费主义有关；这是一种根本的知识创造的一部分。我们努力思考，抛弃旧的想法，保留我们认为有用的知识。这种知识生产的残余物被扔掉并被遗忘——直到社会工程师把它挖出来并提醒我们。

The second answer is more philosophical: the production of trash is in part an act of forgetting. We forget all the time, throwing away old items we no longer want and not thinking about them again. But this is not only about consumerism; it is a fundamental part of knowledge creation. We work our way through ideas, discard old ones, and keep knowledge we find useful. The detritus of such knowledge production is thrown out and forgotten—until a social engineer digs it up and reminds us of it.

打造垃圾社会：卫生工程和大规模社会工程

Making a Trash Society: Sanitary Engineering and Mass Social Engineering

当代垃圾处理过程的基础是一种隐形基础设施，美国各地垃圾填埋场的发展就是最好的例证。这些系统是在 20 世纪初由一群新兴的专业工程师开发的，他们自称是“卫生工程师”。11他们的成功具有深刻的变革性：美国城市从 19 世纪末的“垃圾就像一个丑陋的溃疡，摆在每个人面前”，转变为垃圾填埋场中“几乎看不见的溃疡，很容易被遗忘，因为它在表面下膨胀”。12垃圾从城市街道转移到隐蔽的地方。

Underpinning contemporary wasting processes is an invisible infrastructure, best symbolized by the development of landfills across the United States. These systems were developed around the turn of the twentieth century by an emerging professionalized class of engineers who referred to themselves as “sanitary engineers.”11 Their success was deeply transformational: American cities moved from having “garbage [as] an ugly canker staring everyone in the face” in the late nineteenth century to garbage as a “nearly invisible canker, so easy to forget as it swelled beneath the surface” in landfills.12 Trash was moved from city streets to hidden sites.

卫生工程师在开发这些基础设施方面取得的成功，促使人们发表了一些关于工程改变社会力量的非常广泛的宣言。20 世纪早期的一些卫生工程师

The sanitary engineers’ success in developing these infrastructures led to some very sweeping proclamations about the power of engineering to change society. Some of the early twentieth-century sanitary engineers

卫生工程师意识到了更高的使命：卫生工程师必须超越他们的培训，寻求在慈善和政治方面发挥更大的社区领袖作用，尤其是作为公民委员会成员、市政行政人员，甚至公职人员。正如麻省理工学院卫生化学讲师、生态学领域的先驱和家庭经济运动的领导者艾伦·斯瓦洛·理查兹所说，“卫生工程师在未来几年的公民觉醒中肩负着三重责任。凭借知识，他必须成为开发国家和市政改善工程和工厂的‘领导者’，同时他也是这些工程和工厂的‘专家’。但他必须做得更多；作为一名卫生官员，他必须成为人民的‘老师’，向他们展示为什么会发生所有这些事情。” 13

perceived a higher calling: sanitary engineers had to transcend their training and seek larger roles as community leaders in philanthropic and political capacities, especially as members of civic commissions, as municipal administrators, and even as officeholders. As Ellen Swallow Richards, instructor in sanitary chemistry at MIT, a pioneer in the field of ecology, and a leader in the home-economics movement, stated, “The sanitary engineer has a treble duty for the next few years of civil awakening. Having the knowledge, he [sic] must be a ‘leader’ in developing works and plants for state and municipal improvement, at the same time he is an ‘expert’ in their employ. But he must be more; as a health officer he must be a ‘teacher’ of the people to show them why all these things are to be.”13

我们在这里看到了工程诱惑力的另一个例子：尽管工程师们声称自己在政治上保持中立，但他们却认为，通过修建下水道或垃圾填埋场来改变社会所取得的成功，是将工程思维拓展到政治管理等其他领域的依据。

Here we see another example of the seductive power of engineering: despite their claims to political neutrality, some engineers saw their successes in transforming society with sewers or landfills as a warrant for expanding the engineering mentality into other domains, including political administration.

当然，利用这些政治权力的动向并将其放大的工程师是进步时代出现的大众社会工程师。他们还在发展浪费型社会方面发挥了作用，尤其是从 20 世纪 20 年代到 50 年代。无形浪费基础设施的发展，以及福特主义制造工艺带来的生产力提高，促成了一种消费主义意识形态，在这种意识形态中，时尚、技术或奢华的“新”物品必须不断取代“旧”物品，而“旧”物品随后会被遗忘。大众社会工程师告诉我们，浪费对经济至关重要。

And of course, the engineers who took these stirrings of political power and ramped them up are the mass social engineers who emerged during the Progressive Era. They also played a role in developing a wasting society, especially from the 1920s through the 1950s. The development of invisible infrastructures of waste, along with increased productivity due to Fordist manufacturing processes, enabled a consumerist ideology in which fashionably, technologically, or luxuriously “new” objects must constantly replace the “old,” which are subsequently forgotten about. The mass social engineers taught us that wasting is essential to the economy.

正如记者兼社会评论家万斯·帕卡德 (Vance Packard) 于 1960 年在其著作《浪费制造者》中所说，让 20 世纪中叶的营销人员夜不能寐的是“他们正在努力销售的产品过剩的幽灵”。14 20世纪 50 年代尤其以“商品库存膨胀”为标志，这些商品必须出售。15为了卖出这些商品，必须说服美国人扔掉他们已经拥有的完好无损的物品。“不浪费是 20 世纪中叶营销人员的敌人” 。16

As the journalist and social critic Vance Packard argued in 1960 in his book The Waste Makers, what kept mid-century marketers up at night was the “the specter of glut for the products they are already endeavoring to sell.”14 The 1950s were especially marked by “bulging inventories of goods” that had to be sold.15 And to sell those goods, Americans had to be convinced to throw away the perfectly good items they already owned. “Failure to waste was the enemy” of the mid-century marketers.16

防止浪费的一个明显方法是对汽车和家电等高价商品进行计划报废。正如帕卡德所言，计划报废可以融入产品本身，在产品信用计划的最后一笔付款后，零件就会磨损。然而，更有效的是心理报废，即以这样一种方式设计产品，即“剥夺它的吸引力，尽管它仍然在尽职尽责地发挥作用”。17借用时尚界的说法，这种心理过时现象以车型年份、尾翼、不同颜色或格栅改造的形式应用于汽车。值得注意的是，帕卡德在 1957 年的另一本重要著作《隐藏的说服者》中对这种做法进行了诊断。帕卡德将心理过时现象的出现与“同意工程”联系起来，称爱德华·伯内斯等人是“不满的商人”，他们教导美国人抛弃旧事物，拥护新事物。18

An obvious way to prevent the failure to waste was planned obsolescence of big-ticket items, such as cars and appliances. As Packard argued, planned obsolescence could be engineered into the products themselves, with parts that wear out just after the last payment was made on the credit plan for the item. More effective, however, was psychological obsolescence, or designing a product in such a way as to “strip it of its desirability even though it continues to function dutifully.”17 Borrowed from the world of fashion, such psychological obsolescence was applied to automobiles in the form of model years, fins, different colors, or modifications to the grills. Notably, Packard had diagnosed this practice in 1957 in another major book of his, The Hidden Persuaders. Packard connected the advent of psychological obsolescence to “consent engineering,” calling figures such as Edward Bernays “merchants of discontent” who taught Americans to toss out the old in favor of the new.18

虽然心理或计划报废通常用于指汽车或洗衣机等大件物品，但我们这里感兴趣的是垃圾箱和它们所包含的更日常的垃圾。回到对卫生问题的担忧，我们可以重点介绍看似无害的一次性纸杯，例如 20 世纪初开发的 Dixie Cup。据报道，同意工程师 Bernays 和 Fleischman 帮助宣传 Dixie Cups 是可洗杯子的更卫生的替代品。他们的广告包括疾病和污秽的图像，以暗示一次性纸杯将使美国人免于生病。19 Bernays、Fleischman 和 Dixie Cups 告诉我们，与其重复使用玻璃杯，不如使用纸杯，扔掉它，然后忘掉它。20

While psychological or planned obsolescence is usually used in reference to big-ticket items like cars or washing machines, our interest here is in dumpsters and the more quotidian waste that they contain. Returning to concerns about sanitation, we could highlight the seemingly innocuous disposable paper cup, such as the Dixie Cup, developed in the early twentieth century. Reportedly, the consent engineers Bernays and Fleischman helped advertise Dixie Cups as a more sanitary replacement for washable cups. Their advertisements included images of disease and filth to suggest that the one-use paper cup would save Americans from illness.19 Rather than reuse a glass cup, Bernays, Fleischman, and Dixie Cups tell us, just use the paper one, throw it out, and forget it.20

但是，电话飞客和黑客破坏行为背后的一个重大变化是信用的出现。20 世纪中叶，美国信用的扩张意味着“近年来，掩埋在垃圾填埋场中的许多材料都是用信用卡购买的，这导致了典型的美国习惯，即在购买的物品变成垃圾后，还要继续付款，有时甚至要花好几年时间。” 21信用不仅会加速消费和浪费的循环，而且还会形成一种产生越来越多的纸质垃圾的系统。毕竟，为了在疯狂的购物中支付高价商品以保持领先于心理过时，美国人需要一个不断增长的信用官僚机构，包括文件、账单和报表。22这类文件包含大量信息——谁可以获得信贷、谁欠了什么以及哪些机构向他们提供信贷。23

But a major change that underpins what would become phone phreak and hacker trashing is the advent of credit. The expanse of credit in mid-twentieth-century America meant that “much of the material buried in landfills in recent years was bought with . . . credit cards, leading to the quintessentially American practice of continuing to pay, sometimes for years, for purchases after they become trash.”21 Credit would not only speed up circuits of consumption and wasting; it would also be a system to produce an expanding class of paper waste. After all, to pay for the big-ticket items in the mad dash to stay ahead of psychological obsolescence, Americans would need a growing credit bureaucracy, complete with paperwork, bills, and statements.22 Such documents contain a wealth of information—who has access to credit, who owes what, and which institutions are offering them credit.23

当然，这些信用文件是定期归档的。然而，浪费纸杯、汽车等一切东西的过时逻辑往往也适用于账单和信用报表：它们都可以扔进垃圾桶，被遗忘。公司员工可能会丢弃此类文件，消费者肯定会丢弃旧账单和报表。显示付款与二手商品之间关系的信用文件经常与用信用卡支付的废弃产品一起被埋没。当黑客和盗号者进行破坏时，这些信用文件是珍贵的发现。

Certainly, such credit documents are regularly filed. However, very often, the same out-with-the-old logic that underpinned wasting of everything from paper cups to automobiles applied to bills and credit statements: it could all go in the trash, out to the dump to be forgotten. Corporate employees might dump such paperwork, and certainly consumers dumped old bills and statements. Credit documents that show the relation between payment and used goods often get buried alongside the trashed products that were paid for with credit. Those credit documents were prized finds when hackers and phreaks went trashing.

总体结果就是美国社会发生了转变，公民变成了消费者，商品变成了垃圾，而信贷加速了这种流动。但除了美国政治经济全面转变为垃圾经济之外，黑客破坏行为的成因还有另一个答案。这是一个哲学答案，将传统垃圾与我们当代的数字媒介社会直接联系起来。

The overall result is a transformation of American society, where citizens become consumers, conduits for the flow of commodities to become waste, speeding up the flow with credit. But beyond this wholescale transformation of American political economy into a wasting economy, there is another answer to what makes hacker trashing possible. It’s a philosophical answer, one that ties traditional waste directly to our contemporary digitally mediated society.

垃圾哲学

A Philosophy of Garbage

垃圾不仅仅是消费主义的副产品，也是知识生产的结果。24在约翰·斯坎兰的垃圾文化史中，他借鉴了伊曼纽尔·康德的哲学，认为理性的阴暗面是由浪费组成的。对斯坎兰来说，康德的理性概念“完全建立在对怀疑、错误、无用等的处理上”。25因此，要产生知识，就必须解决“半成熟的想法、不可行的假设和智力努力的死胡同”。26我们可能认为知识生产是一个干净有序的过程，但当然，所有知识都以失败、失误、错误和事故为标志。垃圾是知识生产的副产品。虽然公认的知识受到重视，但被丢弃的想法却沦为符号混乱。正如斯坎兰所说，“所有试图呈现知识统一性或克服错误的尝试，都会导致垃圾的产生……因此，知识更普遍地通过清除多余的部分来为特定目的而组织起来。” 27

Garbage is not just the byproduct of consumerism. It’s also a result of knowledge production.24 In John Scanlan’s cultural history of garbage, he draws on the philosophy of Immanuel Kant to argue that reason’s dark side is comprised of waste. For Scanlan, Kant’s conception of reason “rests squarely on the disposal of doubt, error, uselessness, and so on.”25 Thus, to produce knowledge, one must work through the “half-formed ideas, unworkable hypotheses and dead ends of the intellectual endeavour.”26 We may think of knowledge production as a clean and orderly process, but of course all knowledge is marked by failure, missteps, mistakes, and accidents. Garbage is the byproduct of the production of knowledge. While accepted knowledge is valued, trashed ideas are reduced to a semiotic jumble. As Scanlan argues, “all attempts to present a unity of knowledge, or an overcoming of error, results in the creation of garbage . . . so it is that knowledge is more generally regimented for particular ends by the purging of the excess.”27

同样，环境学者 Myra Hird 从女权主义认识论的角度分析了垃圾，并认为垃圾是不确定的，每个垃圾填埋场都是“异质的、独特的混合物……与季节、天气、降水、太阳光线照射垃圾填埋场材料的不同角度等相互作用。” 28废物管理——将垃圾从一个地方运到另一个地方的庞大基础设施，通常是运到垃圾填埋场——是一种确定垃圾、使其可知、可控的尝试，但废物管理者总是无法确定垃圾。事实上，我们几乎没有关于废物流的信息，尤其是与我们在供应链上拥有的大量信息相比。29从本体论上讲，这就是废物之所以成为废物的原因，因此在废物中，我们看到我们的知识（有序、确定的理性）总是与未分化垃圾的不确定性纠缠在一起。30

Similarly, environmental scholar Myra Hird analyzes garbage from a feminist epistemological perspective and argues that garbage is indeterminate, with each landfill a “heterogeneous, unique mix . . . intra-acting with seasons, weather, precipitation, the varying angles of the sun’s rays bombarding landfill material and so on.”28 Waste management—the massive infrastructure of moving garbage from place to place, so often to the landfill—is an attempt to determine garbage, to make it knowable and hence controllable, but such determination always escapes waste managers. Indeed, we have almost no information about waste streams, especially when compared to the sheer glut of information we have on supply chains.29 This is, ontologically, what makes waste waste, and hence in waste we see how our knowledge (the orderly, determinate Reason) is always entangled with the indeterminacy of undifferentiated trash.30

此外，由于垃圾填埋场基础设施和追求最新的消费主义的双重创新，我们被要求彻底忘记垃圾。正如赫德所说，

Moreover, thanks to the dual innovations of landfill infrastructures and get-the-newest-version consumerism, we are invited to simply forget trash altogether. As Hird argues,

西方中产阶级勤勉地将垃圾放在人行道上，然后运往垃圾站、垃圾填埋场、焚烧炉等，这种做法使这种遗忘仪式化。立法决定、监管执行、风险模型、社区参与和工程实践使其成为可能。因此，垃圾填埋场作为遗忘的物质表现形式出现在景观中。31

Diligent middle-class western practices of placing garbage on sidewalks to be taken to dumping stations, landfills, incinerators and the like ritualises this forgetting. It is made possible by legislative decision, regulative enforcement, risk models, community accession and engineering practice. As such, landfills make their appearance on and in the landscape as a material enactment of forgetting.31

因此，我们的经济不仅依赖于拒绝承认垃圾，我们的认识论本身也忽视了垃圾，因为我们专注于公认的知识。

Thus, not only does our economy rely on the refusal to acknowledge refuse, our very epistemologies also overlook trash as we focus on accepted knowledge.

因此，垃圾成为我们所珍视的一切的阴暗面，包括知识。这种阴影出现在任何知识领域生产，从烹饪学校（想想垃圾桶里所有失败的蛋奶酥，更不用说用来做煎蛋卷的破鸡蛋了）到艺术学校（想想橡皮擦上的碎橡胶）到学院（想象一下被扔进垃圾桶的大量纸上想法）。这包括过时和陈旧的思想和理论。

Garbage thus becomes the dark side to all we value, including knowledge. This shadow appears in any locus of knowledge production, from cooking schools (consider all the failed souffles in the trash, not to mention the not-so-proverbial broken eggs used to make omelets) to art schools (think of the bits of rubber that fleck off an eraser) to the academy (imagine the multitude of paper ideas that have been thrown in the trash can). This includes outdated and old ideas and theories.

结合所有这些因素——垃圾基础设施、制造垃圾的政治经济，以及扔垃圾作为知识创造和遗忘的同步行为——我们就有了翻垃圾桶的条件。虽然我们可能认为丢弃的知识副产品没有价值，并允许它们返回不确定和混乱的世界，虽然我们可能会把它们扔到一边，从而忘记它们，但垃圾桶是可能的，因为大量被浪费的副产品可以重新组合成新的知识形式。这样的知识使新的、可操纵的交流实践成为可能。纸片、信用卡收据、电话公司手册、旧发票、群发电子邮件的打印件——任何数量的异质无差别垃圾碎片都可以用来深入了解个人或组织。32而且，正如我们将在下文中讨论的那样，这些逻辑延伸到了数字媒体的世界。

Combining all these factors—the infrastructure of refuse, the waste-making political economy, and throwing out the trash as a simultaneous act of knowledge-making and forgetting—and we have the conditions of possibility for dumpster diving. While we may believe that discarded knowledge byproducts have no value and allow them to return to the world of indeterminacy and chaos, while we may toss them aside and thus forget about them, trashing is possible because the glut of wasted byproducts can be reconstituted into new forms of knowledge. Such knowledge enables new, manipulative communicative practices. Scraps of paper, a credit receipt, a phone company manual, an old invoice, a printout of a mass email message—any number of heterogeneous bits and pieces of undifferentiated waste can be drawn upon to make deep insights into individuals or organizations.32 And, as we will argue below, these logics extend into the world of digital media.

废物系统作为知识生产副产品的终点，可以自由使用，从而形成稳定且易于定位的材料流。黑客或飞客所要做的就是在更大的垃圾网络中找到一个关键节点，以定位潜在信息。这个节点是消费者端废物和垃圾填埋场之间的中间点：垃圾箱。

The liberal use of the waste system as an endpoint for the byproducts of knowledge production creates a steady and easily located stream of such material. All the hacker or phreak has to do is find a key node in the larger garbage network to target for potential information. This node is the interim point between consumer-side wasting and the landfill: the dumpster.

在垃圾箱里

In the Dumpster

毕竟，垃圾在被收集运往垃圾填埋场之前必须先去某个地方：桌子旁边的垃圾桶、水槽下的垃圾箱，路边的“herbie-curbies”或办公室后面的垃圾箱。垃圾箱是一个存放垃圾的场所，垃圾在这里等待被分拣、回收或最有可能被送往垃圾填埋场。它是消费短循环和填埋长循环之间的过渡场所。

After all, the garbage has to go somewhere before it’s picked up for transportation to the landfill: cans by desks, bins under sinks, “herbie-curbies” by the road, or dumpsters behind the office. The dumpster in particular is a holding cell, a place for trash to sit and wait for its fate in the sorting facility, recycling center, or, most likely, the landfill. It is an interim place between short circuits of consumption and the long circuit of landfilling.

这也是一个目标。

It is also a target.

黑客杂志、公告板和在线论坛上随处可见的垃圾分类指南（也称翻找垃圾）都提到了这一目标。在1984 年2600 年出版的一本长篇指南中，两个电话飞客指导想要翻找垃圾的人把注意力集中在电话公司的垃圾箱上。他们建议，第一步是侦察：垃圾什么时候收？谁在停车场巡逻？到了检查垃圾箱的时候，作者们说得很清楚：准备好跳进去。不要在垃圾箱里分类；只要抓起任何看起来有希望的东西就行。用汽车往返垃圾箱。永远不要在现场分类。在另一个地方分类。最重要的是，避免使用自助餐厅的垃圾箱。33

The hacker guides to trashing—also called dumpster diving—found across hacker zines, bulletin boards, and online forums recognize this target. In a lengthy guide in 2600 in 1984, two phone phreaks instruct the would-be trasher to focus on phone company dumpsters. The first step, they suggest, is reconnaissance: When does the trash get picked up? Who is patrolling the parking lot? When it comes time to examine the dumpster itself, the authors are clear: be prepared to jump in. Do not sort in the dumpster; just grab anything that looks promising. Use a car to get to and from the dumpster. Never sort on site. Sort at another location. And above all, avoid cafeteria dumpsters.33

本指南是众多指南中的代表，它概括了垃圾处理的价值转化方法。侦察阶段要求垃圾处理者找到可能被丢弃的知识所在的垃圾箱。跳进去抓取是一种体力劳动。用汽车运输，将垃圾从垃圾箱中拖走，从而远离垃圾填埋场，逆转了办公室工作人员认为他们正在摆脱无用知识的浪费过程。分类是关键：用 Hird 的话来说，就是确定不确定的东西，记住被遗忘的东西，同样是通过劳动（分类、归类、思考）。哪些信息可能对社会工程有用？什么材料最好扔回去？

This guide—representative of many—encapsulates the value transformation methods of trashing. The reconnaissance stage requires the trashers to locate the precise dumpster in which discarded knowledge may be waiting. Jumping in and grabbing is a physical act of labor. Transportation in a car, where the garbage is hauled away from the dumpster and hence away from the landfill, reverses the wasting process by which the office workers believed they were ridding themselves of useless knowledge. And sorting is key: to use Hird’s language, it is determining the indeterminate, remembering what was forgotten, again through labor (sorting, categorizing, thinking). What information is potentially useful for social engineering? What material is best thrown back?

至于哪些材料可能被认定为有价值，正如 1982 年一位计算机黑客在TAP上所写，

As for what materials may be determined to be of value, as a computer hacker writes in TAP in 1982,

垃圾可以提供极好的信息来源……拨号、密码、计算机登录等。尝试通过本地深夜去 ESS 垃圾箱看看那里有什么。或者也许是股票市场。或者银行（不过要小心）。我想你会对所得到的东西感到惊讶（除了跳蚤和瘟疫）！34

Garbage can provide an excellent source of information . . . dialups, passwords, computer logins, etc. Try going through your local ESS dumpster late at night and see what’s there. Or perhaps a stock market place. Or bank (be careful, though). I think you’ll be surprised at what you’ll get (besides fleas and the plague)!34

此外，在TAP中，一位信用卡诈骗专家建议查找复写本：

Also in TAP, an expert credit card fraudster recommends finding carbon copies:

对于信用卡商品……你可以搜索任何接受信用卡的商店外面的垃圾箱，寻找他们在进行信用卡销售时使用的复写纸。这被称为“丢弃” 。35

To credit card things . . . you search the dumpsters outside of any store that takes credit cards, look for the pieces of carbon paper that they use when running off a credit card sale. This is called “trashing.”35

在接受电话飞客、黑客和社会工程师杰拉尔多·里维拉 (Geraldo Rivera) 的采访时，苏珊·海德利 (Susan Headley) 提请人们注意被丢弃的电话公司手册：

In her interview with Geraldo Rivera, the phone phreak, hacker, and social engineer Susan Headley drew attention to discarded phone company manuals:

[电话公司员工] 收到更新后，他们会扔掉旧的 [手册]，直接扔进垃圾箱。因此，电话窃贼会翻遍垃圾箱，把垃圾箱都清空。这样可以获取大量知识。36

[Phone company employees] get an update, they throw away the old [manual], just toss it in the bin. So the phone phreaks would go through and clean out the bins. There was a lot of knowledge retrieved that way.36

此外，尽管约翰·霍夫曼 (John Hoffman) 的著作《翻垃圾桶的艺术与科学》并非专门针对社会工程师，但BBS 帖子中引用该书作为该实践的极佳指南，尤其是其中的“信息翻找”一章。在该章中，他认为

Further, although not specifically aimed at social engineers, John Hoffman’s book The Art & Science of Dumpster Diving is cited in BBS posts as an excellent guide to the practice, particularly his chapter “Information Diving.” In that chapter, he argues that

垃圾桶会告诉你一个人的一切：他吃什么。他在哪里购物。他的收入。他的爱好。他的医生和药物。他在哪里工作、玩耍和过夜。当然，你可能会幸运地发现一些非常好的东西：他越狱的重罪犯兄弟的来信。情妇的便条。暗示一些长期埋藏的丑闻的旧文件。37

Trash can tell you EVERYTHING about a person: what he eats. Where he shops. His income. His hobbies. His doctor and medications. Where he works, plays and stays overnight. And, of course, you might get lucky and find something really good: A letter from his escaped felon brother. A note from a mistress. Old documents alluding to some long-buried scandal.37

虽然这些指南可以追溯到 20 世纪 80 年代初到 90 年代，但将垃圾扔进垃圾箱的做法如今仍然很盛行。现在有来自专业社会工程师的关于这一主题的指南。社会工程学专家 Chris Hadnagy 于 2010 年出版的《社会工程学：人类黑客的艺术》一书中，有一节关于翻找垃圾箱的内容，包括基本的法律和健康建议，作为渗透的一部分测试专业社会工程师。Sharon Conheady 2014 年出版的《IT 安全中的社会工程学》一书也提到了这一点。38 YouTube上有很多关于这种做法的视频指南。对于黑客社会工程师来说，最详尽的翻找垃圾的指南可能是 Johnny Long 2008 年出版的《No Tech Hacking》一书，该书的第一章专门介绍了这种做法。因此，尽管多年来信息安全专家一直向企业推荐碎纸机，但对于社会工程学的初始研究阶段来说，扔掉垃圾仍然是一个有吸引力的选择。

While these guides date back to the early 1980s through the 1990s, trashing in dumpsters is still going strong today. There are now guides from professional social engineers on the topic. Social engineering specialist Chris Hadnagy’s 2010 book Social Engineering: The Art of Human Hacking, includes a section on dumpster diving, including basic legal and health advice, as part of penetration testing for professionalized social engineers. Sharon Conheady’s 2014 book Social Engineering in IT Security does, as well.38 Video guides to the practice abound on YouTube. Perhaps the most elaborate guide to dumpster diving for hacker social engineers is Johnny Long’s 2008 book No Tech Hacking, which dedicates its entire first chapter to the practice. Thus, despite years of the information security professionals recommending paper shredders to corporations, trashing remains an attractive option for the initial research phase of social engineering.

数字垃圾箱

The Digital Dumpster

当然，有些人可能会说我们不再使用纸张，我们的信息已被数字化，这肯定不会像物理垃圾那样产生相同的物质足迹。我们甚至看到数字媒体与“环保”的联系：“避免收到纸质邮件”，我们的银行和信用卡公司敦促我们，“改用电子账单！”这些论点是错误的，原因有很多：我们不仅仍然使用大量纸张，而且数字媒体在生态上也很难免责，因为它依赖于庞大的资源密集型物质基础设施来运作。39许多学者，尤其是媒体研究和法律研究领域的学者，已经开始将庞大的数据网络视为一种数字垃圾场，而不是一个干净、卫生的空间。40 这种遍布全球的数字数据基础设施——包括废弃的、表面上被删除的和“过时的”数据，可以说是一种数据垃圾——并没有被社会工程师忽视，他们相应地更新了他们的技术。

Of course, some may argue we don’t use paper anymore, that our information has been digitized, which surely does not have the same material footprint as physical trash. We even see articulations of digital media with “going green”: “Avoid getting paper mail,” our banks and credit card companies urge us, “and switch to eBilling!” These arguments are false for many reasons: not only do we still use a lot of paper, digital media is hardly ecologically guilt-free, relying as it does on a vast, resource-intensive material infrastructure to function.39 A number of scholars, notably in media studies and legal studies, have begun to consider the vast networks of data not as a clean, hygienic space, but instead as a sort of digital dumping ground.40 And this globe-spanning digital infrastructure of data—including abandoned, ostensibly deleted, and “outdated” data, arguably a form of data trash—has not gone unnoticed by social engineers, who have updated their techniques accordingly.

数字垃圾搜寻的可能性条件与传统垃圾搜寻非常相似。同样的混乱产生了大量的垃圾，这些垃圾被送往垃圾填埋场——为了忘记而丢弃，为了消费而丢弃——推动了当代数字媒体实践。媒体研究学者梅尔·霍根 (Mél Hogan) 称这就是“数字垃圾箱”。对于 Hogan 来说，数字垃圾箱源自一种数字囤积形式，这种形式是通过增加存储容量实现的：

Digital dumpster diving’s conditions of possibility are quite similar to its traditional counterpart. The same churn that produces the vast amount of waste that goes to landfills—dispose in order to forget, throw away in order to consume—drives contemporary digital media practices. Media studies scholar Mél Hogan calls this the “digital dumpster.” For Hogan, the digital dumpster arises from a form of digital hoarding made possible by increased storage capacities:

我们鼓励毫无良知、毫无后果、毫无情感洞察力地囤积数据，无论是我们在做什么，还是谁会受到影响。旧电子邮件、社交媒体流、文本，以及越来越多的物联网，继续存在于为我们囤积数据的服务器上，这通常是一种“免费”服务的商业模式。41

We encourage hoarding without conscience, without consequence, without affective insights into what we are doing or who might be affected. Old emails, social media streams, texts, and increasingly, the Internet of things, continue to exist on servers that hoard our data for us, often as a business model for “free” services.41

这种数字囤积是“自我策划”这一更大举措的副产品，即用数字媒体的零碎信息构建自我。当今的当代数字媒体公司是 20 世纪中叶营销者的直系后代，记者兼文化评论家万斯·帕卡德称之为“废物制造者”。42企业社交媒体强调新鲜事物和潮流。再拍一张头像。更新您的状态。告诉我们您在想什么。这些是您的热门话题。加入这项新服务。下载这款最新应用。所有这些行为都被宣传为数字时代自我表达和真实性的一种方式。在这种不断的变化中，随着新更新的出现，较旧的数字文物被推到了时间线的后面，似乎已经从平台上消失了。或者，我们离开过时的平台，转而使用热门的新平台，也就抛弃了数据。

This digital hoarding is a byproduct of the larger move to “self-curate,” to construct the self out of bits and pieces of digital media. Today’s contemporary digital media companies are direct descendants of the mid-twentieth-century marketers that journalist and cultural critic Vance Packard called “the waste makers.”42 Corporate social media emphasize the new and the trending. Take another profile picture. Update your status. Tell us what’s on your mind. These are your trending topics. Join this new service. Download this latest app. All of these actions are marketed as a means of self-expression and authenticity in the digital age. In this constant churn, as new updates appear, older digital artifacts get pushed down the timeline, seemingly off the platform. Or, we leave data behind as we leave an out-of-date platform for the hot new one.

这一过程是数字媒体中自我生产过程的迭代，Hird 在其垃圾研究工作中指出了这一过程。“垃圾填埋场堆满了我们曾经想要但现在不想要的东西，曾经珍视但现在不再珍视的东西，”Hird 认为。“我们丢弃这些东西后剩下的就是我们（想要）认为的真正的自我。” 43同样，自我策划实践：当我们丢弃 Instagram 上构图不佳的自拍照、删除 Twitter 上的推文或取消 Facebook 上的“赞”后还剩下什么？当我们从手机或电脑上删除图片、文字或视频后还剩下什么？我们依靠这种数字丢弃来创造真正的自我。

This process is a digital media iteration of the same processes of self-production qua wasting that Hird identifies in her work on garbage. “Landfills swell with things we once wanted and now do not want, once valued and no longer value,” Hird argues. “What remains after our disgorgement is what we (want to) consider our real self.”43 Likewise, self-curation practices: what is left over after we discard poorly framed selfies from Instagram, delete a tweet from Twitter, or revoke a “like” on Facebook? What remains after we delete images, text, or videos off our phones or computers? We rely on such digital disgorgement to produce our real selves.

这样做，我们在巨大的数字垃圾箱里留下了数字垃圾的影子。大数据的论述完全基于致力于“回收”我们这个时代的副产品，一种被委婉地称为“数字痕迹”的废弃物。44这些副产品是“网络搜索、信用卡支付和手机向最近的电话信号塔发出信号的数字废气”。45当然，我们知道数字媒体公司存储了我们上传并想要分享的材料。但很少被谈论的是，它们还包括我们丢弃的数据。例如，Facebook 会记录最终用户最终未发布的状态更新和文本输入。46 Twitter会保留已删除的直接消息。47 Google Docs 会保留文档的每个版本，包括每次删除、每个错误和每次修订。48企业社交媒体收集“已删除”数据的努力应该提醒我们数字垃圾的价值。与任何知识生产过程一样，自我管理必然会产生浪费：没有对焦的自拍照、已删除的状态更新、撤销的好友请求、丢弃的电子邮件草稿、从硬盘中删除的文件。虽然我们可能会忽略这些媒体错误，认为它们不是我们自我管理实践的一部分，就像普通垃圾一样，但它们却是我们身份的有力见证。49此外，数字数据通常存储在数字版本的垃圾箱中：硬盘或搜索引擎缓存中的“垃圾”或“回收”文件夹。这些数据是从事数字垃圾箱搜索的当代社会工程师的诱人目标。

And in doing so, we leave a shadow of digital waste in the vast digital dumpster. The discourse of Big Data is entirely predicated on “recycling” the byproducts of our age, a waste product euphemistically referred to as “digital traces.”44 These byproducts are “the digital exhaust of web searches, credit card payments, and mobiles pinging the nearest phone mast.”45 Of course, we know that the digital media corporations store the material we upload and want to share. What is less talked about is the fact that they also include data we discard. For example, Facebook records status updates and text entry that the end user ultimately does not post.46 Twitter maintains deleted direct messages.47 Google Docs keeps every version of a document—including every deletion, every mistake, every revision.48 Corporate social media’s efforts to collect “deleted” data should alert us to the value of digital trash. Like any knowledge production process, self-curation necessarily produces waste: the selfie that wasn’t in focus, the deleted status update, the revoked friend request, the email draft abandoned, the files removed from the hard drive. While we may ignore these media mistakes and discount them as not part of our self-curation practices, like regular trash, they are eloquent witnesses about who we are.49 Moreover, often digital data are in fact stored in digital versions of dumpsters: “trash” or “recycling” folders on hard drives or search engine caches. These data are an attractive target for contemporary social engineers who engage in digital dumpster diving.

扔进数字垃圾箱

Trashing in the Digital Dumpster

电话飞客和黑客社会工程师很久以前就认识到了数字垃圾搜索的可能性。事实上，在 1983 年向美国参议院作证时，苏珊“雷霆”海德利明确将传统垃圾与基于计算机的数字垃圾联系起来。她在作证时说，黑客会查看常规垃圾，但也会查看“[计算机上的]可用磁盘空间，因为当删除某些东西时，它通常不会被归零（即完全删除]。” 50同样，在1982 年2600 号的一篇匿名文章中，一位作者指出，

Phone phreak and hacker social engineers recognized digital dumpster diving possibilities quite a long time ago. In fact, in her testimony to the United States Senate in 1983, Susan “Thunder” Headley explicitly linked traditional trashing with computer-based, digital trashing. She testified that hackers would look through regular garbage but also “free disk space [on computers] because when something is deleted it usually isn’t zeroed [that is, completely deleted].”50 Likewise, in an anonymous article in 2600 in 1982, an author noted,

垃圾拾取是一门寻找别人丢弃的东西的艺术。分时系统的黑客早已熟悉这种技术，即向操作系统请求一些尚未清零的内存或大容量存储空间，然后将其中的内容转储到屏幕或打印机上。密码文件和系统程序等内容总是会不时更新或备份，这时就会创建“垃圾副本” 。51

Garbage picking is the art of finding things that someone else has thrown away. Hackers on time-sharing systems are long familiar with the technique of asking the operating system for some memory or mass storage space that has not yet been zeroed out, and then dumping out whatever was in there to the screen or printer. Things like password files and system programs are always updated or backed up from time to time, and that’s when a “garbage copy” will be created.51

这种技术被称为“核心转储”。就像普通的垃圾一样，当我们从电脑中删除文件时，我们可能会认为数据已经真正被破坏了，但通常数据是可以恢复的。52因此，被删除的数据就成了那些试图建立个人资料、绘制组织结构、收集密码或寻找软件漏洞的人的目标。

This technique is called making a “core dump.” Much like regular trash, when we delete files off computers, we may be encouraged to think of the data as truly destroyed, but often it can be recovered.52 Deleted data thus becomes a ripe target for those seeking to build profiles, map organizations, gather passwords, or find software vulnerabilities to exploit.

最近，数字垃圾处理已高度网络化。随着互联网越来越流行，黑客“仅凭搜索引擎和一点聪明才智”就创建了“Google hack”或“Google dorks”，这是一种高度针对性的搜索，旨在查找可公开访问的数据。53这些数据包括临时缓存，例如 Web 服务器操作系统上的 .trash、recycler 或 $Recycle.bin 文件夹。54这些数字垃圾搜索可以限制在目标 URL 上。例如，如果有人在寻找犹他大学网站上托管的临时文件，他们会将搜索范围限制在该机构的域名 ( www.utah.edu ) 上，并添加 Google Dork 来查找临时文件。

More recently, digital trashing has become highly networked. As the internet became more and more popular, hackers “armed only with a search engine and a bit of ingenuity” created “Google hacks” or “Google dorks,” which are highly targeted searches designed to find publicly accessible data.53 These data include temporary caches, such as .trash, recycler, or $Recycle.bin folders on web server operating systems.54 These searches for digital trash can be limited to targeted URLs. For example, if someone were looking for temporary files hosted on the University of Utah’s website, they would limit the search to the institution’s domain (www.utah.edu) and add in the Google Dork to find temporary files.

我们也不能忽视“数据转储”，即在企业或政府数据库被入侵后发布的之前被限制的信息（我们应该注意到，这些入侵通常使用黑客的社会工程技术）。无论是黑客活动分子获取的，还是为举报人准备的泄密网站，或者仅仅是为了炫耀，大量以前被禁止的信息被“泄露”到互联网上。安全顾问迈克尔·巴泽尔（Michael Bazzell）在他的播客中建议听众：“如果你没有将泄露的数据用作在线调查的一部分，我相信你真的错过了什么。” 55一个臭名昭著的例子是 Ashley Madison 的数百万个电子邮件地址被曝光，该网站专门面向寻求婚外情的已婚人士。《连线》杂志报道称，除了电子邮件地址之外，这份 10GB 的数据泄露“还包含 Ashley Madison 的内部文件，包括员工凭证、图表、合同和销售文件。” 56正如Social-Engineer.org 播客的长期参与者和 Social-Engineer Toolkit 软件套件的作者戴夫·肯尼迪（Dave Kennedy）与同事所写的那样，“这份泄露看起来是合法的。非常非常合法。” 57在这里，他不仅在验证泄露中包含的数据是真实的；他还在验证任何人都可以进入泄露并收集有关潜在目标的大量个人和公司信息。

We also cannot overlook “data dumps,” the posting of previously restricted information gleaned after corporate or government databases are breached (often, we should note, using hacker social engineering techniques). Whether obtained by hacktivists, leak sites meant for whistleblowers, or simply for bragging rights, massive amounts of previously restricted information have been “dumped” on the internet. As security consultant Michael Bazzell advises listeners on his podcast, “If you are not using breach data as part of your online investigations, I believe you are really missing out.”55 A notorious example was the exposure of millions of email addresses from Ashley Madison, a website marketed to married people seeking affairs. Wired magazine reported that, in addition to email addresses, the 10-gigabyte data dump “also contains internal documents from Ashley Madison including employee credentials, charts, contracts, and sales documents.”56 As Dave Kennedy, a longtime participant in the Social-Engineer.org Podcast and author of the Social-Engineer Toolkit software suite, writes with his colleagues, “This dump appears to be legit. Very, very legit.”57 Here, he’s not only verifying that the data included in the dump are real; he’s verifying that anyone can dive into the dump and gather an incredible amount of personal and corporate information on potential targets.

最后，我们不应该忘记那些我们称之为老式的物理垃圾箱的数字垃圾。考虑到我们当代版本的计划报废——即数字设备在大约 18 个月后就会过时——世界各地的垃圾箱里都堆满了废弃的手机、平板电脑、硬盘和 USB 驱动器。一位安全研究人员检查了他从回收商和经销商那里获得的一些旧数字设备，发现

Finally, we should not forget digital waste in what we might call the old-school, physical dumpster. Given our contemporary version of planned obsolescence—that is, the idea that a digital device is obsolete after about 18 months—dumpsters all over the world are brimming with discarded phones, tablets, hard drives, and USB drives. One security researcher went through some old digital devices he acquired from recyclers and resellers and found that

事实证明，这堆垃圾包含 41 个社会安全号码、50 个出生日期、611 个电子邮件帐户、19 个信用卡号、两个护照号和六个驾驶执照号。此外，设备中还包含超过 200,000 张图片和超过 3,400 份文件。他还提取了近 150,000 封电子邮件。58

The pile of junk turned out to contain 41 Social Security numbers, 50 dates of birth, 611 email accounts, 19 credit card numbers, two passport numbers, and six driver’s license numbers. Additionally, more than 200,000 images were contained on the devices and over 3,400 documents. He also extracted nearly 150,000 emails.58

所有这些数据都仅从 85 台设备中收集而来。59我们无法准确估计全世界有多少台设备被丢弃在垃圾场，但可以猜测这个数字肯定达数百万。

All these data were culled from only eighty-five devices.59 We have no reliable estimates of how many devices are in dumps around the world, but it’s fair to guess the number is easily in the millions.

结论：调查、翻找垃圾和 OSINT

Conclusion: Surveys, Dumpster Diving, and OSINT

鉴于网上有大量信息，当代社会工程师似乎不太可能需要把自己扔进垃圾桶。正如专业社会工程师 Sharon Conheady 在一次安全会议演讲中高兴地指出的那样，

Given the vast amount of information available online, it seems far less likely that a contemporary social engineer would need to sully themselves in a physical dumpster. As professional social engineer Sharon Conheady noted with glee during a security conference presentation,

人们在社交媒体上发布了太多信息，以至于他们没有意识到这些信息可能会被用于社会工程攻击。我喜欢它的原因是：我不再需要翻垃圾桶了，因为信息可以在网上找到！我讨厌翻垃圾桶——这太肮脏了！60

People publish so much information [in social media] that they don’t realize could be used in a social engineering attack. And what I like about it is: I don’t have to do so much dumpster diving anymore ‘cause the information is available online! And I hate dumpster diving—it’s so dirty!60

此外，即使是仔细研究数字数据转储也不常被称为“数字垃圾翻找”。当代的黑客社会工程师——尤其是像康黑迪这样的专业安全顾问，他们利用社会工程学来测试组织安全性并获得报酬——使用一个更干净的术语：OSINT。OSINT 源自军方，是指“开源情报”收集；即“将公共记录重新用于情报和调查，包括不受隐私设置保护的社交媒体内容。” 61该行业的工具包括 Google Dorks、专业搜索引擎、社交媒体 API 和消费者数据库。62 OSINT 不仅仅是黑客社会工程的领域。它已经成为数字时代的一个无处不在的术语。例如，记者开始使用这个术语来描述通过“卫星图像、社交媒体、风、天气和船只运动数据库”来讲述故事的工作。63 OSINT 不仅指一种与旧的翻垃圾箱方法看似不同的数据收集方法，其军事化缩写词还使其在安全意识强的人中享有一种受人尊敬的气氛——肯定比“捣乱”或“翻垃圾箱”更受尊敬。

Moreover, even poring through digital data dumps is not often called “digital dumpster diving.” Contemporary hacker social engineers—especially professionalized security consultants like Conheady, who gets paid to use social engineering to test organizational security—use a cleaner term: OSINT. Appropriated from the military, OSINT refers to “open-source intelligence” gathering; that is, “the repurposing of public records for intelligence and investigations, including social media content not protected by privacy settings.”61 Tools of the trade include Google Dorks, specialized search engines, social media APIs, and consumer databases.62 OSINT is not just the domain of hacker social engineering. It has become a ubiquitous term in the digital age. Journalists, for example, are starting to use the term to characterize the work of rooting through “satellite imagery, social media, databases of wind, weather, and vessel movement” to tell stories.63 OSINT not only refers to a seemingly different approach to gathering data than the older dumpster diving method, its militaristic acronym gives it an air of respectability among the security-minded—certainly more so than “trashing” or “dumpster diving.”

然而，尽管开源情报工作看似光鲜，软件驱动，但它却是旧政治经济的血统后裔，垃圾和浪费的认识论。OSINT“能够将原本转瞬即逝的社交互动重塑为原始数据……以供分析。” 64就像扔进垃圾桶的纸张一样，一方遗忘或视为短暂的东西对另一方来说却变成了有价值的数据。一年前深夜发布的图片、五年前顺便发表然后删除的社交媒体评论，甚至十年前与可疑网站的联系，似乎都丢失在数字垃圾箱中，但 OSINT 研究的数字垃圾箱潜水员可能会恢复它们。我们在当代 OSINT 工具名称中看到了旧式飞客破坏实践的痕迹，尤其是 dnsdumpster.com，这是一个返回网络服务器上域名系统信息的网站。20 世纪早期卫生工程师在福特主义生产过剩之后不得不处理的浪费与媒体研究学者马克·安德烈耶维奇所说的数字时代的“信息过剩”有着直接联系。65为了开展工作，社会工程师必须仔细研究过剩的信息。

However, for all its slick, software-driven aspects, OSINT is a genealogical descendant of the older political economy and epistemology of garbage and wasting. OSINT “enables the recasting of otherwise ephemeral social interactions into raw data . . . to be analysed.”64 Like the paper tossed in a trash can, what was forgotten or seen as transitory by one party becomes valuable data to another. The picture posted late one night a year ago, the social media comment made in passing and then deleted five years prior, or even a connection made to a questionable website a decade ago may seem lost in the digital dumpster, but the digital dumpster divers of OSINT research may recover them. We see vestiges of the older phreak trashing practices in contemporary OSINT tool names, especially dnsdumpster.com, a site that returns domain name system information on web servers. There is a direct line from the waste that the early twentieth-century sanitary engineers had to deal with in the wake of the glut of Fordist production to what media studies scholar Mark Andrejevic calls the “infoglut” of the digital age.65 In order to do their work, social engineers must pore through glut.

此外，垃圾的认识论维度，包括恢复被遗忘的知识，有助于我们重新考虑大规模社会工程的研究实践。1942 年的一篇关于“广告工程”的文章认为，有效的大规模社会工程需要深入研究人们家中的消费习惯。这篇文章明确呼吁检查垃圾。这是因为垃圾说的是真话，而人们却忘记了：“家庭主妇的记忆里什么也没有留下。她把空包裹保存起来。” 66换句话说，他们要求目标家庭保存垃圾，以免他们忘记自己消费了什么。

Moreover, the epistemological dimensions of trashing, including the recovery of forgotten knowledge, helps us reconsider the research practices of mass social engineering. A 1942 article on “advertising engineering” argues that efficient mass social engineering requires intense study of consumption practices in peoples’ homes. The article explicitly calls for examination of trash. This is because trash tells the truth while people forget: “Nothing is left to the housewife’s memory. She saves her empty packages.”66 In other words, they ask their target families to save their garbage, lest they forget what they consumed.

垃圾处理的社会工程实践既暴露了知识生产是一个干净的过程，没有副产品的自负，也暴露了故意忽视垃圾填埋场基础设施所暗示的虚假反物质主义。我们可能会忘记那里有什么——网上或垃圾箱里的垃圾。但当文档被恢复，信息被提取，组织、人口统计或个人通过垃圾被分析时，社会工程师暴露了我们对垃圾信息潜力的集体无知。正如黑客社会工程师约翰尼·朗尖刻地说的那样，“继续认为你的个人或公司机密没有暴露在某个垃圾箱里，等待着一个不懂技术的黑客来抢走它们。” 67

The social engineering practice of trashing betrays both the conceit that knowledge production is a clean process with no byproducts, as well as the false anti-materialism implied by the willful ignorance of the infrastructure of the landfill. We might forget what’s out there—the waste online or in the dumpster. But when the document is recovered, the information extracted, and the organization, demographic, or person profiled through the trash, the social engineer exposes our collective ignorance about the informational potentials of our waste. As hacker social engineer Johnny Long caustically puts it, “Go on thinking your personal or corporate secrets aren’t sitting exposed in a dumpster somewhere, waiting for a no-tech hacker to snatch them up.”67

掌握了关于我们的垃圾知识后，社会工程师可以进入下一个阶段，构建一个虚假但合理且可识别的身份或角色：借口。

Armed with garbage-begotten knowledge about us, the social engineer can move to the next phase, constructing a false, yet plausible and recognizable, identity or role to play: the pretext.

4

4

借口：认识米特尼克神话

Pretexting: Recognizing the Mitnick Mythology

社会工程学的目标是让你不假思索地做出决定。。。我需要指出一个非常重要的观点：社会工程学并不符合政治正确。。。[社会工程学]利用了性别偏见、种族偏见、年龄偏见和地位偏见（以及这些偏见的组合）存在的事实。

The goal of the social engineer is to get you to make a decision without thinking. . . . I need to state one very important point: social engineering is not politically correct. . . . [social engineering] takes advantage of the fact that gender bias, racial bias, age bias, and status bias (as well as combinations of those biases) exist.

—Chris Hadnagy 1

—Chris Hadnagy1

我们都有刻板印象，它不仅削弱了我们的思维习惯，也削弱了我们的日常生活。

We all have stereotypes which minimize not only our thinking habits but also the ordinary routine of life.

—爱德华·伯内斯2

—Edward Bernays2

多年来，黑客社会工程学领域的旗舰播客Social-Engineer.org Podcast一直以一首名为“相信我”的歌曲作为主题曲。这首歌由书呆子嘻哈二人组 Dual Core 创作，其中吹嘘社会工程师能够承担任何角色：

For several years, the Social-Engineer.org Podcast, a flagship podcast in the field of hacker social engineering, used a song called “Trust Me” as its theme song. Written by the nerdcore hip-hop duo Dual Core, “Trust Me” includes a boast about the social engineer’s ability to take on any role:

我可以成为任何人，去任何我想去的地方

I can be anyone, anywhere I aim

我需要的只是心态、故事和名字。3

I just need the mindset, a story, and a name.3

Dual Core 的歌词让人想起间谍电影中的老套情节，间谍迅速乔装打扮，进入最安全的区域。这首歌的后续歌词延续了这一主题，说唱歌手 Int80 探索了他可以扮演的一系列角色：拿着剪贴板的领班、客服人员、公司高管、技术支持。

Dual Core’s lyrics bring to mind the clichés of spy movies, where spies quickly don disguises that get them into the most secure areas. The song’s subsequent lyrics continue this theme, with rapper Int80 exploring a host of roles he could play: clipboard-carrying foreman, customer service worker, corporate executive, tech support.

黑客社会工程师对此有一个词：借口。简而言之，借口是黑客社会工程师在与目标接触时所扮演的角色。显然，黑客不能打电话给某个组织说：“你好！我是一名黑客。请问您能给我一个您的网络密码吗？”相反，黑客社会工程师通过扮演一个看似合法需要敏感信息的角色来实施欺骗。从逻辑上讲，借口与破坏行为非常吻合：破坏行为提供了大量信息，可以告知社会工程师可以扮演的角色。

Hacker social engineers have a word for this: pretexting. Put simply, a pretext is the role a hacker social engineer will play when they are engaging with the target. Obviously, a hacker can’t call up an organization and say, “Hello! I am a hacker. May I please have a password to your network?” Instead, the hacker social engineer practices deception by playing a role with a seemingly legitimate need for sensitive information. Logically, pretexting follows trashing quite nicely: trashing provides a wealth of information that can inform the roles a social engineer can play.

在这里，我们讨论这个黑客社会工程术语有几个目的。我们将探索黑客社会工程的人际关系动态，然后我们将使用这个概念作为镜头回顾类似的大规模社会工程实践。就像在 Dual Core 的“相信我”中一样，我们将看到一系列借口：建筑工人、慈善组织代表、公民委员会和医疗专业人员。这一基本分析似乎强化了 Dual Core 的观察，即社会工程师可以是任何人，可以针对任何目标。

Here, we take up this hacker social engineer term with several goals. We’ll explore the interpersonal dynamics of hacker social engineering, and then we’ll use the concept as a lens to look backward at similar mass social engineering practices. Just as in Dual Core’s “Trust Me,” we’ll see a range of pretexts: construction workers, representatives of charitable organizations, citizens’ councils, and medical professionals. This basic analysis will appear to reinforce Dual Core’s observation that social engineers can be anyone, anywhere they aim.

然而，我们分析的核心不是社会工程师能够随意扮演任何角色的疯狂能力。相反，我们关注的是限制和引导社会工程借口的社会结构。为了探索这样的社会结构，我们本章的大部分内容都与也许是最著名的社会工程师凯文·米特尼克 (Kevin Mitnick) 进行了探讨。米特尼克最初是一名电话飞客，因黑客罪被定罪后成为重罪犯，后来发展成为受人尊敬的安全顾问，直到今天。关于米特尼克功绩的故事比比皆是，给我们留下了一个印象，他是一个神奇的借口能力。如果说任何人可以成为任何人，无论他想去哪里，这个人可能就是米特尼克。

However, the heart of our analysis is not about the social engineer’s wild abilities to take on any role they please. Instead, we focus on the social structures that constrain as well as inform social engineering pretexts. To explore such social structures, the bulk of our chapter engages with perhaps the most famous social engineer of all, Kevin Mitnick. Mitnick started as a phone phreak, became a felon after being convicted for hacking crimes, then later evolved to be the respected security consultant he is to this day. Stories about Mitnick’s exploits abound, giving us the impression of a man with mythical pretexting abilities. If anyone can be anyone, anywhere he aims, it might be Mitnick.

然而，正如我们所论证的，米特尼克的个人天才被严重夸大了。米特尼克的借口依赖于社会结构。我们从米特尼克的案例中学到的教训是，社会工程师的高超能力并不是借口成功的因素。归根结底，借口之所以能成功，很大程度上要归功于刻板印象的顽固存在。我们将不仅在黑客社会工程中看到刻板印象的力量，而且还会在大规模社会工程中看到，以及后来的大规模个人社会工程中看到。

And yet, as we argue, Mitnick’s individual genius is grossly overstated. Mitnick’s pretexts were reliant on social structures. The lesson we learn from Mitnick’s case is that it’s not the virtuoso abilities of the social engineer that enables a pretext to succeed. Ultimately, pretexts succeed thanks in large part to the pernicious persistence of reductive stereotypes. We will see the power of reductive stereotypes not only in hacker social engineering, but also in mass social engineering and later in masspersonal social engineering.

黑客借口

Hacker Pretexting

借口是黑客社会工程师攻击中一个极其重要的方面；它不能听天由命。它必须事先有条不紊地规划好，专业社会工程师的文献也强调了这一理念。社会工程师需要安全顾问 Sharon Conheady 在其著作《IT 安全中的社会工程学》中提到的“背景故事，解释你是谁以及你为什么需要你请求的信息”。借口“甚至会影响你执行测试时的态度”。4 Conheady的同事 Chris Hadnagy 援引了一个伪方法演绎来描述这一过程：

The pretext is an exceptionally important aspect of a hacker social engineer’s attack; it is not to be left to chance. It must be methodically planned out in advance, and the literature from professional social engineers reinforces this idea. The social engineer needs what security consultant Sharon Conheady’s book Social Engineering in IT Security refers to as “the backstory that explains who you are and why you need the information you are requesting.” The pretext “even influences your attitude while executing the test.”4 Conheady’s colleague, Chris Hadnagy, invokes a pseudo-method acting description of the process:

借口不仅包括构思故事情节，还包括塑造人物的外表、行为、说话和走路方式；决定他们拥有哪些工具和知识；然后掌握所有要素，这样当你接近目标时，你就是那个人，而不仅仅是扮演一个角色。5

Pretexting involves not just coming up with the storyline but also developing the way your persona would look, act, talk, walk; deciding what tools and knowledge they would have; and then mastering the entire package so when you approach the target, you are that person, and not simply playing a character.5

之所以需要如此关注借口，是因为黑客社会工程师会直接通过人际交流与他们的目标接触：通过电话、电子邮件或短信，甚至面对面。因此，在交战期间试用该角色之前，必须进行精心准备。

Such attention to the pretext is needed because hacker social engineers directly engage with their targets in interpersonal communication: on the phone, over email or text, or even in person. The role, then, must be carefully prepared before it is put to trial during an engagement.

这些角色可以根据社会工程师在破坏阶段了解到的情况而有所不同。目标是否向慈善机构捐款？也许我应该通过电子邮件发送慈善协会传单的恶意 PDF。目标是否与特定的自助餐厅供应商签订了合同？我可以模仿他们的制服，通过这种方式进入组织。目标是否使用特定类型的计算机？也许打电话说我是技术支持人员，我需要更新他们的操作系统就可以了。

These roles can vary based on what the social engineer learns during the trashing phase. Does the target donate to charities? Perhaps I should email a malicious PDF of a charitable society’s flier. Does the target contract with a particular cafeteria vendor? I can mimic their uniforms and get into the organization that way. Does the target use a particular type of computer? Perhaps calling up and saying that I’m with tech support and I need to update their operating system can work.

在这些借口中，社会工程师使用“真实性材料”：使他们与他们试图渗透的组织保持一致的物质制品。6常见的物品有制服、身份证、挂绳、名片、安全帽、午餐盒、工具箱、商务装束、电话，或者（如果有人试图从门口后面穿过）几杯外带咖啡。7考虑一下这位社会工程师在以建筑工人为借口时如何实现视觉（以及在较小程度上嗅觉）真实性的指南：

During these pretexts, social engineers use the “stuff of authenticity”: material artifacts that align them with the organization they seek to infiltrate.6 Common artifacts are uniforms, ID badges, lanyards, business cards, hardhats, lunchboxes, toolboxes, business attire, phones, or (if one is trying to tailgate through a door) several to-go cups of coffee.7 Consider this social engineer’s guide to visual (and, to a lesser extent, olfactory) authenticity during a pretext as a construction worker:

一个常见的错误是购买全新的高能见度背心和安全帽，这看起来有些不寻常。有多少工人穿着崭新的服装？当[社会工程师]最终建立起衣柜时……他们用二手的换下了全新的高能见度背心和帽子。不幸的是，二手物品散发着柴油味，但至少它们看起来是真的，因为它们确实是真的。8

A common mistake is to purchase brand-new high visibility vests and hardhats, which stand out as somewhat unusual. How many workmen [sic] are seen with a pristine outfit? When the [social engineers] eventually built up the wardrobe . . . , they swapped brand-new high visibility vests and hats for used ones. Unfortunately, the used items stank of diesel, but at least they looked authentic, because they were.8

在这里，用过和丢弃的衣服可以帮助扮演角色。

Here, used and thrown-out clothing can help with playing the role.

即使是通过电话或数字渠道进行伪装，也需要准备好所有正确的细节。如果黑客社会工程师正在打电话并扮演办公室职员的角色，他们可能会希望在背景中播放办公室声音；电话中心员工的借口可能需要不同的音景（两者都可以通过 YouTube 视频轻松获得）。9如果他们使用电子邮件，则可能需要使用公司徽标或伪造的网站。所有这些还没有提到在电话交谈或书面通信时使用正确的语气。

Even in the case of pretexting over the phone or over digital channels, all the right details need to be in place. If a hacker social engineer is making a telephone call and playing the role of an office worker, they’ll probably want to play office sounds in the background; a phone center employee pretext may call for a different soundscape (both easily available via YouTube videos).9 If they’re using email, a company logo or spoofed website may be in order. And all of this is not to mention using the proper tone during the phone call or in written correspondence.

大规模社会工程借口

Mass Social Engineering Pretexts

虽然人际黑客社会工程师花费了大量时间专注于构建角色和场景，但他们并不是第一批这样做的社会工程师。作为 20 世纪 20 年代的先锋公共关系从业者，大众社会工程师 Edward Bernays 和 Doris Fleischman 经常创造“会改变”目标群体习惯和风俗的情况。10为了做到这一点，这些大众社会工程师使用借口，就像黑客社会工程师一样。然而，与黑客社会工程师不同的是，大众社会工程师并没有亲自扮演这些角色。相反，他们创造的环境中充满了扮演这些角色的替代者。Bernays 明确地写道：

While the interpersonal hacker social engineers have spent a great deal of time focusing on constructing roles and scenarios, they weren’t the first social engineers to do so. As pioneering public relations practitioners in the 1920s, mass social engineers Edward Bernays and Doris Fleischman regularly created “circumstances which will modify” the habits and customs of targeted groups.10 To do so, these mass social engineers used pretexts just as hacker social engineers would do. However, unlike hacker social engineers, mass social engineers did not adopt the roles themselves. Instead, their created circumstances were populated with surrogates who played the roles. Bernays wrote about this explicitly:

公共关系顾问……可能会从客户的角度来争取个人或组织的利益……该个人组织可能会通过自己的渠道宣传[客户的问题]，因为它对此感兴趣。在这种情况下，原点就变成了那个个人或组织。公共关系顾问在客户的利益和第三方的利益之间建立了联系，不再需要在向公众表达的结果中出现。11

the public relations counsel . . . may enlist the interest of an individual or an organization in his client’s point of view. . . . That individual organization may then propagandize [the client’s issue] through its own channels because it is interested in it. In such a case, the point of origin then becomes that individual or organization. The public relations counsel, having made the link between the interest of his client and the interest of the third party, no longer need figure in the resulting expression to the public.11

如果没有现存的团体或个人愿意为伯内斯和弗莱施曼的客户进行宣传，他们就会简单地借用当时社会改革者的剧本，创造

If there were no existing groups or individuals willing to propagandize on behalf of Bernays and Fleischman’s clients, they would simply borrow from the playbook of the social reformers of their time and create

这些看似独立的组织声称支持公共利益：食品饮料卫生分配研究与促进委员会、广播听觉艺术学院、温度研究基金会；[和]中部美国信息局。12

seemingly independent organisations which profess to support concerns of the common good: the Committee for the Study and Promotion of the Sanitary Dispensing of Foods and Drink; the Radio Institute of the Audible Arts; the Temperature Research Foundation; [and] the Middle America Information Bureau.12

虽然这些组织模仿了 20 世纪早期进步社会改革者使用公民委员会的方式，但它们的目的并非自治。相反，它们始终与伯内斯和弗莱施曼受雇开展的特定公关活动有关。例如，美国广泛阅读委员会就是在他们为一家图书出版商做公关工作时成立的。13 据报道，食品和饮料卫生分配研究和促进委员会的成立是为了宣传 Dixie 的一次性纸杯比可重复使用、可清洗的杯子更卫生。14

While these organizations imitated the early twentieth-century progressive social reformers’ use of citizen committees, their purpose was not for self-governance. Instead, they were always tied to a specific public relations campaign Bernays and Fleischman were hired to conduct. For example, the American Council for Wider Reading was formed while they were doing public relations for a book publisher.13 The Committee for the Study and Promotion of the Sanitary Dispensing of Foods and Drink was reportedly created to promote Dixie’s disposable paper cups as more sanitary than reusable, washable cups.14

他们的一项努力值得一提，即伯内斯和弗莱施曼在 20 世纪 20 年代初向宝洁公司提出的一个非常成功的想法：肥皂雕刻比赛。这些比赛是为了支持宝洁公司销售更多香皂的目标而设立的。15从1925年开始，宝洁公司开始赞助美国人用象牙肥皂雕刻艺术品的比赛。但宝洁公司并没有表现出自己是一个“幕后策划者”，而是以成立“全国肥皂雕刻委员会”为借口：

One of their efforts, a wildly successful idea Bernays and Fleischman pitched to Proctor & Gamble in the early 1920s, deserves more mention: soap carving competitions. These were created to support P&G’s goal of selling more bar soap.15 Starting in 1925, P&G began sponsoring contests for Americans to create art carved out of Ivory soap. But rather than appear to be a “string-pulling mastermind,” P&G established a “National Soap Sculpture Committee” as a pretext:

这听起来确实很正式，而其纽约市地址也进一步凸显了委员会在艺术界的可信度。比赛的所有方面都以这个名义公开处理。委员会发布了每一份比赛公告和展览目录，并负责出版一系列由肥皂雕刻师撰写的书籍，介绍他们所选艺术形式的操作方法和原因。16

This sounded very official, indeed, and its New York City address only punctuated the authenticity of the committee’s art world credibility. All aspects of the contest were handled publicly under this name. The committee published every contest announcement and exhibition catalog, and it was responsible for an informative series of books by soap carvers on the how-tos and wherefores of their chosen art form.16

宝洁公司从未被提及是“比赛的唯一发起人和协调员（因此只向其自己的公关项目‘捐赠’资金）。” 17正如詹妮弗·简·马歇尔 (Jennifer Jane Marshall) 在她的文章《宝洁公司大萧条时期的肥皂雕刻比赛》中写道，“通过这种方式，宝洁公司能够避免出现不当行为，这在广告噱头和对它们的愤怒盛行的时代是一种重要的礼仪措施。” 18事实上，甚至比赛的名称都是幌子：“全国白色肥皂肥皂雕刻比赛”没有提到 Ivory 的名字，但比赛期间 Ivory 是市场上唯一的白色肥皂。19

P&G was never mentioned as the “contest’s sole originator and coordinator (thus ‘donating’ money only to its own PR programs).”17 As Jennifer Jane Marshall writes in her article “Procter & Gamble’s Depression-Era Soap-Carving Contests,” “This way P&G was able to avoid the appearance of impropriety, an important measure of decorum in an era when advertising gimmicks—and exasperation with them—ran high.”18 Indeed, even the name of the contest was a front: “The National Soap Sculpture Competition in White Soap” didn’t mention Ivory by name, but Ivory was the only white soap on the market at the time of the contests.19

换句话说，全国肥皂雕塑委员会只是一个借口，扮演着健康艺术比赛赞助商的角色，但由大众社会工程师伯内斯和弗莱施曼设计，以帮助宝洁销售肥皂。象牙的销量确实上升了——即使在大萧条期间也是如此。

In other words, the National Soap Sculpture Committee was a pretext, playing the role of sponsors of wholesome art contests but designed by the mass social engineers Bernays and Fleischman to help P&G sell soap. Sales of Ivory did indeed rise—even during the Great Depression.

但伯内斯和弗莱施曼编造的最臭名昭著的借口或许来自他们在 20 世纪 20 年代末为美国烟草公司工作时，该公司试图增加女性吸烟者的数量。这项工作在很大程度上依赖于借口。他们邀请专家谴责糖并赞扬吸烟，将吸烟与苗条和健康联系起来。伯内斯和弗莱施曼请教了一位医生，医生给了他们这样的医学建议：不要吃含糖的甜点，

But perhaps the most infamous pretexts concocted by Bernays and Fleischman came from their late 1920s work for American Tobacco, a company seeking to increase the number of women smokers. This work relied heavily on pretexting. They linked smoking to thinness and health by enlisting experts to condemn sugar and praise cigarette smoking. Bernays and Fleischman solicited a physician who obliged them with this medical advice: instead of having a sugary dessert,

正确的餐后收尾方式是吃水果、咖啡和香烟。水果可以硬化牙龈、清洁牙齿；咖啡可以刺激口腔唾液流动，起到漱口水的作用；最后香烟可以给口腔消毒、舒缓神经。20

the correct way to finish a meal is with fruit, coffee and a cigarette. The fruit hardens the gums and cleans the teeth; the coffee stimulates the flow of saliva in the mouth and acts as a mouth wash; while finally the cigarette disinfects the mouth and soothes the nerves.20

伯内斯和弗莱施曼将这句话分享给记者，以便让新闻报道医生的建议。为了支持香烟比圣代更健康的说法，伯内斯和弗莱施曼招募了舞蹈学校的老师、摄影师和舞蹈团来赞扬瘦身、戒掉糖果和吸烟。21他们再次与记者分享了这些观点，营造出全国一致反对糖（顺便说一句，支持香烟）的假象。这样，他们的客户美国烟草公司就不必直接提出索赔，而这些代理人则必须这样做。

Bernays and Fleischman shared this quote with journalists in order to get news coverage of the physician’s recommendation. To bolster the claim that cigarettes are healthier than sundaes, Bernays and Fleischman recruited dance school instructors, photographers, and dance troupes to praise being thin, cutting out sweets, and smoking cigarettes.21 Again, they shared these sentiments with reporters, creating the appearance of a nationwide consensus against sugar (and, incidentally, in favor of cigarettes). This way, their client, American Tobacco, never had to make direct claims; these proxies did.

此外，弗莱施曼和伯内斯将吸烟与女权解放联系起来，招募女性参加 1929 年的复活节游行，手持点燃的香烟作为“自由火炬”，抗议女性在公共场合吸烟的禁忌。22目的是让新闻报道这一看似颠覆性的行为。这些女性没有透露她们是由美国烟草公司雇佣的一家公关公司招募参加游行的。23

In addition, Fleischman and Bernays linked cigarette smoking to feminist emancipation, recruiting women to march in the 1929 Easter Parade, carrying lit cigarettes as “torches of freedom” to protest a taboo against women smoking in public.22 The goal was to have this seemingly subversive act covered in the news. The women did not reveal that they were recruited to march by a PR firm hired by American Tobacco.23

最后，为了鼓励更多女性吸食美国烟草公司的 Lucky Strike 香烟（包装为独特的绿色和红色），伯内斯和弗莱施曼在纽约市华尔道夫酒店策划了一场“绿色舞会”。虽然美国烟草公司赞助了这场舞会，但伯内斯和弗莱施曼却将这一事实隐藏在纽约社交名流的背后，后者将功劳揽在自己身上。舞会要求每个人都穿绿色衣服，弗莱施曼回忆说，舞会的“宣传努力”非常成功，“全国掀起了对绿色服装和配饰的需求。” 24再一次，美国烟草公司从未公开点名。

Finally, in order to encourage more women to smoke American Tobacco’s Lucky Strike cigarettes—which came in distinctive green and red packaging—Bernays and Fleischman concocted a “Green Ball” at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York City. While American Tobacco sponsored the ball, Bernays and Fleischman hid that fact behind a front of New York socialites who took credit. The ball required everyone to wear green, and it was so successful in its “propaganda efforts,” recalls Fleischman, “that the country was swept by a demand for green costumes and accessories.”24 And again, American Tobacco was never openly named.

这些做法对于大众社会工程师来说并非不典型——事实上，公共关系史上充斥着代表强大组织的“前线组织”的记录——但伯内斯和弗莱施曼完善了这种形式。25使用借口现在是一种常见的公关策略。26今天，虽然多个专业公共关系团体敦促其成员不要使用这种“第三方技术”，但从制药公司到政府，各利益相关方都在雇用大众社会工程师来制造这些借口，而这种欺骗行为几乎不会受到任何惩罚。27

These practices were not atypical for mass social engineers—indeed, histories of public relations are rife with documentation of “front groups” who stood in for powerful organizations—but Bernays and Fleischman perfected the form.25 The use of pretexts is now a common public relations tactic.26 Today, while multiple professional public relations groups urge their members not to use this “third party technique,” a wide range of interests, from pharmaceutical companies to governments, employ mass social engineers who create these pretexts with few to no consequences for such deceptions.27

要想奏效，这些借口必须令人信服，而这种信念必须从大众社会工程师本身开始。“无论他们服务于什么事业或销售什么商品，有效的宣传者都必须相信它——或者至少暂时相信他们相信它。” 28就像建议黑客社会工程师必须完全信奉他们创造的借口一样，大众社会工程师必须相信他们的工作很重要，他们所倡导的事业对全人类都有好处。

To work, such pretexts had to be believable, and such belief had to start with the mass social engineers themselves. “Whatever cause they serve or goods they sell, effective propagandists must believe in it—or at least momentarily believe they believe in it.”28 Like the recommendation that the hacker social engineer must totally inhabit the pretext they create, the mass social engineer must believe that their work is important, that the cause they champion is beneficial to all of humanity.

“世界上最著名的黑客”

The “World’s Most Famous Hacker”

这种对黑客和大规模社会工程借口的解释可能会给人留下这样的印象：社会工程师几乎可以采取任何可以想象到的借口。伯内斯和弗莱施曼使用的借口尤其具有传奇色彩——许多评论家认为他们代表美国烟草公司所做的工作是 20 世纪女性吸烟率不断上升的主要原因。而我们当代对黑客社会工程师的看法是，他们是狡猾的天才，可以扮演各种各样的角色。

This accounting of hacker and mass social engineering pretexts might give the impression that social engineers can take on just about any pretext imaginable. The pretexts used by Bernays and Fleischman are particularly legendary—many commentators present their work on behalf of American Tobacco as being the key reason women increasingly smoked cigarettes in the twentieth century. And our contemporary vision of hacker social engineers is of devious geniuses who can take on a wide range of roles.

但社会工程学历史上有一个人似乎是伪装大师：凯文·米特尼克 (Kevin Mitnick)，自称“世界上最著名的黑客”。

But there is one figure in social engineering history who appears to be the master pretexter: Kevin Mitnick, the self-proclaimed “world’s most famous hacker.”

在过去的一个世纪中，与社会工程学（无论是大众的、人际的还是其他的）联系最密切的名字是凯文·米特尼克 (Kevin Mitnick)。几乎每次我们向人们提到这个社会工程学书籍项目时，他们都会说：“哦，你是说像凯文·米特尼克这样的人。” 20 世纪 90 年代中期，米特尼克被联邦调查局追捕，1995 年因计算机黑客被捕，被定罪，以及他随后的写作、演讲和安全咨询生涯，都使米特尼克自封为世界上最著名的黑客。他选择的黑客技术不是通过计算机辅助技术侵入网络，而是找个借口，直接打电话给人们，要求访问。米特尼克不仅是最著名的黑客，还是最著名的社会工程师。

More than just about anyone in the past century, the most common name associated with social engineering—mass, interpersonal, or otherwise—is Kevin Mitnick. Almost every time we mentioned this social engineering book project to people, they would say, “Oh, you mean like Kevin Mitnick.” The FBI manhunt in the mid-1990s, his arrest in 1995 for computer hacking, his conviction, and his subsequent writing, speaking, and security consulting careers have all contributed to Mitnick’s self-proclaimed status as the world’s most famous hacker. And his hacking technique of choice is not to break into networks through computer-aided techniques, but instead to use a pretext and simply call people up on the phone and ask for access. Mitnick is not just the most famous hacker; he’s the most famous social engineer.

媒体对米特尼克犯罪生涯以及随后的改过自新和合法化的报道并没有动摇米特尼克的自我神话。29最近关于米特尼克的头条新闻称他为“传奇人物”，“黑客大师”，可以“在不到一小时内进入你的系统”。30米特尼克本人并没有阻止这样的赞美，他向记者吹嘘说他是“黑客界的摇滚明星”，“我非常擅长我想做的事情” 。31他他的著作，尤其是《欺骗的艺术》和《电话里的幽灵》巩固了他的传奇地位。在这些书中，他重温了他的社会工程借口：在一次电话中，他是一名客户。下一次，他是一名警察。接下来，他是一名首席执行官。最后，企业被渗透，信息被窃取，米特尼克的地位也随之上升。最重要的是，通过阅读新闻报道和他的书籍，我们了解到，我们这些倒霉的人类是计算机安全的“薄弱环节”，重复米特尼克最喜欢的一句话。32

Media coverage of Mitnick’s criminal career and subsequent reformation and legitimation have not challenged Mitnick’s self-mythology.29 Recent headlines about Mitnick refer to him as “legendary,” a “master hacker” who can “access your system in less than an hour.”30 Mitnick himself does little to discourage such praise, bragging to journalists that he is a “rock star in the hacker community” and that “I’m very good at what I want to do.”31 And he reinforces his legendary status with his books, especially The Art of Deception and Ghost in the Wires. In those books, he relives his social engineering pretexts: on one telephone call, he’s a customer. The next, he’s a police officer. Next, he’s the CEO. And in the end, businesses are infiltrated, information purloined, and Mitnick’s status grows. Above all, reading through the news coverage and his books, we learn that the rest of us, we hapless humans, are the “weak link” of computer security, to repeat one of Mitnick’s favorite phrases.32

我们可以通过重复米特尼克的功绩故事来轻松为米特尼克神话添砖加瓦，用它们来说明黑客社会工程借口的实际行动，但我们的方法不同。强调米特尼克的功绩掩盖了比揭示的更多的东西。我们不想关注米特尼克精湛的社会工程技巧，而是想关注使他成功的结构。我们将重点关注社会认可结构如何帮助和怂恿他使用借口。

We could easily contribute to the Mitnick mythology by repeating stories of his exploits, using them to illustrate hacker social engineering pretexts in action, but ours is a different approach. Emphasizing Mitnick’s exploits obscures more than it reveals. Instead of focusing on the virtuoso social engineering skills of Mitnick, we want to focus on the structures that enabled him to succeed. We will focus on how his use of pretexts is aided and abetted by social structures of recognition.

身份扮演理论

Theories of Identity Play

社会工程师扮演各种角色的能力促使我们探索后现代理论，这些理论认为身份是完全可塑的。这种观点在 20 世纪 90 年代尤其强大，因为互联网越来越受欢迎，人们在在线聊天、游戏和早期社交媒体中扮演着各种身份。然而，最近，越来越多不同领域的学者开始将他们的分析从以个人为中心的身份表现转向更大的社会结构，这种结构既促成了这种表现，也限制了这种表现。

Social engineers’ ability to inhabit roles invites us to explore postmodern theories that hold that identity is entirely malleable. Such ideas were especially powerful in the 1990s as the internet gained popularity and people performed a range of identities in online chats, games, and early social media. Recently, however, an increasing number of scholars across a range of fields are starting to shift their analysis away from the individual-focused performance of identity to the larger social structures that both enable and constrain such performances.

考虑跨性别身份的酷儿理论家在这方面是一个很好的指导。雷温·康奈尔和卡拉·普费弗将后现代的身份扮演理论与社会学对社会结构和权力关系的兴趣相结合，认为“通过”例如，如果跨性别女性被视为顺性别女性，则她被视为“成功”，这过分强调了女性表现的细节。33相反，两人都主张“认可”的概念，关注这些表现如何被那些有特权的人接受或拒绝。对康奈尔来说，认可是一种关系视角。虽然关注通过可能有助于我们理解社会类别（如男性/女性、酷儿/异性恋或黑人/白人）的表现方面，但认可有助于我们理解这些表现清晰易懂的结构。34在此基础上，普费弗认为，

Queer theorists considering trans identities are a good guide here. Synthesizing the postmodern, identity-play theories of identity with sociology’s interest in social structures and power relations, Raewyn Connell and Carla Pfeffer have argued that “passing,” where, for example, a transgender woman is deemed “successful” insofar as she passes as a cisgender woman, places far too much emphasis on the particulars of the woman’s performance.33 Instead, both argue for the concept of “recognition,” focusing on how such performances are accepted or denied by those with the privilege to do so. For Connell, recognition is a relational perspective. While a focus on passing may help us to understand the performative aspects of social categories (such as male/female, queer/straight, or Black/white), recognition helps us understand the structures in which such performances are legible.34 Building on this, Pfeffer argues that,

社会学家不应该关注跨性别社会行为者如何通过“传递”实现规范性别，而应该关注所有社会行为者在承认或拒绝其他人“属于”（或合法属于）特定性别和性取向认同类别和群体的过程中充当性别秩序的仲裁者。35

rather than focusing on transgender social actors’ accomplishment of normative gender through “passing,” sociologists might focus, instead, on the interactional processes whereby all social actors serve as arbiters of the gender order as they recognize or reject others as “belonging” to (or rightful members of) particular gender and sexual identity categories and groups.35

这种关于身份如何融入社会关系的关系互动主义概念可以在米歇尔·塞雷的神秘哲学中看到，他的著作《寄生虫》提出了一种三部分关系和沟通的三角理论。36对于塞雷来说，沟通不仅仅是一个实体向另一个实体发送信息的问题。必须有第三个术语，即两个实体之间的通道。第三项的一种特殊类型是“空白”或“小丑”，这是塞雷从纸牌和多米诺骨牌游戏中借鉴的概念：

Such a relational, interactionist conception of how identities are enmeshed in social relations can be seen in the enigmatic philosophy of Michel Serres, whose book The Parasite puts forward a triangulating theory of three-part relations and communication.36 For Serres, communication is not simply a matter of one entity sending messages to another. There has to be a third term, a channel between the two entities. One special type of a third term is the “blank” or “joker,” a concept Serres draws from card and domino games:

小丑是游戏中用来改变游戏方向的牌。它会中断游戏，使一组新动作成为可能。同样，白色或空白的多米诺骨牌也可以改变玩家的命运，因为它可以用来连接原本不相称的多米诺骨牌序列。37

The joker is a card in a game that serves to alter the direction of play. It interrupts the game and makes a new set of moves possible. Likewise, the white or blank domino can change the fortunes of a player because it can be played to link sequences of dominoes that are otherwise incommensurable.37

因此，虽然它是百搭牌，但百搭牌或空白牌的价值只取决于游戏中的其他元素。它的存在是游戏的一部分。尽管它的特殊能力可以根据它的背景允许进行更具动态的游戏，它必须结合现有卡片进行。

Hence, while it is wild, the joker or blank takes on value only in relation to other elements in the game. Its presence is part of the game. Though its special capacity to change its role depending on its context allows for a more dynamic game, it must be played in relation to existing cards.

综合这些观点，只有当玩家同意游戏规则并认识到其与其他牌或多米诺骨牌的关系时，百搭牌或空白多米诺骨牌才能在游戏中发挥作用。同样，身份表现（包括借口）只有在得到社区其他成员的认可和合法化时才能发挥作用，而这些成员通常遵循不言而喻的社会规范和规则。只关注传递会忽略其他社会仲裁者的合法化过程，这些仲裁者会隐性或显性地判断表现，随后包括和支持或排除和贬低试图传递的人。同样，只关注百搭牌、百搭牌或空白多米诺骨牌的狂野性会夸大其改变游戏的能力。百搭牌或空白“肯定会扰乱社会秩序，但我们不应忽视这样一个事实，即它也可以拯救而不是破坏秩序。” 38

Bringing these perspectives together, a joker or blank domino can only function within a game if the players both agree upon the rules of the game and recognize its relationship to other cards or dominoes. Likewise, identity performances—including pretexts—work insofar as they are recognized and legitimated by other members of a community who operate under often unspoken social norms and rules. To focus solely on passing ignores the legitimating processes of the other social arbiters who implicitly or explicitly judge the performance and subsequently include and support or exclude and diminish the person attempting to pass. Likewise, focusing solely on the wildness of the wild card, joker, or blank domino is to overstate its capacity to change the game. The joker or blank “certainly adds disruption to social order, but we should not lose sight of the fact that it can also save rather than destroy order.”38

因此，角色扮演不仅仅是承担一个角色的问题；它要求其他人认可并接受角色扮演者。社会结构可以限制，但它们允许在这些限制内进行创造性的身份表现。正如组织研究学者所说，“‘身份’是一个主张，而不是性格；一个角色，而不是个性；一个表现，而不是自我……‘身份’是由观察者和被观察者共同塑造的。” 39

Thus, role-playing is not simply a matter of taking on a role; it requires others to recognize and accept the role-player. Social structures can constrain, but they allow for creative identity performances within those constraints. As organizational studies scholars argue, “‘identity’ is a matter of claims, not character; persona, not personality; and presentation, not self. . . . ‘Identity’ is discursively fashioned by both the observers and the observed.”39

回顾凯文·米特尼克，讲述他的社会工程历史的一种方式是关注他高超的借口，事实上许多评论家正是这样做的。他们暗示他的人际沟通技巧使他能够接受任何借口。这个神话可以说在今天帮助了米特尼克，因为他自称是“世界上最著名的黑客”，并拥有一家安全咨询公司，吹嘘其在渗透测试方面拥有“100% 的成功率” 。40

Turning back to Kevin Mitnick, one way to tell his history of social engineering is to focus on his virtuoso pretexts, and indeed many commentators do precisely this. They imply that his interpersonal communication skills are such that he could take on any pretext. This mythology arguably aids Mitnick today, since he claims the title “the world’s most famous hacker” and owns a security consultancy boasting of having a “100% success rate” in penetration testing.40

然而，理解米特尼克（以及整个社会工程借口）的另一种方式是考虑他扮演社交小丑的能力，一个能够承担不仅得益于他自己的借口技巧，还得益于广泛的社会认可结构。在这些隐喻的游戏规则中，米特尼克的不同角色既提供了维护现有秩序的机会，也破坏了现有秩序。这种方法引起了人们对使借口成为可能的社会网络的关注，表明借口如何有助于维护——而不是颠覆——这些社会网络。当我们从这个角度阅读有关米特尼克的报道以及他自己的著作时，我们开始考虑社会资本的社会结构、跨国公司组织动态和种族刻板印象（特别是亚洲人与白人的并置）如何帮助创造条件，使米特尼克的借口变得可识别。

However, another way of understanding Mitnick—and by extension, social engineering pretexts as a whole—is to consider his capacity to act as a social joker, a blank that is capable of taking on roles thanks not just to his own pretexting skills but also to a wide range of social structures of recognition. Within these metaphorical rules of the game, Mitnick’s varying roles offer a chance to preserve existing orders as much as they disrupt them. This approach draws attention to the social webs that make pretexting possible, showing how pretexting can help maintain—rather than subvert—those social webs. When we read the reporting on Mitnick, as well as his own writings, from this perspective, we start to consider how social structures of social capital, transnational corporate organizational dynamics, and racial stereotypes (particularly, juxtapositions of Asianness against whiteness) help create the conditions that allow Mitnick’s pretexts to become recognizable.

认识米特尼克的借口成功：结构性因素

Recognizing Mitnick’s Pretexting Successes: Structural Factors

社会资本

Social Capital

关于凯文·米特尼克如何意识到社会工程学的前景，最广为流传的故事可能是他在 20 世纪 70 年代还是个孩子的时候，就想出了如何在加利福尼亚州圣费尔南多谷免费乘坐公共汽车。他注意到公交系统使用纸质换乘单，需要特殊的纸质打孔机进行验证，他推测如果他能自己打孔换乘，他就可以免费乘坐公共汽车。在米特尼克的回忆录中，他讲述了他的第一个借口，扮演一个需要物资的学生的角色：

Perhaps the most commonly told story of how Kevin Mitnick awakened to the promises of social engineering is his figuring out how to ride public buses for free throughout the San Fernando Valley of California as a child in the 1970s. He noticed that the bus system used paper transfer slips validated with a special paper punch, and he surmised he could ride the buses for free if he could punch his own transfers. In Mitnick’s memoir, he tells of what may have been his first pretext, playing the role of a student in need of supplies:

我走到公交车前面，坐在离司机最近的座位上。当他在红绿灯前停下时，我说：“我正在做一个学校项目，需要在纸板上打一些有趣的形状。你在转印纸上用的打孔器对我来说很有用。有地方可以买到吗？” 41

I walked to the front of the bus and sat down in the closest seat to the driver. When he stopped at a light, I said, “I’m working on a school project and I need to punch interesting shapes on pieces of cardboard. The punch you use on the transfers would be great for me. Is there someplace I can buy one?”41

这个借口奏效了：公交车司机告诉米特尼克打孔机的销售地点。后来，米特尼克为了得到书籍，做了一些破坏工作。他在公交车站后面的垃圾箱里找到了未使用的换乘票。从那时起，他就可以免费乘坐“公交系统覆盖的所有地方——洛杉矶县、河滨县、圣贝纳迪诺县。” 42
