The pretext worked: the bus driver told Mitnick where the paper punches were sold. Later, Mitnick did some trashing to get books of unused transfers from a dumpster behind a bus depot. From that point on, he rode for free “everywhere the bus system covered—Los Angeles County, Riverside County, San Bernardino County.”42

因此，米特尼克的职业生涯始于交通欺诈。许多研究人员注意到，这种犯罪的起诉情况相当不均衡，差异体现在种族方面：黑人和棕色人种首当其冲地受到交通警察的关注。43但正如白人米特尼克回忆的那样，

Thus, Mitnick’s career starts with transit fraud. This is a crime that many researchers have noted gets prosecuted quite unevenly, with disparities playing out along racial lines: Black and brown citizens bear the brunt of transit cop attention.43 But, as the white Mitnick recalls,

我是否因为翻垃圾桶找公车换乘点和免费乘车而惹上麻烦？……没有。我妈妈认为这很聪明，我爸爸认为这表现出了主动性，而知道我打卡换乘的公车司机认为这很可笑。就好像所有知道我在做什么的人都在向我致敬。44

Did I get into trouble for Dumpster-diving for those bus transfers and riding for free? . . . [N]o. My mom thought it was clever, my dad thought it showed initiative, and bus drivers who knew I was punching my own transfers thought it was a big laugh. It was as though everyone who knew what I was up to was giving me attaboys.44

换句话说，米特尼克家族并没有像黑人和棕色人种的父母那样进行“谈话”——警告美国社会将对犯下哪怕是轻微违法行为的黑人和棕色人种青年进行严厉起诉或处决——而是对小凯文的借口和交通欺诈行为视而不见，或者称赞他打破了制度。45

In other words, rather than having what Black and brown parents call “the talk”—that is, the warning that American society will viciously prosecute or execute young Black and brown men for even minor transgressions—the Mitnick family either turned a blind eye to young Kevin’s pretexts and transit fraud, or they praised him for beating the system.45

从这一刻起，一种模式就出现了：米特尼克开始沉迷于电信的身份扮演，利用各种借口获取受限制的信息和软件，当他被抓到时，他就会回到家人身边，尤其是他生命中爱他的女人身边。例如，在电话公司切断他们的连接后，他的母亲允许他以公寓楼经理的身份骗取 GTE 的电话服务；后来，她对联邦调查局的来访一笑置之。“一个男孩只是在家里玩电脑，能有什么危害呢？”他的母亲问道。正如米特尼克承认的那样，“她根本不知道我在做什么。” 46他的母亲、祖母和姑姑为他提供诉讼费、学费、律师费和保释金。后来，米特尼克的妻子邦妮也支持他（尽管她最终与他离婚了）因为他继续黑客攻击）。所有人都载他到处走，包括上班、下班，以及从各个监狱和警察局。他从利用社会工程学免费搭乘公共汽车到搭家人的便车。

From this moment on, a pattern emerges: Mitnick goes forth and revels in the identity-play possibilities of telecommunications, using a range of pretexts to gain access to restricted information and software, and, when he is caught, retreats to his family, particularly the loving women in his life. His mother, for example, allows him to use a pretext as an apartment building manager to con GTE out of phone service after the phone company shut down their connection; later, she laughs off a visit from the FBI. “What harm could a boy come to just from playing with a computer at home?” his mother asked. As Mitnick admits, “she had no concept of what I was up to.”46 His mother, grandmother, and aunt provide money for suits, tuition, attorney’s fees, and bail. Later, Mitnick’s wife Bonnie also supports him (although she does eventually divorce him because he continues hacking). All of them drive him around, including to work, from work, and from various jails and police stations. He moves from social engineering free rides on the bus to bumming free rides from his family.

正如专业社会工程师 Sharon Conheady 在其著作《IT 安全中的社会工程学》中指出的那样，借口会让人精疲力竭。“你的肾上腺素会剧烈分泌，以至于事后你会完全筋疲力尽。”同样，在Social-Engineer.org Podcast第 120 集中，包括前 FBI 行为学家 Robin Dreeke 和社会工程师 Chris Hadnagy 和 Perry Carpenter 在内的小组成员都告诫未来的社会工程师，借口会让人情绪低落。47这些专业人士强烈建议留出时间来从借口中恢复过来，无论是面对面、在线还是通过电话（米特尼克喜欢的渠道）。对于米特尼克来说，亲戚的社会支持可能让他在借口中知道自己有一个安全的空间可以退缩并从令人肾上腺素激增的活动中恢复过来。他有一个支持结构，可以让他继续前进，“成为任何人，去任何他想去的地方”，但又有地方可以回来恢复。

As professional social engineer Sharon Conheady notes in her book, Social Engineering in IT Security, pretexting can be draining. “Your adrenaline pumps so hard that afterward you are completely exhausted.” Likewise, on the Social-Engineer.org Podcast, episode 120, the panelists, including former FBI behavioralist Robin Dreeke and social engineers Chris Hadnagy and Perry Carpenter, all cautioned would-be social engineers about the emotionally draining aspects of pretexting.47 These professionals strongly recommend setting aside time to recover from pretexts, whether they be in-person, online, or over the phone (the channel Mitnick preferred). For Mitnick, having social support from his relatives may have allowed him to engage in pretexts knowing that he had some safe space to retreat to and recover from his adrenaline-pumping engagements. He had a support structure allowing him to go forth, “be anyone, anywhere he aims,” and yet have somewhere to return to and recover in.

事实上，当我们考虑到 20 世纪 90 年代中期米特尼克逃避联邦调查局追捕的那段时期时，社会支持结构对借口者的必要性就更加凸显了。他与家人断绝关系，改变了身份，搬到了新的城市。他在《Ghost in the Wires》以及记者乔纳森·利特曼的著作《逃亡游戏》中对这段时期的描述都充满了疲惫、偏执和不确定性，因为米特尼克逃离直升机，对坐在停放的汽车里的任何人都心存怀疑，并拒绝接近任何人，以免他们背叛他。

Indeed, the necessity of social support structures for pretexters is highlighted further when we consider the period in the mid-1990s when Mitnick was on the run from the FBI. He cut ties with his family, changed his identity, and moved to new cities. His account of this period in Ghost in the Wires, as well as journalist Jonathan Littman’s book The Fugitive Game, are marked by exhaustion, paranoia, and uncertainty, as Mitnick flees helicopters, is suspicious of anyone sitting in a parked car, and refuses to get close to anyone lest they betray him.

沟通、组织结构和跨国资本主义

Communication, Organizational Structures, and Transnational Capitalism

米特尼克的借口常常利用了一个简单的事实：许多组织分布十分遥远，员工之间彼此并不认识。米特尼克的许多目标（NEC、美国银行、Digital、Pacific Bell、Oakwood Corporate Housing 和 TRW 等）在 20 世纪 90 年代都是在许多地方设有分支机构的地区性、国家性甚至跨国性组织。米特尼克通常会通过相对匿名的电话渗透到这些分布式组织结构中，以缓慢但稳步地收集小信息。正如他所描述的那样，他会收集

Mitnick’s pretexts often exploited a simple fact: many organizations are so far-flung that employees don’t know each other personally. Many of Mitnick’s targets—NEC, Bank of America, Digital, Pacific Bell, Oakwood Corporate Housing, and TRW, to name a few—were, in the 1990s, regional, national, or even transnational-spanning organizations with branches in many locations. Often, Mitnick would infiltrate these distributed organizational structures with the relative anonymity of telephone calls to slowly but surely gather small pieces of information. As he describes the process, he would gather

有关公司的信息，包括该部门或业务单位如何运作、其职能是什么、员工可以访问哪些信息、提出请求的标准程序、他们通常从谁那里获得请求、他们在什么条件下发布所需信息以及公司使用的行话和术语。48

information about the company, including how that department or business unit operates, what its function is, what information the employees have access to, the standard procedure for making requests, whom they routinely get requests from, under what conditions they release the desired information, and the lingo and terminology used in the company.48

米特尼克了解到沟通如何构成这些跨国组织。正如沟通学者所言，沟通有助于定义现实，从而构建互动、行使权力并激发组织内的等级制度。49这在地理分散的组织中尤其如此，在这些组织中，远距离沟通促进了组织单位（如团队）的存在。50米特尼克表现出对沟通如何构建组织的直觉理解，就像一位经理一样，他希望更全面地了解组织中谁在与谁交谈、在什么条件下交谈、他们使用什么术语和语言，以及组织权力如何在这些沟通中表达出来。

What Mitnick learns is how communication constitutes these transnational organizations. As communication scholars argue, communication helps define reality, and thus structures interaction, enacts power, and animates hierarchies within organizations.49 This is especially true in the cases of geographically distributed organizations, where communication across distance facilitates the very existence of organizational units, such as teams.50 Mitnick demonstrated an intuitive understanding of how communication structures an organization, and much like a manager, he wanted a larger picture of who speaks to whom in organizations, under what conditions, what terms and language they use, and how organizational power is expressed in those communications.

米特尼克对太平洋贝尔公司进行社会工程学的一个例子进一步说明了这一点。根据他之前的侦察（无论是通过破坏、交换文件还是电话询问），米特尼克了解了目标公司成员参与的沟通习惯。这些知识包括熟悉内部行话。利用这一点和

An example from Mitnick’s social engineering of Pacific Bell illustrates this further. Based on his previous reconnaissance (whether through trashing, trading for documents, or phone-based inquiries), Mitnick learns the rituals of communication that members of the target corporations engage in. This knowledge includes familiarity with insider lingo. Using this and

我假装自己是现场技术人员，打电话给太平洋贝尔的机械化环路分配中心（MLAC），也称为线路任务办公室。一位女士接了电话，我说：“嗨。我是特里，在外地。我需要 F1 和 F2，电话号码是 310 837-5412……”

“特里，你的技术代码是多少？”她问道。

我知道她不会查的——他们从来没查过。任何三位数都可以，只要我听起来很自信，毫不犹豫。

“六三七，”我随机选了一个数字…… 51

posing as a technician in the field, I called Pacific Bell’s Mechanized Loop Assignment Center, or MLAC, also known simply as the Line Assignment Office. A lady answered and I said, “Hi. This is Terry out in the field. I need the F1 and the F2 on 310 837–5412 . . .”

“Terry, what’s your tech code?” she asked.

I knew she wasn’t going to look it up—they never did. Any three-digit number would satisfy, so long as I sounded confident and didn’t hesitate.

“Six three seven,” I said, picking a number at random . . .51

为了使他作为技术人员的借口奏效，必须满足索取信息（米特尼克的技术代码）和提供信息的仪式，并且其他术语和技术要素也都到位。多亏了这一点，米特尼克能够获得他所寻求的信息——对手黑客的地址——而太平洋贝尔员工则认为她通过与他的互动成功重建了组织。

In order for his pretext as a technician to work, the ritual of asking for information (Mitnick’s tech code) and giving it must be satisfied, and the rest of the lingo and technical elements are in place. Thanks to this, Mitnick is able to get the information he seeks—an address for a rival hacker—while the Pacific Bell employee believes that she successfully reconstitutes the organization through her interaction with him.

米特尼克的成功与其说取决于他所谓的技能，不如说取决于简单的组织沟通惯例。正如他所解释的那样，

Mitnick’s success here hinges far less on his putative skills than on simple, organizational communication routines. As he explains,

为什么 Line Assignment 的那位女士如此愿意回答我的问题？仅仅因为我给了她一个正确的答案，问了正确的问题，使用了正确的术语。所以不要以为给我地址的 Pacific Bell 职员是愚蠢或反应迟钝的。办公室里的人通常会在请求看起来真实时给予他人信任。52

Why was the lady in Line Assignment so willing to answer my questions? Simply because I gave her one right answer and asked the right questions, using the right lingo. So don’t go thinking that the Pacific Bell clerk who gave me [the] address was foolish or slow-witted. People in offices ordinarily give others the benefit of the doubt when the request appears to be authentic.52

换句话说，米特尼克扮演“特里在现场”的表演并非是大师级的表演，也不依赖于某种催眠。简而言之，他所呼叫的接线员认为这是太平洋贝尔这个大型区域组织日常交流结构中看似正常的一部分。

In other words, Mitnick’s performance as “Terry out in the field” was not some virtuoso acting, nor was it reliant upon some sort of hypnosis. Simply put, it was recognized by the operator he called as a seemingly normal part of day-to-day communicative structure that constituted the large, regional organization that is Pacific Bell.

通过通讯网络绘制出该组织的地图后，米特尼克可以利用手机的相对匿名性，将自己插入该组织并捕获网络上流动的信息。他会使用各种借口，从声称自己是该组织的特定成员到声称自己是外部人员，例如承包商或企业合作伙伴。但他总是必须与其他人打交道，确保他的沟通实践与目标组织的沟通实践保持一致。

After having mapped the organization via its communication network, Mitnick could use the relative anonymity of the phone to insert himself into the organization and capture information as it flowed across the network. He would use a variety of pretexts, ranging from claiming to be a specific member of the organization to claiming to be an outsider, such as a contractor or business partner. But he always had to do so in relation to others, making sure his communicative practices aligned with those of his target organization.

“我的英雄是日本男孩”：米特尼克的黄脸吟游诗人

“My Hero Is Japboy”: Mitnick’s Yellowface Minstrelsy

米特尼克还利用了现有的文化结构，尤其是种族刻板印象。米特尼克（以及美国文化）与日本人在 20 世纪 90 年代的特殊关系，为米特尼克最臭名昭著的借口之一提供了依据。

Mitnick also took advantage of existing cultural structures, particularly racial stereotyping. Mitnick’s—and by extension, American culture’s—peculiar relationship with Japanese people in the 1990s informed one of Mitnick’s most notorious pretexts.

据多家报纸和书籍报道，在 20 世纪 90 年代中期米特尼克逃亡期间，帮助 FBI 抓获他的一个关键人物是日裔美国计算物理学家兼安全专家下村疆。有一次，米特尼克侵入了下村疆的计算机。作为回应，下村疆协助 FBI 追捕米特尼克。在下村疆的帮助下，FBI 于 1995 年在北卡罗来纳州罗利的公寓中抓获了米特尼克。53

As several newspapers and books reported, a key person who helped the FBI catch Mitnick during his fugitive period in the mid-1990s was the Japanese-born American computational physicist and security expert Tsutomu Shimomura. At one point, Mitnick broke into Shimomura’s computer. In response, Shimomura aided the FBI in hunting down Mitnick. Thanks to Shimomura’s help, the FBI caught Mitnick in his apartment in Raleigh, North Carolina, in 1995.53

作为一名在 20 世纪 90 年代因追踪和抓捕“全球头号黑客”而声名鹊起的日裔美国人，美国新闻界对下村的报道大肆渲染他的种族背景并不令人意外。同样不足为奇的是——尽管如此——报道中的种族主义仍然令人深感不安。对下村与米特尼克的报道带有美国研究学者约瑟夫·元所说的“黄脸杂耍”的色彩，“非亚裔利用亚洲武术、艺术家和手工艺品取乐和牟利。” 54正如元所说，黄脸杂耍与美国白人对黑脸杂耍表演的旧做法相似

As a Japanese-born American who gained fame in the 1990s for tracking and catching “the world’s most wanted hacker,” it is not surprising that the American journalistic coverage of Shimomura played up his ethnic background. Also not surprising—but nonetheless deeply disturbing—was the racism of the coverage. The coverage of Shimomura versus Mitnick took on valences of what American studies scholar Joseph Won calls “yellowface minstrelsy,” “the use of Asian martial arts, artists and artifacts by non-ethnic Asians for fun and profit.”54 As Won argues, yellowface minstrelsy parallels older white American appropriative practices of blackface minstrel shows

正如黑人舞蹈、音乐和语言表演概括了 19 世纪的黑人文化一样，今天的亚洲武术形象在很大程度上构成了当代电视、电影、报纸和杂志消费者所熟知的“亚洲（和亚裔美国人）文化” 。55

in the same way that black dance, music and verbal play summarized black culture in the 19th century, Asian martial arts images today comprise in large part what contemporary consumers of television, film, newspapers and magazines know as “Asian (and Asian American) culture.”55

《纽约时报》对下村的报道是有关这位安全研究员的第一批文章之一，它巧妙地唤起了人们对武术的想象。在讨论米特尼克入侵下村的电脑时，

A New York Times profile of Shimomura was one of the first articles on the security researcher, and it subtly invoked visions of martial arts. Discussing Mitnick’s hacking of Shimomura’s computer,

这就像是小偷为了证明自己的实力，偷窃了锁匠的物品。这就是为什么本案中钥匙保管人 Tsutomu Shimomura 将入室盗窃视为个人侮辱——以及为什么他认为破案是荣誉问题。56

It was as if the thieves, to prove their prowess, had burglarized the locksmith. Which is why Tsutomu Shimomura, the keeper of the keys in this case, is taking the break-in as a personal affront—and why he considers solving the crime a matter of honor.56

“荣誉问题”引发了美国人对亚洲功夫电影的特殊迷恋，并通过这些电影，体现了 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代美国和亚洲文化（尤其是日本）之间不稳定的关系。57 以这种方式描述下村对米特尼克的追求在随后的报道中得到了进一步的放大。例如， 《滚石》杂志的一篇文章将下村和米特尼克之间的较量描述为“武士与网络窃贼”的较量。58此类报道是人们对 20 世纪 90 年代美国神秘、精通技术且富有的日本人的更大担忧的一部分。59下村在计算机和数字网络方面的能力——这两件事许多​​人觉得难以捉摸和难以理解——可能加剧了神秘感，导致他使用熟悉而又奇特的流行文化比喻武术。

A “matter of honor” invokes a peculiar American fascination with Asian martial arts movies and, through them, the uneasy relationship between American and Asian cultures—particularly Japan—in the 1980s and 1990s.57 Framing Shimomura’s pursuit of Mitnick in such terms gets amplified in subsequent coverage. A Rolling Stone article, for example, presented the contest between Shimomura and Mitnick as a battle of “the samurai and the cyberthief.”58 Such coverage is part of the larger anxiety about the mysterious, technologically adept and wealthy Japanese in 1990s America.59 Shimomura’s abilities with computers and digital networks—two things that many people find inscrutable and difficult to fathom—likely intensified the mystery, resulting in the use of familiar and yet exotic popular culture tropes of martial arts.

也许最令人震惊的黄脸戏法陷害下村的例子出现在米特尼克评论他昔日的对手时，尤其是在《逃亡游戏》一书中，记者乔纳森·利特曼在书中附上了与当时在逃的米特尼克的电话记录。他们之间的几次谈话都是关于下村的，当时下村正在追踪米特尼克。利特曼将下村描述为“吹捧的武士”。60他与米特尼克讨论了《新闻周刊》上下村的照片：“在键盘旁边，”利特曼告诉米特尼克，“我发誓它看起来像是一把武士刀。” 61米特尼克回答说：“我敢肯定他想砍掉一些人的头……” 62然后，根据利特曼的说法，“米特尼克尽其所能模仿功夫大师。‘你让我的家人蒙羞。你会死！我会见到你……我们会战斗到死！’” 63在这里，米特尼克的口音是黄脸戏法的一个例子，用武术陈词滥调来讨论“荣誉问题”。为了进一步加剧对抗，米特尼克还在在线聊天中嘲笑下村，说：“我的英雄是日本男孩。” 64

Perhaps the most egregious examples of the yellowface minstrelsy framing of Shimomura appears when Mitnick comments on his erstwhile foe, especially in the book The Fugitive Game, where journalist Jonathan Littman includes transcripts of his phone calls with then-fugitive Mitnick. Several of their conversations were about Shimomura, who by then was tracking Mitnick. Littman describes Shimomura as a “touted samurai.”60 He discusses a picture of Shimomura in Newsweek with Mitnick: “Next to the keyboard,” Littman tells Mitnick, “I swear it looks like there is a samurai sword.”61 Mitnick replies, “I’m sure he’d like to chop some people’s heads off. . . .”62 Then, according to Littman, “Mitnick does his best kung fu master imitation. ‘You dishonored my family. You will die! I’ll meet you . . . and we will fight to the death!’”63 Here, Mitnick’s accent is an instance of yellowface minstrelsy, using martial arts clichés to discuss the “matter of honor.” To further fuel the antagonism, Mitnick also mocks Shimomura in an online chat, saying, “my hero is japboy.”64

然而，米特尼克并没有将他的黄脸口音限制在他与利特曼的私人谈话中。对下村的报道中所体现的黄脸吟游诗人刻板印象也帮助米特尼克找到了一个借口，将我们带到了社会工程师可能利用的另一个结构性背景：种族刻板印象。正如他在《电线中的幽灵》中所写，米特尼克想要“闯入 NEC 的网络并下载美国使用的所有 NEC 手机的源代码”。65为此，他首先以“IT 部门的罗布”为借口访问了一台计算机。66但他想获取更多数据，因此他又打电话给了同一名 NEC 员工，这次的借口完全不同。有了这个第二个借口，米特尼克变得如他所说“大胆”：

However, Mitnick did not limit his use of yellowface accents to his private conversations with Littman. The same yellowface minstrelsy stereotyping that informed coverage of Shimomura also aided Mitnick with one of his pretexts, bringing us to another structural context that social engineers might exploit: racial stereotypes. As he writes in Ghost in the Wires, Mitnick wanted to “break into NEC’s network and download the source code for all the NEC cell phones used in the United States.”65 To do so, he first used the pretext “Rob in the IT department” to gain access to one computer.66 But he wanted to get more data, so he called the same NEC employee back, this time with a different pretext altogether. With this second pretext, Mitnick gets, as he claims, “gutsy”:

说到模仿口音，我可不是 Rich Little，但我打算尝试模仿 NEC 日本移动无线电部门的高田先生。

我打电话给 [NEC 美国员工 Jeff Lankford]。当他拿起电话时，我开始表演：

“先生，啊，Lahngfor，我是 Takada 先生……来自日本。”他知道这个名字，并询问他能帮上什么忙。

“先生，拉恩……我们没有找到，啊，热狗项目的第三版第五版”——使用我为 NEC P7 源代码挑选的代号。“你能，啊，安装 mrdbolt [NEC 服务器] 吗？”

他向我保证他有 3.05 版本的软盘并且可以上传。

“啊，谢谢……啊，谢谢您，杰夫先生……我很快就会去看看 mrdbolt。再见。” 67

I was no Rich Little when it came to doing accents, but I was going to try to pass myself off as Takada-san, from NEC Japan’s Mobile Radio Division.

I called [NEC USA employee Jeff Lankford] at his desk. When he picked up the phone, I launched into my act:

“Misterrrr, ahh, Lahngfor, I Takada-san . . . from Japan.” He knew the name and asked how he could help.

“Misterrr Lahng . . . for—we no find, ahhh, vers’n three ohh five for hotdog uhh project”—using the codename I’d picked up for the NEC P7 source code. “Can you, ahhh, put on mrdbolt [an NEC server]?”

He assured me that he had Version 3.05 on floppy and could upload it.

“Ahhh, thank . . . ahhh, thank you, Mr. Jeff . . . I check mrdbolt soon. Bye.”67

由于这一方法有效，米特尼克为自己感到自豪：这是一种“显然并不太可悲的口音”。

Because this works, Mitnick gives himself a pat on the back: it was an “apparently not-too-pathetic accent.”

米特尼克在扮演黄脸口音时，迎合了 20 世纪 90 年代美国人对日本的看法，这种看法也激发了对下村的新闻报道。这并不是对日本人说话、生活和行为方式的细致理解，而是一种满足美国人对日本人看法的说话方式。在这种框架下，六岁起就住在美国的下村不是滑雪爱好者，而是一个手持武士刀的网络功夫战士，正在寻求恢复自己的荣誉。米特尼克成为了一个最终未能打败他的对手功夫大师。68同样，米特尼克饰演高田先生的黄脸口音也是 20 世纪 90 年代美国很容易辨认的借口。

In invoking a yellowface accent, Mitnick played to the same 1990s American visions of Japan that fueled the journalistic coverage of Shimomura. This was not a nuanced understanding of the many ways the Japanese speak, live, and act, but rather a mode of speaking that satisfied American perceptions of the Japanese. In this framing, Shimomura, who had lived in America since he was six, was no ski bum, but rather a sort of samurai sword-wielding cyber-kung fu warrior on a quest to regain his honor. And Mitnick becomes a rival kung fu master who ultimately fails to best him.68 Likewise, Mitnick’s yellowface accent as Takada-san is a pretext readily recognizable in 1990s America.

从借口的关系方面来看，这种黄脸戏法对米特尼克有利，因为它满足了接听电话的人，而接听电话的人可能自己也利用偏见来判断米特尼克打来的电话是否合法。对于兰克福德来说，这种口音显然“不太可怜”，只是一种过眼云烟。这是刻板印象在身份表现过程中发挥作用的一个具体案例：

In terms of the relational aspects of pretexting, such yellowface minstrelsy benefited Mitnick because it satisfied the recipient of his call, who may himself have drawn on prejudices to judge the legitimacy of Mitnick’s call. The accent was apparently “not-too-pathetic,” a passing accent, for Lankford. This is a specific case of how stereotypes function during an identity performance:

由于这些结构根深蒂固，而且利用它们可以带来切实的好处，这些刻板印象的再现（通过传递和再传递）可能在抽象上对社会等级制度构成挑战，但从字面意义上讲，也会强化社会等级制度。69

Because these structures are so ingrained and because taking advantage of them can offer such concrete advantages, the reproduction of these stereotypes (through passing and to pass) may in the abstract present a challenge to social hierarchies, but in the literal sense also reinforces them.69

我们可能会认为米特尼克这样的社会工程师是颠覆性的，而他的受害者则是倒霉的乡巴佬，考虑到借口的关系方面，我们不得不质疑高田先生或“下村武士”如何在 20 世纪 90 年代美国人对日本的担忧背景下强化社会等级制度。谁更容易被辨认出是“日本人”——来自新泽西州普林斯顿的古板、长发滑雪爱好者，还是说话很快、口音像 Kwai Chang Caine 或 Yunioshi 先生一样的白人？哪种口音更可信：平淡的俄亥俄山谷广播声音，还是以“啊”和省略辅音打断的讲话？这两种口音——可能是白人的“IT 界的 Rob”和假日本人的“高田先生”都很容易理解。米特尼克 (Mitnick) 的借口，并且两者都针对同一个 NEC 员工，该员工致力于通过支持（而不是质疑）他的同事、组织等级制度或主导种族秩序来帮助公司正常运转。

Whereas we may view a social engineer like Mitnick as subversive and his victims as hapless rubes, taking up the relational aspects of pretexting, we have to question how Takada-san or “Shimomora the Samurai” reinforce social hierarchies in the context of the American anxieties about Japan during the 1990s. Who is more recognizably “Japanese”—the staid, long-haired ski bum from Princeton, New Jersey, or the white man fast-talking in a Kwai Chang Caine-esque or Mr. Yunioshi-esque accent? Which accent is more believable: a flat Ohio Valley radio voice or speech punctuated by “ahhs” and dropped consonants? Both accents—the presumably white “Rob in IT” and the faux-Japanese “Takada-san” were ready to hand for Mitnick for his pretexts, and both worked on the same NEC employee, who is invested in helping the corporation function by supporting—and not questioning—his colleagues, the organizational hierarchy, or the dominant racial order.

社会工程和刻板印象

Social Engineering and Stereotyping

凯文·米特尼克 (Kevin Mitnick) 的神话认为，他可以通过电话做任何借口，通过胡扯进入任何信息系统。这种神话只关注米特尼克的表现，让人觉得他的能力是独一无二的天才。然后，我们可以将这种神话更广泛地扩展到社会工程学。社会工程师——无论是大众、人际还是大众个人——都可以扮演任何他们喜欢的角色来操纵我们。米特尼克等黑客社会工程师的荒诞故事、爱德华·伯内斯 (Edward Bernays) 和多丽丝·弗莱施曼 (Doris Fleischman) 等大众社会工程师的故事，或俄罗斯人操纵在线通信的幽灵，都给人留下了极其熟练、精英操纵目标的印象。

The myth of Kevin Mitnick held that he could do any pretext over the phone and bullshit his way into any information system. Such a myth focuses solely on Mitnick’s performances, making it seem as if his abilities are those of a singular genius. We may then extend such mythologies to social engineering more broadly. A social engineer—mass, interpersonal, or masspersonal—can play any role they please and manipulate us. The wild stories of hacker social engineers like Mitnick, the stories from mass social engineers like Edward Bernays and Doris Fleischman, or the specter of Russians manipulating online communication, create the perception of extremely skilled, elite manipulators of targets.

正如我们所表明的，情况并非完全如此。在实践中，米特尼克的社会工程借口在很大程度上依赖于他人的认可，尤其是他们的目标。他在关系网中运作，并从他人的认可中受益，从而扮演他选择的角色。在这样做的过程中，他能够成为一个小丑或空白，并且“通过拦截关系来 [制造] 一种差异”。70米特尼克在电话中，在借口中，必须结合他所处的更大的社会、组织和文化背景来理解，而不是独立于它们。我们研究了米特尼克的案例，以展示这种关系的一些具体维度：社会资本、组织结构和社会刻板印象。在这里，我们想使用最后一个类别，即社会刻板印象，并回到我们在本章开头提到的大众和人际社会工程师的更广泛的借口实践。

As we have shown, this is not entirely the case. In practice, Mitnick’s social engineering pretexts rely heavily on the recognition of others, especially their targets. He operated within webs of relationships and benefited from the recognition of others to pass in the roles he chose to play. In doing so, he was able to be a joker or blank and “[engineer] a kind of difference by intercepting relations.”70 Mitnick on the phone, in the midst of a pretext, must be understood in relation to the larger social, organizational, and cultural contexts he was operating in, not independent of them. We’ve examined the case of Mitnick to show some specific dimensions of this relationality: social capital, organizational structure, and social stereotyping. Here, we want to use the last category, social stereotyping, and return to the broader pretexting practices of mass and interpersonal social engineers we began this chapter with.

一个教训是显而易见的：在借口方面，某些身体和主观性比其他身体和主观性享有更多的灵活性。拥有大量社会资本并讲该地区主流语言的白人顺性别男性的选择范围可能比没有稳定家庭、说话带有非规范口音的非二元有色人种的选择范围更大。71

One lesson is clear: some bodies and subjectivities enjoy more flexibility than others when it comes to pretexting. The range of options open to white, cisgender males who have a great deal of social capital and speak the dominant language of a region is likely larger than those available to a non-binary person of color who does not have a stable home and speaks with a non-normative accent.71

但无论社会工程师的具体存在与否，他们的借口都必须得到关系上的认可。

But no matter the embodied existence of the social engineer, their pretexts must be relationally recognized.

例如，在一次安全会议的演讲中，黑客社会工程师兼安全专家 Sharon Conheady 带领观众进行了一次思想实验：“哪些……借口对我最有可能奏效？”她指出，她身材矮小，“看起来不像黑客”；她以女性身份出现，口音是爱尔兰语。然后，她介绍了一些场景，让观众判断她成功的可能性。IT 部门？不，她说，这很尴尬；人们问她是不是迷路了。老师？是的。清洁工？“是的，完全是，”她说。女服务员？是的。建筑工人？不。电信工程师？不是。首席执行官？这时，她陈述了自己的观点：“我们迎合刻板印象。尽管我讨厌这样，但我们就是迎合刻板印象。” 72她指出，在网络钓鱼攻击中，她在电子邮件中假装自己是首席执行官可能会奏效，但在现场这样做会“相当厚颜无耻”。事实上，鉴于她的形象和表现方式，康黑迪在某些角色上会拥有其他人可能不具备的优势。但她不能只是随便一个人。她必须得到认可。

For example, in a presentation at a security conference, hacker social engineer and security professional Sharon Conheady takes her audience through a thought experiment: “which . . . pretexts are the most likely to work for me?” She notes she’s short and “doesn’t look like a hacker”; she presents as female, and her accent is Irish. She then goes through scenarios, asking the audience to judge her likelihood of success. IT department? No, she says, it’s awkward; people ask her if she’s lost. Teacher? Yes. Cleaner? “Yeah, totally,” she says. Waitress? Yes. Construction worker? No. Telecoms engineer? No. CEO? At that point, she states her point: “We play to stereotypes. As much as I hate it, we play to stereotypes.”72 As she notes, her pretext as a CEO over email in a phishing attack might work, but doing so in person would be “pretty brazen.” And indeed, given her embodiment and ways of performing her identity, Conheady would have advantages in some of these roles that other people may not enjoy. But she cannot be just anybody. She must be recognized.

社会工程师必须“迎合刻板印象”，这一现象并不局限于当代黑客社会工程师。正如对爱德华·伯奈斯作品的分析所指出的那样，伯奈斯

That a social engineer has to “play to stereotypes” is not limited to contemporary hacker social engineers. As an analysis of the work of Edward Bernays argues, Bernays

认为刻板印象“对公关顾问的工作有很大帮助”，因为“普通人”也能理解它们，尽管他承认，它们“不一定是它们应该描绘的真实画面”。无论如何，根据伯内斯的说法，[公共关系]从业者可以利用刻板印象来达到公众，然后加入自己的想法来巩固自己的地位，并赋予它“更大的承载力” 。73

regards stereotypes as “a great aid to the public relations counsel in his work” because they can be grasped by “the average mind,” even though, he acknowledges, they are “not necessarily truthful pictures of what they are supposed to portray.” No matter, according to Bernays, [public relations] practitioners can use stereotypes to reach a public and then add their own ideas to fortify their position and give it “greater carrying power.”73

对于伯内斯（和弗莱施曼）来说，刻板印象是对特定世界观的顺从，这与传播理论家沃尔特·李普曼（Walter Lippmann）将刻板印象视为一种简化的速记的说法一致。74但与批评刻板印象的李普曼不同，伯内斯和弗莱施曼认为刻板印象是大规模社会工程的资源。为了利用刻板印象，伯内斯建议关注“群体倾向于标准化个人的习惯并为其分配合乎逻辑的理由”。75伯内斯强烈否认任何诉求都会对目标群体起作用：

For Bernays (and Fleischman), a stereotype is conformity to a particular worldview, consonant with communication theorist Walter Lippmann’s formulation of stereotypes as a reductive shorthand.74 But unlike Lippmann, who is critical of the use of stereotypes, Bernays and Fleischman see in them resources to leverage for mass social engineering. To leverage stereotypes, Bernays suggests paying attention to the “tendency the group has to standardize the habits of individuals and to assign logical reasons for them.”75 Bernays vehemently denies that just any appeal will work for the group being targeted:

公共关系顾问所代表的事业必须与他试图接触的公众具有共同的群体反应和传统。这必须存在，他们才能相互产生同情反应。76

The cause [the public relations counsel] represents must have some group reaction and tradition in common with the public he [sic] is trying to reach. This must exist before they can react sympathetically upon one another.76

“公众舆论是公共关系顾问和群体意识相互作用的结果”。77刻板印象有助于调解这种相互作用。作为人们用来顺从群体的心理捷径，刻板印象成为社会工程的有力工具——它们很容易被识别。因此，回到伯内斯和弗莱施曼使用掩护团体作为借口的问题，他们的团体必须被识别——他们必须符合刻板印象——才能成功管理目标人群。

“Public opinion is the resultant of the interaction between” the public relations counsel and the group mind.77 And stereotypes help mediate that interaction. As mental shortcuts people use to conform to their groups, stereotypes become powerful tools for social engineering—they are easily recognized. So, returning to Bernays and Fleischman’s use of front groups as pretexts, their groups had to be recognized—they had to fit the stereotype—in order to successfully manage the targeted crowds.

总体而言，正如我们所指出的，利用刻板印象是可能的，因为社会工程师想要接触的人有先入之见。根据康黑迪的经验，一个身材娇小的爱尔兰女人在服务员工作打破了其他人的预期，他们问她是不是迷路了。但女服务员很容易被他们识别出来，而且非常符合他们的观念。对于米特尼克来说，他在电话里用男性的声音说话是一种灵活的工具，可以扮演技术人员、警察或经理的角色——甚至可以扮演日本人的卡通版工程师，只要角色能够被识别。对于伯内斯和弗莱施曼来说，社会刻板印象成为针对不同群体的公关活动的便捷简写。这些举动必须被识别。

Overall, playing to stereotypes is possible, as we suggest, due to the preconceptions of those the social engineer is seeking to engage with. In Conheady’s experience, being a petite Irish woman working on servers broke the expectations of others, who asked if she was lost. But being a waitress is easy for them to recognize and fits their notions quite well. For Mitnick, his male voice on the phone was a supple instrument that could play the role of technician, police officer, or manager—or even a cartoonish version of a Japanese engineer, so long as the roles could be recognized. For Bernays and Fleischman, social stereotypes become convenient shorthand in public relations campaigns directed at various groups. These moves just have to be recognizable.

换句话说，正如哈德纳吉和伯内斯在本章题词中所说，社会工程师利用刻板印象来避免目标思考。目标是识别，而不是认知。

In other words, as Hadnagy and Bernays put it in the epigraphs to this chapter, the social engineer uses stereotypes in order to avoid having the target think. The goal is recognition, not cognition.

结论

Conclusion

借口是社会工程学方法的重要组成部分。虽然我们主要关注米特尼克在 20 世纪 90 年代的职业生涯以及他在 21 世纪的回忆，但米特尼克的借口奏效的动力反映在社会工程学文献中。在这里，我们谈到了大众社会工程师伯内斯和弗莱施曼如何理论化大众社会工程中的刻板印象，稍后，我们将回到我们所说的大众个人社会工程中的借口刻板印象。我们鼓励其他人从相关性的角度来分析借口，而不是社会工程师的表面技能，以便更好地理解这些欺骗是如何运作的。

Pretexting is a staple part of the social engineering approach. While we have largely focused on Mitnick’s career in the 1990s, as well as his recollection of it in the 2000s, the dynamics that made Mitnick’s pretexts work are reflected across the social engineering literature. Here, we’ve touched on how the mass social engineers Bernays and Fleischman theorized stereotypes in mass social engineering, and later, we will return to this focus on stereotypes in pretexts in what we’re calling masspersonal social engineering. We encourage others to analyze pretexting in terms of relationality, rather than the ostensible skills of the social engineer, to better understand how these deceptions work.

当社会工程师努力寻找一个可识别的借口时，总有一天，他们必须将借口付诸行动。这是与狡猾目标交战的时刻。这是胡扯的时刻。我们接下来讨论这个问题。

While the social engineer works hard to develop a recognizable pretext, there comes a moment when the pretext has to be put into action. This is the moment of engagement with the wily target. This is a moment for bullshit. We turn to this next.

5

5

胡说八道：欺骗、友善、准确

Bullshitting: Deception, Friendliness, and Accuracy

这种角色往往非常友善、能干、乐于助人，你会很庆幸遇到他。

This character is often so friendly, glib, and obliging that you’re grateful for having encountered him.

—凯文·米特尼克 (Kevin Mitnick) 谈及社会工程师1

—Kevin Mitnick on the social engineer1

...任何编辑都会非常乐意得到帮助来直接核实任何事实陈述。

. . . Any editor will be assisted most cheerfully in verifying directly any statement of fact.

—艾维·李，《原则宣言》2

—Ivy Lee, “Declaration of Principles”2

社会工程师都是吹牛高手。

Social engineers are master bullshitters.

他们中有些人甚至会公开承认这一点。20 世纪 70 年代到 90 年代的电话飞客尤其公开承认自己是骗子。事实上，他们并不称之为“社会工程”，而是更经常地称他们从电信公司员工那里骗取信息的做法是“胡说八道”。

Some of them would even admit this openly. The phone phreaks of the 1970s through 1990s were especially open about being bullshitters. In fact, instead of calling it “social engineering,” more often they simply called their practice of conning telco employees out of information “bullshitting.”

和“垃圾信息”一样，电话飞客使用的术语“胡说八道”听起来很粗俗。难怪当代安全研究人员使用“社会工程”一词——它听起来更体面。但和垃圾信息一样，胡说八道也是一个丰富而复杂的概念。它所阐明的不仅仅是电话探索。使用胡说八道的概念作为镜头，可以揭示当代人际社会工程实践以及二十世纪早期至中期较早的大规模社会工程实践的大量信息。展望未来，这一概念将与诋毁和借口一起成为帮助我们阐明当代大规模人际社会工程实践的工具。

Much like “trashing,” the phone phreak term “bullshitting” sounds crude. No wonder contemporary security researchers use the phrase “social engineering”—it just sounds more respectable. But like trashing, bullshitting is a rich and complex concept. Focusing on it illuminates more than just telephone exploration. Using the concept of bullshitting as a lens reveals a great deal about contemporary interpersonal social engineering practice, and as well as the older mass social engineering practices of the early to mid-twentieth century. And looking ahead, this concept will join trashing and pretexting as tools to help us illuminate the contemporary practice of masspersonal social engineering.

扯淡是社会工程学的核心行为。这是社会工程师与目标接触时会发生的事。社会工程师需要诋毁目标，并了解他们所能了解的一切。然后，他们可以编造借口——例如，现成的社会刻板印象——他们可以充分体现这些借口，而他们的目标也会认可这些借口。但是，如果社会工程师不会扯淡，那么所有这些准备都将化为乌有。在与目标接触的过程中，社会工程师必须将他们的计划和技术知识付诸实践。这是一个艰难的时刻，是对社会工程师适应能力的考验。在接触过程中，社会工程师依靠一种特殊的、不分真假的欺骗、友好和准确的组合来成功操纵他们的目标。这就是我们所说的扯淡。

Bullshitting is the central act of social engineering. It’s what happens when the social engineer engages with the target. Social engineers need to trash their targets and learn everything they can about them. They then can construct pretexts—for example, ready-to-hand social stereotypes—that they can fully embody and that their targets will recognize. But all of that preparation will be for naught if the social engineer can’t bullshit. There comes a moment when the social engineer must put their plans and technical knowledge to the test during the engagement with the target. This is a difficult moment, a trial of the social engineer’s ability to be adaptive. During the engagement, social engineers rely on a peculiar, truth-indifferent mix of deception, friendliness, and accuracy to successfully manipulate their targets. That is what we mean by bullshit.

要理解胡说八道，我们必须回到那些将胡说八道发展为一种社会工程技术的电话飞客身上。我们将与电话飞客一起认真对待胡说八道，利用哲学和社会学研究的一小部分——胡说八道的意义和用途——来阐明社会工程师在达到目标时会做什么。然后，我们将看看电话飞客胡说八道指南，并认识到胡说八道的本质：一种巧妙的、无视真相的欺骗、准确和友好的混合体。我们将再次采用这个电话飞客和黑客的概念，回顾较早的、大规模的社会工程师，发现他们也是完美的胡说八道者。

To understand bullshitting, we have to return to the phone phreaks who developed bullshitting as a social engineering technique. We’ll join the phreaks in taking bullshit seriously by drawing on a small area of philosophical and sociological inquiry—the meaning and uses of bullshitting—to clarify what social engineers do when they meet their target. We will then take a look at phone phreak bullshitting guides and come to recognize bullshit for what it is: a skillful, truth-indifferent mix of deception, accuracy, and friendliness. We’ll once again take this phreak and hacker concept and look back at the older, mass social engineers and find that they, too, were consummate bullshitters.

关于电话飞客的胡言乱语

On Bullshit with the Phone Phreaks

我们非常感谢电话飞客，他们给我们留下了理论丰富的胡说八道概念。回想一下，电话飞客是 20 世纪 60 年代到 80 年代痴迷于贝尔电话系统的人。为了探索其最远的范围，电话飞客找到了免费拨打长途电话的方法。关于电话飞客的历史和纪录片倾向于强调他们用来探索贝尔系统的技术，尤其是他们的“蓝盒子”，可以产生可以操纵网络的特殊控制音。他们经常因其将电话电路连接在一起的技术能力（这一过程称为串联堆叠）和获取免费长途电话的技能而受到称赞。电话飞客欺骗接线员的社交技巧很少被讨论。

We owe a great deal to the phone phreaks, who bequeathed us the theoretically rich concept of bullshit. Recall that the phone phreaks were people obsessed with the Bell telephone system in the 1960s through the 1980s. In order to explore its furthest reaches, the phreaks found ways to make free long-distance calls. The histories of and documentaries about the phone phreaks tended to emphasize the technologies they used to explore the Bell System, especially their “blue boxes” that could create special control tones that could manipulate the network. They are often lauded for their technical abilities to connect phone circuits together (a process called tandem stacking) and their skills in getting free long-distance calls. Less discussed are the phreaks’ social skills in bullshitting the operator.

最简单的形式是，欺骗是指与电话公司员工（通常是接线员和技术人员）交谈，以操纵他们为电话飞客做某事或让电话飞客获得重要的内部信息。这是社会工程的核心活动。例如，电话飞客可能会欺骗接线员，并说服接线员将电话飞客连接到一条特殊电话线路，以便电话飞客可以免费拨打长途电话。另一个电话飞客可能会欺骗电话技术人员，以了解新的交换系统是如何工作的。

In its simplest form, bullshitting involves talking to telephone company employees, typically operators and technicians, in order to manipulate them into doing something for the phreak or giving the phreak access to vital internal information. This is the central activity of social engineering. A phreak might bullshit an operator, for example, and convince the operator to connect the phreak to a special phone line so that the phreak can make free long-distance calls. Another phreak might bullshit a phone technician in order to learn how a new switching system works.

为了达到效果，电话飞客的胡说八道需要大量准确的技术知识——电话飞客在电话公司办公室外的垃圾箱里寻找垃圾时会找到这种知识。但当然，胡说八道是欺骗性的：电话飞客经常会使用借口，比如是贝尔公司的同事。然而，当电话飞客试图欺骗接线员时，他们并不残忍；事实上，他们非常友好。胡说八道远非简单：它是欺骗、善良和技术精湛的复杂组合，所有这些都融入了精心策划的人际操纵中。

To be effective, phone phreak bullshitting required a lot of accurate, technical knowledge—the sort of thing the phreaks would find during trashing runs in the dumpsters outside telephone company offices. But, of course, bullshitting was deceptive: the phreaks would often use pretexts, such as being a fellow Bell employee. And yet, the phreaks weren’t cruel when they sought to deceive operators; in fact, they were downright friendly. Bullshitting then was far from simple: it was a complex mix of deception, kindness, and technical mastery, all brought together in calculated, interpersonal manipulation.

尽管这个词听起来很粗鲁，但当电话飞客称他们的活动是胡说八道时，他们还是发现了一些问题。毕竟，我们的社会充满了胡说八道者，这引起了严肃的学术思想家的注意。从这项学术分析中得出了两种看似截然不同的胡说八道概念。一方面，胡说八道是一种严酷、危险、操纵性的做法，它破坏了人们对机构的信任，欺骗了观众。另一方面，胡说八道是一种允许身份扮演、社会实验和友爱的社会实践。正如我们将看到的，当我们考虑电话飞客的胡说八道以及各种形式的社会工程时，这两种观点都是成立的。在社会工程师的手中，这两个概念融合成了一种创造性的、无视真相的欺骗、准确的知识和社交能力的混合体。

Despite the term sounding crude, the phreaks were onto something when they called their engagements bullshit. After all, our society is full of bullshitters, and this has attracted the attention of serious academic thinkers. What emerges from this scholarly analysis are two seemingly distinct conceptions of bullshitting. On the one hand, bullshitting is a harsh, dangerous, manipulative practice that undermines trust in institutions and deceives the audience. On the other, bullshitting is a social practice that allows for identity-play, social experimentation, and camaraderie. As we will see, both of these perspectives will hold when we consider phone phreak bullshitting as well as social engineering in all its forms. In the hands of social engineers, both of these conceptions merge in a creative, truth-indifferent mix of deception, accurate knowledge, and sociability.

胡说八道是对真相的漠视

Bullshitting as Indifference to Truth

自 20 世纪 80 年代中期以来，有一小部分哲学家开始发展一套关于胡说八道的理论，该理论与谎言、说真话和欺骗有关。这些争论非常激烈，涉及许多重要问题，包括如何识别胡说八道、如何区分胡说​​八道和说谎、以及胡说八道在当代社会的程度。这批胡说八道哲学家的领袖是哈里·法兰克福，他 1986 年的热门论文《论胡说八道》（2005 年重新出版成为畅销书）引发了关于胡说八道在当代美国文化中的定义、实践和程度的争论。

Since the mid-1980s, there has been a small but robust group of philosophers developing a theory of bullshitting as it relates to lying, truth-telling, and deception. The debates are lively and address many important questions, including how to identify bullshitting, distinguishing bullshitting from lying, and considering the extent of bullshitting in contemporary society. The dean of this school of philosophers of bullshit is Harry Frankfurt, whose popular 1986 essay (republished in 2005 as a bestselling book), On Bullshit, kicked off the debate about the definition, practices, and extent of bullshitting in contemporary American culture.

《论胡说》中被引用最多的一句话可能是法兰克福关于“胡说的本质”的观点：胡说本质上是“缺乏对真相的关注……对事情的真相漠不关心”。3对于法兰克福来说，胡说比撒谎危险得多，因为至少撒谎者关心真相或事情的真相——即使他们想告诉我们与真相相反的东西。相反，胡说是对真相或虚假的漠不关心。法兰克福认为：“除非一个人认为自己知道真相，否则他不可能撒谎。而胡说八道则不需要这样的信念。” 4因此，胡说八道者

Perhaps the most quoted line from On Bullshit is Frankfurt’s point about the “essence of bullshit”: bullshit is essentially a “lack of connection to a concern with truth . . . [an] indifference to how things really are.”3 For Frankfurt, bullshitting is far more dangerous than lying, because at least the liar is concerned with the truth or how things really are—even if they want to tell us the opposite of the truth. Instead, bullshitting is indifference towards truth or falsity. “It is impossible for someone to lie unless he thinks he knows the truth,” Frankfurt argues. “Producing bullshit requires no such conviction.”4 Thus, the bullshitter

既不站在真一边，也不站在假一边。他的眼睛根本不盯着事实，而诚实的人和撒谎者的眼睛却盯着事实，除非这些事实可能与他逃避惩罚的利益有关。他不在乎自己说的话是否正确地描述了现实。他只是挑选它们，或者编造它们，以达到他的目的。5

is neither on the side of the true nor on the side of the false. His [sic] eye is not on the facts at all, as the eyes of the honest man and of the liar are, except insofar as they may be pertinent to his interest in getting away with what he says. He does not care whether the things he says describe reality correctly. He just picks them out, or makes them up, to suit his purpose.5

归根结底，对于法兰克福来说，胡说八道者的目的是欺骗我们，让我们误以为他们的真实意图。他举的一个关键例子很容易理解：政客滔滔不绝地吹嘘我们光荣的国家和上帝给予它的特殊祝福。法兰克福认为，这位政客并不关心真假，而更关心我们对他们作为敬畏上帝的爱国者的印象。从这个意义上说，胡说八道的这一方面与我们在上一章中对借口识别的讨论产生了共鸣。胡说八道者可以依靠刻板印象和其他容易识别的社会习俗作为欺骗性的掩护。

Ultimately, for Frankfurt, the bullshitter’s purpose is to deceive us as to their true intentions. One of his key examples is readily understandable: the politician who blusters on and on about our Glorious Country and its Special Blessings from God. This politician, Frankfurt argues, is far less concerned about true and false and far more concerned about our impressions of them as a God-fearing patriot. In this sense, this aspect of bullshit resonates with our discussion of recognition of pretexts in the previous chapter. Bullshitters can rely upon stereotypes and other easily recognized social practices as a deceptive cover.

法兰克福最初将胡说八道定义为对真假漠不关心，但其他几位哲学家对此提出了质疑，他们提出了反例，并就人们可能关心真相但仍在胡说八道的情况提出了技术论据。6这场争论的范围超出了本章的范围，但对于我们考虑社会工程师中的胡说八道的目的而言，对法兰克福理论的一种修改非常有用。它来自哲学家安德烈亚斯·斯托克和唐·法利斯，他们将法兰克福对真假漠不关心的论点修改为对真假的探究漠不关心。7正如他们所解释的那样，

Frankfurt’s initial definition of bullshitting as an indifference to truth or falsity has been challenged by several other philosophers who develop counterexamples and offer technical arguments about situations where one might care about truth but still be bullshitting.6 The extent of this debate is beyond the scope of this chapter, but for our purpose of considering bullshitting among social engineers, one modification of Frankfurt’s theory is quite useful. It comes from the philosophers Andreas Stokke and Don Fallis, who modify Frankfurt’s indifference to truth or falsity thesis into indifference towards the inquiry into what is true or what is false.7 As they explain,

我们认为胡说八道是一种对回答[正在讨论的问题]的真假漠不关心的言语方式。对真相或胡说八道现象的虚假性并不是对自己所说内容的真实性漠不关心，而是对自己的贡献对话语的影响漠不关心。8

We characterize bullshitting as a mode of speech marked by indifference toward contributing true or false answers to [questions under discussion]. The kind of indifference toward truth or falsity that characterizes the phenomenon of bullshitting is not indifference toward the truth-value of what one says, but indifference toward the effect that one’s contributions have on the discourse.8

因此，对于 Stokke 和 Fallis 来说，胡说八道会破坏对真相的探究，因为这种探究是在他们称之为“正在讨论的问题”的特定对话情境中进行的。这些正在讨论的问题可能是这样的：公共汽车什么时候到？外面天气怎么样？你有很多家庭作业要做吗？撒谎者会知道真相并说出相反的话，诚实的人会尽其所能如实回答（包括说他们不知道答案），而胡说八道者只是发表声明，无意将讨论引向真相。相反，胡说八道者更感兴趣的是印象管理：也许是回避问题，隐藏真实意图，试图表现出友好但实际上不感兴趣，等等。因此，对于 Stokke 和 Fallis 来说，“胡说八道者做出了贡献，却不关心他们对特定子查询的影响。” 9

For Stokke and Fallis, then, bullshitting undermines the inquiry towards truth as this inquiry plays out in specific conversational situations they call “questions under discussion.” These questions under discussion might be things like: when does the bus arrive? What’s the weather like outside? Do you have much homework to do? Whereas a liar would know the truth and tell its opposite, and the honest person would simply answer truthfully to the best of their ability (including saying they don’t know the answer), the bullshitter simply makes statements with no intention of moving the discussion toward truth. Instead, the bullshitter is more interested in impression management: perhaps evading the question, hiding true intentions, trying to appear friendly while really being uninterested, or the like. Thus, for Stokke and Fallis, “the bullshitter makes contributions while not caring about their effect on particular subinquiries.”9

抛开关于定义的争论，如果法兰克福、斯托克和法利斯对胡说八道的概念化有任何缺陷，那就是他们低估了胡说八道者胡说八道所带来的风险。谁在乎政客是夸夸其谈，还是一个人在毫无证据的情况下胡说八道？但是，正如犯罪学家丹尼尔·米尔斯所指出的那样，胡说八道可以成为剥削和操纵的一部分：“胡说八道可以提供一种影响或控制对现实的看法的手段，进而提供一种实现特定社会、政治和经济目标的手段。” 10当我们考虑社会工程时，这一点尤其重要。

Setting aside the debates about definitions, if there is anything to fault in Frankfurt, Stokke, and Fallis’s conceptualizations of bullshitting, it is that they underplay what is at stake when bullshitters bullshit. Who cares if the politician bloviates or the person bullshits about the weather with no evidence? But, as criminologist Daniel Mears notes, bullshitting can be part of exploitation and manipulation: “Bullshitting can provide a means by which to influence or control perceptions of reality and in turn with a means to achieve specific social, political, and economic goals.”10 This point is especially important when we consider social engineering.

射牛

Shooting the Bull

但在我们转向社会工程师的工具性、操纵性沟通目标之前，我们应该考虑更多胡说八道的社交含义，可以在“shooting the bull”或“bullshit session”等短语中看到。

But before we turn to the instrumental, manipulative communication goals of social engineers, we ought to consider the more sociable connotations of bullshitting, found in phrases like “shooting the bull” or “bullshit session.”

也许对胡说八道这一内涵最深入的思考，来自传播学和社会学学者 Chandra Mukerji 在 20 世纪 70 年代末对搭便车者的研究。正如近十年后法兰克福所指出的那样，Mukerji 认为，对真相的漠视是胡说八道的一个关键特征。但 Mukerji 并不认为胡说八道纯粹是危险的，而是将其视为一种社交行为：“真假不是胡说八道的问题，因为这种谈话方式很有趣；这是一种让谈话更有趣的方式。” 11她认为，搭便车者进行有趣的胡说八道是为了重建他们的经历，从而将自己塑造成“公路故事”中的英雄。这些故事将搭便车者描绘成“世故的”，他们“有足够的胆量、勇气、耐力和朋友在路上‘成功’。” 12此外，搭便车者的听众——通常是搭便车者或搭载他们的人——与这些故事息息相关。他们的故事被讲给那些“对美化旅途生活有既得利益”的人听。13鉴于这些故事是通过口头方式讲给陌生人听的，它们可能会在之后被遗忘或否认，从而降低了真实性的价值，而更加强调了这些胡说八道的社交性和娱乐性。

Perhaps the most extensive consideration of this connotation of bullshitting is in communication and sociology scholar Chandra Mukerji’s late 1970s work on hitchhikers. Much as Frankfurt would note almost a decade later, Mukerji argues that an indifference to truth is a key feature of bullshitting. But rather than see it as purely dangerous, Mukerji sees it as a sociable practice: “truth and falsehood are not issues in bullshitting because this kind of talk is playful; it is a way to make conversation more fun.”11 Hitchhikers, she argues, engage in playful bullshitting in order to reconstruct their experiences and hence themselves as heroes in “road stories.” These stories present the hitchhiker as “worldly” with “enough guts, daring, endurance and friends to ‘make it’ on the road.”12 Moreover, the hitchhiker’s audience—typically fellow hitchhikers or the people giving them rides—have a stake in such stories. Their stories are told to others who “have vested interests in glamourizing life on the road.”13 Given that these are stories vocally told to strangers, the stories could be forgotten or denied later, reducing the truth-value stakes while placing more emphasis on the sociable, entertaining qualities of the bullshit.

犯罪学学者米尔斯进一步发展了胡说八道的社交和身份扮演方面，指出胡说八道的主要功能包括社交、探索自我、表达感受和消磨时间。正如米尔斯所说，“对于那些精通胡说八道艺术的人来说，他们有能力定义自己并实现特定目标。” 14因此，除了搭便车故事之外，我们可以想象许多社交场合，在这些场合中，真假被放在一边，取而代之的是可信但尖锐的对话，从钓鱼故事到酒吧故事，再到学术会议的走廊谈话。

The criminology scholar Mears develops this sociable, identity-play aspect of bullshitting further, noting that key functions of bullshitting include socializing, exploring the self, expressing feelings, and passing time. As Mears notes, “To those well-versed in the art of bullshitting, there is an ability to define oneself and to achieve particular goals.”14 Thus, beyond hitchhiking road stories, we can imagine many social settings in which truth or falsehood are set aside in favor of plausible yet edgy conversation, from fishing stories to barroom tales to hallway talk at academic conferences.

为了把这两股潮流——对探究真理的冷漠和“胡说八道”的社会性——结合起来，我们可以回到法兰克福。具体来说，法兰克福注意到了胡说八道的艺术性和创造性，也就是“胡说八道艺术家”这个词的含义。他解释说，

To draw these two streams together—the indifference to inquiry towards truth and the sociability of “shooting the bull”—we can return to Frankfurt. Specifically, Frankfurt notes the artistry and creativity of bullshitting, connoted in the phrase “bullshit artist.” As he explains,

一个用胡说八道来解决问题的人比撒谎者自由得多。他的注意力是全面的，而不是具体的。他不局限于在某个特定点插入某种谎言，因此他不受围绕该点或与其相交的真相的约束。只要有必要，他也准备伪造背景。这种摆脱撒谎者必须服从的约束的自由当然并不一定意味着他的任务比撒谎者的任务更容易。但它所依赖的创造力模式比撒谎时调动的创造力模式更少分析性和更少深思熟虑。它更广阔、更独立，有更多即兴发挥、色彩和想象力的机会。这与其说是手艺问题，不如说是艺术问题。因此，人们熟悉的“胡说八道艺术家”这个概念。15

A person who undertakes to bullshit his way through has much more freedom [than the liar]. His [sic] focus is panoramic rather than particular. He does not limit himself to inserting a certain falsehood at a specific point, and thus he is not constrained by the truths surrounding that point or intersecting it. He is prepared, so far as required, to fake the context as well. This freedom from the constraints to which the liar must submit does not necessarily mean, of course, that his task is easier than the task of the liar. But the mode of creativity upon which it relies is less analytical and less deliberative than that which is mobilized in lying. It is more expansive and independent, with more spacious opportunities for improvisation, color, and imaginative play. This is less a matter of craft than of art. Hence the familiar notion of the “bullshit artist.”15

对于法兰克福来说，胡说八道既好玩又危险，既善于交际又具有颠覆性，既有创意又狡猾。这种艺术方法可以满足穆克吉所确定的目的：娱乐、创作有趣的故事、建立关系和培育社区。正如米尔斯、斯托克和法利斯所观察到的，它还可以用来破坏追求真理的动力。事实上，真相并不是重点。

For Frankfurt, bullshitting is playful and dangerous, sociable and subversive, creative and cunning. Such an artistic approach can serve the purposes Mukerji identified: to have fun, create entertaining stories, build relationships, and foster community. It can also be used to undermine a drive towards truth, as Mears, Stokke, and Fallis observed. Truth, indeed, is beside the point.

极其准确的胡说八道

Exquisitely Accurate Bullshit

然而，我们必须强调，扯淡不是撒谎。它不是简单地说出事实的反面。事实上，扯淡往往涉及细节、事实和论据的正确性——至少在它们对扯淡者有利的范围内。法兰克福指出，广告和政治等整个行业，并指出

And yet, we must emphasize that bullshitting is not lying. It is not the simple telling of the opposite of the truth. In fact, bullshitting often involves getting details, facts, and arguments right—at least to the extent that they serve the bullshitter. Frankfurt points to entire industries, such as advertising and politics, and notes the

精湛技艺的工匠借助先进而严苛的市场调研、民意调查、心理测试等技术，孜孜不倦地致力于使他们创作的每一个 [废话] 单词和图像都准确无误。16

exquisitely sophisticated craftsmen who—with the help of advanced and demanding techniques of market research, of public opinion polling, of psychological testing, and so forth—dedicate themselves tirelessly to getting every [bullshit] word and image they produce exactly right.16

事实上，关心废话——让废话恰到好处——反映了“准确性”的古老含义：源自拉丁语accuratia，即“关心、注意”。废话往往需要大量的基础研究和规划：当对目标进行广泛研究、充分理解目标语言、精心调整信息以达到目标时，废话效果最好。（否则，为什么会有电话飞客或黑客跳进垃圾箱？）

Indeed, the idea of caring for the bullshit—for getting it just right—reflects an older meaning of “accuracy”: from the Latin accuratia, or “care, attention.” The underlying research and planning that bullshitting often requires is tremendous: bullshitting works best when the target is extensively studied, the language of the target is fully understood, and the messaging is carefully calibrated to reach that target. (Otherwise, why would any phreak or hacker jump into dumpsters?)

和法兰克福一样，穆克吉观察到搭便车者很在意他们提供的胡说八道。他们讲述的关于旅途危险的故事必须“可信……过于夸张会让故事不可信。” 17可信度取决于将胡说八道的故事与观众的经历进行清晰的表达。准确的故事是与观众自己对旅途生活的理解产生共鸣的故事；不一致意味着讲故事者的胡说八道会被揭穿。

Like Frankfurt, Mukerji observed hitchhikers caring for the bullshit they provided. Their stories of the dangers of the road must be “plausible . . . too much exaggeration can make the story implausible.”17 Plausibility relies upon articulating the bullshit story with the audience’s experiences. An accurate story is one that resonates with the audience’s own understanding of life on the road; a misalignment means that storyteller’s bullshit is called out.

因此，事实很重要——即使是在胡说八道的故事中。胡说八道者所作的贡献可能是真实的陈述、准确的信息或欺骗——关键在于，这种谎言和真相的混合是对对话的理解目的的漠视。在欺骗接线员的情况下，电话飞客不是用纯粹的谎言来破坏接线员“正在讨论的问题”，而是用精心混合的准确信息和欺骗来掩盖电话飞客的意图。

Thus, facts can matter—even in a bullshit story. The bullshitter’s contributions can be true statements, accurate information, or deception—the point is that this mix of lies and truth are made with indifference to the understood purposes of the conversation. In the case of bullshitting the operator, the phone phreaks undermine the operator’s “questions under discussion” not with pure lies but with a careful mix of accurate information and deception that covers up the phreaks’ intentions.

欺骗操作员：最佳实践

Bullshitting the Operator: Best Practices

在这里，我们要回报我们的恩人——电话飞客，他们慷慨地给我们提供了丰富的废话概念。

Here, we want to return to our benefactors, the phone phreaks, who generously gave us the rich concept of bullshit.

胡扯的概念分为三部分：对真相的探究漠不关心、一种好玩、善于交际的行为以及对信息的关心和关注，这又回到了电话飞客指南中对接线员的胡扯。这些指南可以可以在一系列地下杂志文章（例如2600和TAP）、计算机公告板系统 (BBS) 帖子和（在较小程度上）出现在 20 世纪 70 年代末到 80 年代中期的主流媒体文章中找到。这些指南揭示了电话飞客胡说八道的精妙技艺，它结合了欺骗、社交和正确做法。他们展示了胡说八道如何放大社会工程师的欺骗性借口，为什么友好是社会工程师的最佳选择，以及如何使用在破坏过程中收集的术语。这些实践是当代大规模个人社会工程实践的前身，它们也为旧式的大规模社会工程提供了新的启示。

The three-fold conceptualization of bullshitting as an indifference towards the inquiry into truth, a playful, sociable practice, and an act of care and attention to information, maps back onto the phone phreak guides to bullshitting the operator. These guides can be found in a range of underground magazine articles (such as 2600 and TAP), computer Bulletin Board System (BBS) posts, and (to a lesser extent) mainstream press articles appearing in the late 1970s to mid-1980s. These guides reveal the exquisitely sophisticated craft of phone phreak bullshitting as a mix of deception, sociability, and getting it right. They demonstrate how bullshitting can amplify the social engineer’s deceptive pretexts, why being friendly is the social engineer’s best bet, and how to use the lingo gathered during trashing. These practices are precursors to contemporary, masspersonal social engineering practices, and they also throw new light on the older mass social engineering.

欺骗：借口

Deception: Pretexting

电话飞客的胡说八道指南经常建议，想要胡说八道的人在打电话给接线员之前先想出一个合理的角色。当然，这种做法最终会正式化，被称为“借口”，尽管电话飞客自己并没有使用这个词。借口让胡说八道的飞客在寻求信息或访问权时占据优势，因为它们为后续对话奠定了基础。

Phone phreak guides to bullshitting often recommend that the would-be bullshitter come up with a plausible role to play before calling up the Bell operator. This is of course the practice that would eventually become formalized and referred to as “pretexting,” although the phreaks themselves did not use that term. Pretexts give the bullshitting phreak an advantage as they seek information or access, because they set the stage for the subsequent conversation.

指南中对头衔和向接线员介绍自己的方式进行了非常具体的说明。TAP 的早期指南建议使用一些借口，比如是同事接线员或贝尔安全员工。18一个 BBS 指南的标题很神秘，叫做“飞天企鹅呈现：欺骗接线员”，它提供了更多的角色供大家扮演。当欺骗接线员时，飞天企鹅建议我们，“我们必须来自电话公司。” 19为此，指南列出了飞客可以采用的头衔，包括

The guides get quite specific about titles and ways to introduce oneself to the operator. An early guide in TAP recommends pretexts such as being a fellow operator or Bell security employee.18 A BBS guide with the enigmatic title “Flying Penguin Presents: Bullshitting the Operator” provides even more roles to play. When bullshitting an operator, Flying Penguin advises us, “we must be from the phone company.”19 To that end, the guide offers a list of titles the phreak could adopt, including

  • • 收费服务维护工程师
  • • Toll service maintenance engineer
  • • 车站维修
  • • Station repair
  • • 有线 MTCE 技术员
  • • Cable MTCE technician
  • • TSPS 维护/维护管理员
  • • TSPS maintenance/maintenance administrator
  • • 中央办公室主管
  • • Central Office Supervisor
  • • TSPS 安全[，和]
  • • TSPS Security[, and]
  • • 收费服务维护。20
  • • Toll Service Maintenance.20

除了角色之外，指南还提供脚本。TAP 中的指南提供了与客户姓名和地址 (CN/A) 接线员交谈的脚本：

Beyond roles, the guides offer scripts. A guide in TAP provides a script for talking to Customer Name and Address (CN/A) operators:

嗨，我是帕萨迪纳住宅服务中心的吉姆。我有一个客户在等着，他声称没有打过一个相当长的电话给 (212) 555-1212，所以我需要客户的名字。电话号码是 (212) 555-1212。​​21

Hi, this is Jim with the Residence Service Center in Pasadena. I’ve got a customer on hold who claims not to have made a rather lengthy call to (212) 555-1212, so I need the customer’s name on that please. That was (212) 555-1212.21

同样，《夏普 Remob 欺骗电话公司获取重要信息的指南》建议致电接线员并说：“您好，我是维修人员 Bob Dwyer，请问 555-2344 上有订单活动吗？” 22

Likewise, “Sharp Remob’s Guide to Bullshitting the Phone Company Out of Important Information” suggests calling the operator and saying, “Hi, this is Bob Dwyer with repair, do you show any order activity on 555–2344?”22

借口是电话飞客胡说八道中最明显的欺骗性方面。回到哲学家斯托克和法利斯的话题，电话飞客声称自己不是别人，这完全破坏了接线员对真相的具体调查。可以说，使用借口是一种谎言，甚至可能是奥古斯丁的谎言：电话飞客非常清楚他们不是他们自称的那个人。接线员接听电话的目的是帮助贝尔公司的同事或客户，电话飞客非常乐意在调查期间保持这种幻觉，以便获取信息或其他资源。但即使是最好的借口，如果没有胡说八道的其他元素，包括提供一点友好，也无法发挥作用。

Pretexing is the most clearly deceptive aspect of phone phreak bullshitting. To return to the philosophers Stokke and Fallis, a phreak claiming to be someone they are not completely undermines the specific inquiry into truth undertaken by the operator. Arguably, the use of a pretext is a lie, maybe even an Augustinian lie: the phreak knows perfectly well they are not who they claim to be. The operator answers the phone with the intention of helping a fellow Bell employee or customer, and the phone phreak is only too happy to maintain this illusion during the inquiry in order to gain access to information or other resources. But even the best pretext cannot function without other elements of bullshitting—including offering a bit of friendliness.

友善

Being Friendly

为了操纵或获取更多信息而欺骗一个天真的操作员或毫无头绪的技术人员，这听起来很残酷。这是欺骗性地漠视真相或谎言的内涵的一部分。然而，回到欺骗的愉快一面（正如我们在 Mukerji 的研究中看到的）在被称为“搭便车者”的电话飞客看来，他们不仅操纵接线员，而且对接线员很友好。

Bullshitting an otherwise naive operator or clueless technician in order to manipulate them or gain even more information sounds pretty harsh. This is part and parcel of the connotation of bullshitting as deceptive indifference to truth or falsity. However, returning to the jovial side of bullshitting (as we saw in Mukerji’s study of hitchhikers), the phone phreaks did not just manipulate the operators; they were friendly to them.

TAP上的一篇文章提醒读者“接线员也是人，你知道的。所以一定要有礼貌，好好利用他们，小心拨号。” 23同样，Flying Penguin 的“欺骗接线员”指南提醒电话飞客“一定要说谢谢！” 24另一个电话飞客建议听起来“友好而自然” 。25

An article in TAP reminds the reader that “operators are people too, y’know. So always be polite, make good use of ‘em, and dial with care.”23 Likewise, the Flying Penguin’s “bullshitting the operator” guide reminds phreaks to “always say thank you!”24 Another phreak recommends sounding “friendly and natural.”25

在一份罕见的实际社会工程活动记录中，可以看到友好性如何发挥作用。在 1994 年的第一届 HOPE 黑客大会上，一名自称 SN 的黑客在观众面前致电 Sprint，希望获得客户姓名和地址 (CN/A) 电话号码 - 只有 Sprint 员工才有权访问的电话号码。他欺骗了 Sprint 接线员 Deborah Brown (DB)。

An illustration of how friendliness functions can be seen in one of the rare recordings of an actual social engineering engagement available. In front of an audience at the first HOPE hacker conference in 1994, a hacker going by the handle SN calls Sprint, looking to get a Customer Name and Address (CN/A) telephone number—a phone number that only Sprint employees should have access to. He bullshits a Sprint operator, Deborah Brown (DB).

DB： Sprint 客户服务部，我是 Deborah Brown，请问我能为您做些什么？

DB: Sprint Customer Service, this is Deborah Brown speaking, and how may I help you?

SN：嘿，黛博拉，最近怎么样？

SN: Hey, Deborah, how’s it going?

DB：没问题。

DB: It’s fine.

SN：我是 Spring Social Engineering 的 Bob Dwyer，你好吗？

SN: This is Bob Dwyer, over at Spring Social Engineering, how you doing?

DB：我很好。你呢？

DB: I’m fine. And yourself?

SN：非常好，你知道，这就是那样的日子之一。

SN: Pretty good, you know, it’s one of those days.

DB：好的。

DB: Okay.

SN：嗯，您碰巧有处理 313 的 CN/A 号码吗？那是密歇根州的。

SN: Umm, you wouldn’t happen to have the number for the CN/A that handles 313? That’s Michigan.

DB：我想是的……请稍等一下。（哼唱，敲击电脑键盘）

DB: I think so . . . just a moment. (humming, computer keyboard tapping)

SN：那么，你们今天那边忙吗？

SN: So, you guys busy over there today?

DB：我们之前确实很忙。

DB: We were real busy earlier.

SN：是的，我完全明白你的意思。

SN: Yeah, I know exactly what you mean.

DB：好的，是 313……

DB: Ok, it’s 313 . . .

SN：嗯嗯。

SN: Mm huh.

数据库： 424...

DB: 424 . . .

SN：嗯嗯。

SN: Uh huh.

数据库： 0900。

DB: 0900.

SN：好的……好吧。嘿！你们那边有 CIS 吗？

SN: OK. . . . Alright. Hey! Is CIS up for you guys over there?

DB：是的。

DB: Yes.

SN：是吗？因为我们一直遇到很多问题，从 CIS 到交换机的数据丢失，而且 TC 处理得也不是很好。您显示的最后一个帐户是什么？嗯，您处理的是什么？

SN: Yeah? ‘Cause we’ve been having a lot of problems with data loss from CIS to the switch, and it’s not processing the TCs too well. What do you show is the last account that you, umm, handled or processed?

DB：最后一个帐户？

DB: Last account?

SN：是的。

SN: Yeah.

DB：嗯...18-

DB: Umm . . . 18–

SN：哦，等一下，我们这里就有。是的，事实上，CIS 刚刚重新上线。

SN: Oh, wait, we have it right here. Yeah, in fact, CIS just came back online for us.

DB：是吗？

DB: Did it?

SN：是的。

SN: Yeah.

DB：哦。

DB: Oh.

SN：嘿！非常感谢你的帮助！

SN: Hey! Thanks a lot for your help!

DB：你做得很棒！

DB: You have a good one!

SN：好的，再见！

SN: Alright, bye-bye!

DB：再见！26

DB: Goodbye!26

SN 非常小心地加入了社交性的话语：“最近怎么样？”，“你们那边忙吗？”，“你过得很好！”他不仅仅是在进行工具性的信息搜寻；他友好的态度和对所谓同事的善意有助于使互动更加顺畅（并且，也许，分散了人们对他大胆自称为“Sprint Social Engineering 的 Bob Dwyer”的注意力）。

SN is very careful to include sociable lines: “how’s it going?”, “you guys busy over there?”, and “you have a good one!” He isn’t just engaged in an instrumental hunt for information; his friendly demeanor and kindness to his supposedly fellow employee helps smooth the interaction (and, perhaps, distracts from his audacious self-identification as “Bob Dwyer from Sprint Social Engineering”).

这种友好态度在工作中对付骗子时是一种很好的策略。正如一篇题为“官方电话诈骗者手册”的 BBS 帖子所解释的那样，

Such friendliness is a great tactic when bullshitting targets at work. As a BBS post titled “The Official Phreaker’s Manual” explains,

大多数贝尔员工都很乐意与人交谈。记住，他们通常与不满的客户打交道，抱怨不已。他们的配偶可能会对他们大喊大叫，他们的主管要么抱怨他们的表现，要么对他们置之不理。整个社会根本不在乎他们。他们很可能对整个世界感到失望，甚至可能对自己的工作不满意。有机会与一个只想听他们说话的人交谈是一个可喜的变化。他们会滔滔不绝地谈论几乎任何事情，从电信到他们的家庭生活和童年。社会工程的可能性是无穷无尽的。记住，贝尔员工也是人。你所要做的就是倾听。27

Most Bell employees are really glad to talk to someone. Remember, they usually interact with disgruntled customers with complaints. Their spouses probably yell at them, and their supervisors either complain about their performance or ignore them. Society at large just doesn’t care about them. They’re most probably disenchanted with the world at large, and maybe even dissatisfied with their jobs. The chance to talk to some one who merely wants to listen to what they say is a welcome change. They will talk on and on about almost anything, from telecommunications to their home life and their childhood. The possibilities for social engineering are endless. Remember, Bell employees are humans, too. All you have to do is listen.27

穆克吉在搭便车的人中观察到，这是社交意义上的“胡说八道”。在冷漠的公司环境中，友好、有点情谊会让互动更顺畅，信息流动更自由。

This is bullshitting in the social, “shooting the bull” sense that Mukerji observed among the hitchhikers. Friendliness, a bit of camaraderie in a cold, corporate setting makes the interactions smoother and the information flow more freely.

但是，劝告友好可能不仅仅关乎人性和同情心，还关乎提高电话飞客对贝尔系统的控制。TAP的一篇关于对 CN/A 接线员进行胡说八道的文章指出了友好的效用：“当员工（即电话飞客）听起来自然而愉快时，CN/A 接线员不会问任何问题。” 28因此，在这里，友好不仅仅是一种礼貌；它有助于胡说八道，因为它可以将电话飞客在欢乐和善良的背后非法获取信息的意图掩盖起来。这反映了研究欺骗的传播研究人员的发现：友好与“诚实”的举止有关，不管友好的人说的是不是实话。29友好的胡说八道可以避免打扰别人。

But the admonition to be friendly may not be as much about humanity and compassion as it is about improving the phreaks’ control over the Bell System. A TAP article on bullshitting CN/A operators notes the utility of friendliness: “When the employee [read: phone phreak] sounds natural and cheery, the CN/A operator doesn’t ask any questions.”28 Here, being friendly is thus more than mere politeness; it helps the bullshitting operation by covering up the phreak’s intentions to gain illicit access to information behind a cloud of joviality and kindness. This reflects something that communication researchers who study deception have found: friendliness is associated with “honest” demeanor, whether or not the friendly person is telling the truth.29 Friendly bullshit keeps intrusive questions at bay.

此外，友好还具有副作用，即为将来的电话飞客保留了胡说八道的可能性。正如一位电话飞客所建议的那样，

Moreover, friendliness has the side effect of helping preserve bullshitting possibilities for future phone phreak use. As one phone phreak advises,

如果你搞砸了，或者电话公司的员工不合作，你不应该发脾气，骂他们或辱骂他们。这只会助长这些部门在工程方面的破坏。30

You SHOULDN’T, if you screw up, or if the phone co. employees are uncooperative, break down and swear at them or call them names. This will only contribute to the destruction of these departments for engineering purposes.30

同样，一份罕见的电话飞客面对面胡说八道指南描述了如何参观贝尔中央办公室，并敦促任何参与此类参观的人“一定要留下好印象，以便其他电信爱好者将来可以参观这个地方。” 31

Likewise, a rare guide to in-person phone phreak bullshitting describes how to get a tour of a Bell Central Office and urges anyone who engages in such a tour to “Make sure to leave a good impression so that fellow telecommunications hobbyists can tour the place in the future.”31

准确性：使用术语

Accuracy: Using the Lingo

然而，友好的语气只能让你走这么远。当电话飞客假装是电信公司同事时尤其如此。只有当电话飞客了解贝尔系统语言时，这种角色才有可能。电话飞客的胡说八道指南非常强调学习贝尔系统术语并准确使用它。

However, a friendly tone will only take you so far. This is especially the case when the phreak is pretexting as a fellow telco employee. Such a role is only possible if a phreak knows the Bell System language. The bullshitting guides of the phreaks heavily stress learning the Bell system lingo and using it accurately.

例如，1974 年的一本关于如何欺骗一类特殊电话接线员的指南解释说，了解行话会在与这些接线员打交道时产生一种“真实感”。32在这里，“真实”意味着使用正确的术语，例如这些建议的台词：“我是 4-A 17-C 测试板上的 Phil Donehue。我们要进行一些中继线测试，并且需要对 555 办公室进行无测试中继线。” 33用正确的行话对正确的接线员说，这让电话飞客拥有了一种怪异的能力：窃听其他人电话交谈的能力。“事实上，几乎任何拥有正确电话号码和正确说话内容的人都可以通过电话公司电路窃听任何人的电话线。” 34

For example, a 1974 guide to bullshitting a special class of phone operators explains that knowing the lingo lends an “air of authenticity” when dealing with these operators.32 Here, being “authentic” means using the right terms, such as these suggested lines: “This is Phil Donehue on the 4-A 17-C test board. We have some trunk testing to perform and require a no-test trunk for the 555 office.”33 With the right lingo spoken to the right operator, this gives the phreak a, well, freaky ability: the ability to listen to other people’s phone conversations. “The fact is that just about anyone with the right numbers to call and the correct things to say could tap into anyone’s telephone line using telephone company circuits.”34

另一份指南也在一篇关于“费率和路线”接线员（一类特殊的电话接线员）的文章中提出了类似的论点。“[费率和路线]接线员掌握着大量信息，而获取这些数据只需要向她嘟囔一些神秘的短语。” 35该指南继续分享了“神秘的短语”：“号码路线”、“目录路线”、“接线员路线”和“地名”，以命名一些。最全面的电话飞客指南可能是 BIOC 特工 003 的“基础电信课程”，这是 1983 年和 1984 年左右出现在 BBS 上的一系列文本文件。36这些文件包括有关欺骗接线员的信息，这是对电话系统本身的技术术语和细节的更大、更详尽的强调的一部分。该指南解释了破坏和研究的成果如何带来更好的社会工程参与。

Another guide also makes a similar argument in an article on “Rate & Route” operators, a special class of telephone operators. “The [Rate & Route] operator has a myriad of information, and all it takes to get this data is mumbling cryptic phrases at her.”35 The guide goes on to share the “cryptic phrases”: “numbers route,” “directory route,” “operator route,” and “place name,” to name a few. The most extensive phone phreak guide is probably BIOC Agent 003’s “Course in Basic Telecommunications,” a series of text files appearing on BBSs around the years 1983 and 1984.36 These files include information on bullshitting the operator as part of a larger, exhaustive emphasis on the technical terms and details of the phone system itself. The guide explains how the fruits of trashing and research can lead to better social engineering engagements.

正如这些指南所示，电话飞客不遗余力地学习术语并正确使用它们。因此，与借口欺骗相反，电话飞客对术语的使用表明他们在胡说八道过程中谨慎使用准确信息。就像法兰克福的“精湛技艺的工匠”或穆克吉的搭便车者编造了一个似是而非的故事一样，电话飞客努力把事情做好。

As these guides show, the phreaks go to great lengths to learn the terms and use them correctly. Thus, in contrast to the deception of the pretext, the phone phreak’s use of lingo demonstrates the careful use of accurate information during the bullshitting operation. Like Frankfurt’s “exquisitely sophisticated craftsmen” or Mukerji’s hitchhiker who spins a plausible tale, the phreaks work to get things right.

但同样，这些正确信息的部署并不是为了帮助接线员理解调查目标，而是用来掩盖电话飞客的真实意图。如果我们纯粹从“真”和“假”的角度来谈论这些做法——如果我们使用“谎言”或“假新闻”这样的术语——我们可能会说，胡说八道者只关心与沟通效果有关的真相。不管胡说八道者是否知道真相，他们都可能会试图达到足够的逼真度以达到预期的效果。胡说八道者可能不知道或不关心真相，但很可能希望观众至少认为胡说八道是可信的。这就是我们所说的准确性。尽管电话飞客使用电话术语很准确，也很注意把事情说对，但他们仍然是在胡说八道。

But again, these deployments of correct information are not in service of the operator’s understanding of the goals of inquiry, but instead are used to cover up the true intentions of the phreak. If we speak of these practices purely in terms of “true” and “false”—if we use terms like “lies” or “fake news”—we might say that the bullshitter is concerned with truth only so far as it relates to the effectiveness of the communication. Whether the bullshitter is aware of the truth or not, they will likely attempt to achieve verisimilitude sufficient to achieve the desired effect. The bullshitter might not know or care about the truth, but will likely want the audience to at least see the bullshit as plausible. This is what we mean by accuracy. Despite the accuracy of the phreaks’ use of phone lingo, the care and attention paid to getting things just right, they are still bullshitting.

黑客社会工程学中的胡说八道

Bullshitting in Hacker Social Engineering

当今专业化的人际关系黑客社会工程学领域已不再使用“胡说八道”一词。事实上，从不太礼貌的“胡扯”到听起来更专业的“社会工程学”，这种转变发生在 1980 年代到 2010 年代。有时，“胡扯”和“社会工程学”这两个词会同时出现在 BBS 帖子或杂志文章中。但最终，“社会工程学”取代了“胡扯”，成为黑客之间的术语。

The contemporary, professionalized field of interpersonal hacker social engineering no longer uses the term bullshitting. Indeed, the transition from the less polite “bullshitting” to the more professional-sounding “social engineering” occurred in the 1980s through 2010s. Sometimes, the terms “bullshitting” and “social engineering” appeared alongside one another in BBS posts or magazine articles. Eventually, however, “social engineering” replaced “bullshitting” as the term of art among hackers.

当“胡说八道”从词典中删除时，有些东西就消失了。胡说八道是一个绝佳的标签，它描述了当社会工程师离开垃圾/OSINT阶段，在现场测试他们的借口并与人们接触时所发生的事情。黑客社会工程师可能不会称之为胡说八道，但他们是完美的胡说八道艺术家。正如黑客社会工程师凯文·米特尼克所说，“成功的社会工程师具有很强的人际交往能力。他们很有魅力、很有礼貌、很容易被人喜欢——这些社交特质是建立快速融洽关系和信任所必需的。” 37当代社会工程指南，如哈德纳吉、康黑迪或米特尼克的书籍，在电话飞客的旧指南的基础上，加入了角色扮演和欺骗（以编造借口的形式）、准确性（以信息收集和正确使用术语、名称和行话的形式）和友好性的讨论。关于最后一点，约翰尼·朗的《无技术黑客》以他第一次参与实体社会工程学的轶事开篇，当时他的导师建议朗通过装卸码头进入大楼。当朗抗议时——“那里有人！”——他的导师建议他胡扯：“只要看起来像是这里的人就行。向员工打招呼。友好一点。评论一下天气。” 38事实上，专业社会工程师克里斯·哈德纳吉给他的学生的一句非官方座右铭是：“让他们因为见到你而感觉更好。” 39

Something gets lost when “bullshitting” is dropped from the lexicon. Bullshitting is an excellent label for what happens when social engineers leave the trashing/OSINT stage to put their pretexts to the test in the field and engage with people. Hacker social engineers may not call it bullshitting, but they are consummate bullshit artists, nonetheless. As the hacker social engineer Kevin Mitnick puts it, “successful social engineers have strong people skills. They’re charming, polite, and easy to like—social traits needed for establishing rapid rapport and trust.”37 Contemporary social engineering guides, such as the books by Hadnagy, Conheady, or Mitnick, build on the phone phreaks’ older guides by including discussions of role-playing and deception (in the form of developing a pretext), accuracy (in the form of information gathering and getting terms, names, and jargon right), and friendliness. On this last point, Johnny Long’s No Tech Hacking starts with an anecdote about his first physical social engineering engagement, when his mentor suggested Long enter the building via a loading dock. When Long protested—“there’s people there!”—his mentor prescribed bullshitting: “Just look like you belong. Say hello to the employees. Be friendly. Comment on the weather.”38 Indeed, an unofficial motto that professional social engineer Chris Hadnagy offers his students is: “leave them feeling better for having met you.”39

这种从网络飞客那里学来的胡说八道模式主要针对人际操纵。和之前的网络飞客一样，当代的社会工程师可能会使用“语音钓鱼”（“语音”和“网络钓鱼”的混合词）通过电话询问密码。或者他们可能会在电子邮件中使用胡说八道来进行网络钓鱼。当他们亲自潜入目标组织时，他们也会亲自胡说八道。

This mode of bullshitting, adopted from the phreaks, is predominantly aimed at interpersonal manipulation. Like the phreaks before them, contemporary social engineers might use “vishing” (a portmanteau of “voice” and “phishing”) to ask for passwords over the phone. Or they may use bullshit in emails as they phish. And they also bullshit in person when they go to physically penetrate a target organization.

大众社会工程师的胡说八道

Bullshit among the Mass Social Engineers

胡说八道并不局限于网络电话用户和黑客的人际社会工程。

Bullshit isn’t limited to the interpersonal social engineering of phreaks and hackers.

如果说有哪一群社会工程师从未使用过“胡说八道”这个词（至少在印刷品中），那肯定是二十世纪初至中期的大众社会工程师。事实上，他们适应了进步时代对“事实”的强调，这意味着他们会因为通过媒体信息控制人群的技术被称为“胡说八道”而感到愤怒。40电话窃贼和黑客可能对这种粗俗的语言感到满意，但像伯内斯、弗莱施曼或艾维·李这样的大众社会工程师却不满意。

If there’s any group of social engineers who never used the word “bullshit” (at least in print), it’s definitely the mass social engineers of the early to mid-twentieth century. Indeed, their adaptation of the Progressive-era emphasis on “facts” means they would be incensed to have their techniques of controlling crowds through media messages called “bullshit.”40 Phone phreaks and hackers may have been comfortable with such crude language, but not mass social engineers like Bernays, Fleischman, or Ivy Lee.

但正如我们所表明的，“胡说八道”是一个丰富的理论概念。就像飞客和黑客术语“垃圾”一样，大众社会工程师也从未使用过这个词，将胡说八道作为重新审视大众社会工程师活动的视角是有益的。事实上，可以说，哈里·法兰克福在撰写《论胡说八道》一书时就考虑到了他们的同类。他最严厉的谴责是针对营销人员和政治传播者使用胡说八道的行为。

But as we have shown, “bullshit” is a rich theoretical concept. Much like the phreak and hacker term “trashing,” which also was never used by mass social engineers, it’s profitable to take up bullshitting as a lens to reconsider the activities of the mass social engineers. Indeed, arguably Harry Frankfurt had their ilk in mind when he composed his book On Bullshit. His sharpest condemnations are directed at the use of bullshit by marketers and political communicators.

这些谴责似乎有道理。从职业生涯一开始，大众社会工程师艾维·李就一直在兜售胡说八道。1914 年，他被实业家约翰·D·洛克菲勒二世雇佣，代表洛克菲勒家族进行辩护。洛克菲勒家族投资的一家矿业公司雇佣了一支武装民兵，以破坏当年早些时候的工会罢工。民兵屠杀了科罗拉多州拉德洛镇的工会成员，包括试图躲在帐篷下躲避民兵的妇女和儿童，但罢工破坏者放火烧死了他们。41这一事件现在被称为拉德洛大屠杀。

And those condemnations seem justified. From the start of his career, mass social engineer Ivy Lee peddled bullshit. In 1914, he was hired by the industrialist John D. Rockefeller, Jr., to advocate on behalf of the family after a mining company the Rockefellers had invested in paid an armed militia to break a union strike earlier that year. The militia slaughtered union members in the town of Ludlow, Colorado, including women and children who tried to hide from the militia under a tent, but were killed when the tent was set on fire by the strike-breakers.41 The event is now known as the Ludlow Massacre.

洛克菲勒家族不需要更多的负面宣传；多亏了揭丑记者艾达·塔贝尔 (Ida Tarbell) 的工作，他们已经因为拥有贪婪成性的标准石油公司 (Standard Oil Corporation) 而遭到诽谤。42他们参与了血腥的、机枪扫射的、焚烧帐篷的、破坏工会的行动，这对他们的声誉没有帮助。为了洗清洛克菲勒的名声，李向“全国各地的意见领袖：‘政府官员、编辑、牧师、教师以及知名的专业人士和商人’”发送了数以万计的公告和小册子。43这些公告被认为是探索“争取工业自由的斗争”的公报，其中包括有关科罗拉多州煤矿开采的无害事实，旨在让人们了解该行业。它们还包括旨在玷污工会和罢工者的材料。正如媒体研究学者斯图尔特·埃文 (Stuart Ewen) 所指出的那样，李在报道有关该行业的准确事实时，也“故意制造误差——例如，李的报道经常夸大工会组织者的工资。” 44李的传记同意埃文的评估，解释说“大多数公报的内容表面上是真实的，但呈现事实的方式却给人一种虚假的整体印象。” 45这种事实与谎言的混合是为了证明一个胡说八道的说法，“拉德洛的抢劫不是矿主及其军​​队所为，而是‘工会派出的高薪煽动者’所为。” 46

The Rockefeller family didn’t need more bad publicity; thanks to the work of the muckraker Ida Tarbell, they were already vilified due to their history as the owners of the legendarily rapacious Standard Oil corporation.42 Their involvement in a bloody, machine gun-driven, tent-burning, union-busting operation was not helping their reputation. To help clear the Rockefeller name, Lee sent tens of thousands of bulletins and booklets “to opinion leaders throughout the country: ‘public officials, editors, ministers, teachers, and prominent professionals and business men.’”43 Conceived of as missives exploring the “struggle for industrial freedom,” these bulletins included benign facts about Colorado coal mining meant to inform people about the industry. They also included material meant to sully the unions and strikers. As the media studies scholar Stuart Ewen notes, Lee mixed accurate facts about the industry with “calculated inaccuracies—Lee’s dispatches, for example, routinely exaggerated the salaries received by the union organizers.”44 A biography of Lee concurs with Ewen’s assessment, explaining that “most of the bulletins contained matter which on the surface was true but which presented the facts in such a way as to give a total picture that was false.”45 This mix of fact and deception was designed to prove the bullshit claim “that the pillage at Ludlow was the work not of the mine operators and their armies, but of ‘well-paid agitators sent out by the union.’”46

此外，李还使用了欺骗性的借口。这些公报被贴上科罗拉多煤炭行业制作的标签，但只字未提洛克菲勒家族的赞助。47他还招募了一位名叫海伦·格伦费尔的人，即“科罗拉多州妇女法律和秩序联盟副主席”，来提供拉德洛大屠杀的“目击者”证词，指责工会挑起这场斗争，并声称致命的火灾是意外造成的，而不是罢工破坏者故意纵火。“报告中没有提到的是，格伦费尔实际上并不是拉德洛事件的目击者，她是一位铁路官员的妻子，而这位铁路官员的公司从运输科罗拉多煤炭中获利。” 48

Moreover, Lee used deceptive pretexts. The bulletins were labeled as being produced by the Colorado coal industry, with no mention of the Rockefeller family’s sponsorship.47 He also recruited one Helen Grenfell, the “Vice-President of the Women’s Law and Order League of Colorado,” to provide an “eyewitness” account of the Ludlow Massacre that blamed the union for starting the fight and stated that the fatal fire was caused by accident, not set deliberately by the strike-breakers. “Unmentioned in the report were the facts that Grenfell was not, in fact, an eyewitness to events at Ludlow and that she was the wife of a railroad official whose company profited from carrying Colorado coal.”48

除事实外还使用欺骗手段，这违背了李的道德标准。他在 1925 年出版的小册子《宣传》中宣称，“宣传的根本弊端在于不披露信息来源。” 49在《原则宣言》中，李向谨慎的新闻编辑们保证，他的公关工作“是准确的”，并且“我们将非常乐意协助编辑核实任何事实陈述……我们将向编辑提供有关其代表发送文章的所有信息。”他的目标是“及时准确地向美国媒体和公众提供公众有价值和感兴趣的主题的信息。”李最后承诺：“我随时为您服务。” 50

The use of deception alongside facts contradicted Lee’s stated ethical standards. Writing in his 1925 pamphlet Publicity, he declared that “the essential evil of propaganda is the failure to disclose the source of information.”49 In his “Declaration of Principles,” a now-famous statement he had sent to newspaper editors across the United States just nine years prior to the Ludlow Massacre, Lee assured wary news editors that his public relations work “is accurate,” and that “any editor will be assisted most cheerfully in verifying any statement of fact. . . . Full information will be given to any editor concerning those on whose behalf an article is sent out.” His goal is to “supply to the press and public of the United States prompt and accurate information concerning subjects which it is of value and interest to the public to know about.” Lee concluded with a promise: “I am always at your service.”50

李为洛克菲勒家族所做的工作找借口，胡说工会领袖的薪水以及谁挑起冲突，为他辩护的人指出，李不可能信守自己的声明，因为他从雇主和科罗拉多州的一名记者那里得到了信息，他没有时间去核实每一个细节。51然而，当美国工业关系委员会指责李在工作中存在欺骗行为时，尽管他承诺会很乐意提供帮助，但他并没有采取任何措施来纠正记录。值得赞扬的是，李确实以一千本小册子的形式发送了一些更正信息。但这只是他发送的数万本带有欺骗性信息的小册子中的一小部分。52此外，“尽管李努力纠正问题，但未经更正的副本仍在流传。” 53所有这些都没有解决李没有透露洛克菲勒家族是其公告背后黑手的事实，违背了他提供“完整信息……”的承诺。那些代表他们发送文章的人。”尽管李的胡言乱语被委员会指出后受到了惩罚，但在拉德洛之后的几年里，他又在西弗吉尼亚州的煤矿经营者身上重复了他的策略。54

Apologists for Lee’s work on behalf of the Rockefellers—with its pretexts and bullshit about union leader salaries as well as who started the conflict—note that Lee could not possibly have lived up to his own declaration, because he was fed information from his employer and from a journalist in Colorado and he didn’t have the time to verify every detail.51 However, when Lee was called out on the deceptions in his work by the US Commission on Industrial Relations, he did little to correct the record, despite his promise of cheerful assistance. To Lee’s credit, he did send out some corrections in the form of one thousand booklets.
