As for the Internet Research Agency and its social media trolls, the US Department of Justice indictment against twelve of its employees claims that their trashing efforts began as early as May 2014 when the IRA began to discuss interfering in the upcoming US presidential election and started “monitor[ing] US social media accounts and other sources of information about the 2016 US presidential election.”7 More specifically, the indictment explains that the IRA

开始跟踪和研究美国社交媒体网站上专注于美国政治和社会问题的群组。为了衡量社交媒体网站上各种群组的表现，[IRA] 跟踪了某些指标，例如群组的规模、在群组中发布内容的频率以及受众对内容的参与程度，例如帖子的平均评论或回复数量。8

began to track and study groups on US social media sites dedicated to US politics and social issues. In order to gauge the performance of various groups on social media sites, [the IRA] tracked certain metrics like the group’s size, the frequency of content placed on the group, and the level of audience engagement with that content, such as the average number of comments or responses to a post.8

据推测，这些信息是由互联网研究机构专门的“数据分析部门”分析的。9这样的部门与世界各地无数其他部门一起，在当代数字资本主义的废弃物中寻找线索：我们与数字媒体互动时留下的痕迹。将这些痕迹转化为有价值的见解是一个变废为宝的过程，从大量数据中收集有价值的信息。10这样做的原因多种多样，包括获得对人类行为的社会学见解、流行病学、营销，当然还有社会工程学。

Presumably, this information was analyzed by the Internet Research Agency’s dedicated “data analysis department.”9 Such a department joins the myriad others around the world picking through the waste product of contemporary digital capitalism: the traces left behind as we engage with digital media. The conversion of such traces into valuable insights is a trash-to-treasure process, gleaning valuable information out of a massive collection of data.10 Such efforts can be done for a range of reasons, including gaining sociological insights into human behaviors, epidemiology, marketing, or, of course, social engineering.

至于剑桥分析公司，也许世界上没有哪家公司比 Facebook 更能体现数字垃圾桶的危险。11剑桥分析公司事件最具争议的方面是它使用不道德的方式（在某些司法管辖区，可能是非法获取的）获取的 Facebook 数据。正如《纽约时报》在 2018 年报道的那样：

As for Cambridge Analytica, perhaps no company in the world better exemplifies the perils of the digital dumpster—with the possible exception of Facebook.11 The most controversial aspect of the Cambridge Analytica saga was its use of unethically obtained—and, in some jurisdictions, possibly illegally obtained—Facebook data. As the New York Times reported in 2018:

当新兴的选民分析公司剑桥分析公司准备涉足2014年美国中期选举时，它遇到了一个问题。

该公司从富有的共和党捐赠者罗伯特·默瑟那里获得了 1500 万美元的投资，并向他的政治顾问史蒂芬·K·班农承诺，将开发能够识别美国选民性格并影响其行为的工具。但该公司缺乏让新产品发挥作用的数据。12

As the upstart voter-profiling company Cambridge Analytica prepared to wade into the 2014 American midterm elections, it had a problem.

The firm had secured a $15 million investment from Robert Mercer, the wealthy Republican donor, and wooed his political adviser, Stephen K. Bannon, with the promise of tools that could identify the personalities of American voters and influence their behavior. But it did not have the data to make its new products work.12

于是，剑桥分析公司开始大肆破坏。它从剑桥大学研究员亚历山大·科根那里获取了数据，而科根在 2014 年从使用“thisisyourdigitallife”性格测试 Facebook 应用程序的人那里收集了这些数据。13 剑桥分析公司还获取了使用该应用程序的朋友的数据。结果，“只有极小一部分 [该应用程序] 用户同意将他们的信息透露给第三方。” 14此外，为性格应用程序收集的数据旨在用于学术，而不是商业用途。但是，就像电信公司办公室外垃圾箱里的一堆文件一样，这些数据正等着被人拿去。正如剑桥分析公司举报人克里斯托弗·怀利所说：“这些数据从哪里来的，谁说我们可以得到这些数据——我们其实并没有问。” 15

So, Cambridge Analytica went trashing. It acquired data from the Cambridge University researcher Aleksandr Kogan, who had gathered it from people who used the “thisisyourdigitallife” personality test Facebook app in 2014.13 And Cambridge Analytica also took the data of the friends who used that app. As a result, “only a tiny fraction of the users [of the app] had agreed to release their information to a third party.”14 Moreover, the data collected for the personality app was intended for academic, not commercial use. But, like a stack of documents in a dumpster outside a telco office, the data were just ripe for the taking. As the Cambridge Analytica whistleblower Christopher Wylie put it, “Where [the data] came from, who said we could have it—we weren’t really asking.”15

还有一些其他应用程序被用来分析 Facebook 用户并收集他们的朋友的数据，这些应用程序的名字包括“音乐海象”和“性指南针”。16 Wylie指出

There were additional apps being used to profile Facebook users and gather their friends’ data, apps with names like “Music Walrus” and the “Sex Compass.”16 Wylie notes that

剑桥分析公司 [还] 开始测试看似无害的浏览器扩展程序，例如计算器和日历，这些扩展程序可以访问用户的 Facebook 会话 cookie，从而允许该公司以目标用户的身份登录 Facebook，收集他们及其好友的数据。17

Cambridge Analytica [also] began testing innocuous-looking browser extensions, such as calculators and calendars, that pulled access to the user’s Facebook session cookies, which in turn allowed the company to log in to Facebook as the target user to harvest their data and that of their friends.17

此外，该公司还从 Experian、Acxiom、Magellan 和 L2.18 等公司购买了更多数据。应用程序、浏览器扩展和数据市场：数字垃圾箱非常庞大，而剑桥分析公司正乐此不疲地在其中打滚。

In addition, the company purchased more data from firms such as Experian, Acxiom, Magellan, and L2.18 Apps, browser extensions, and data markets: the digital dumpster is vast, and Cambridge Analytica was happily wallowing in it.

像任何其他大数据分析操作一样，剑桥分析公司必须清理数据，这与旧时的电话飞客分类垃圾的行为相似。剑桥分析公司的举报人布列塔尼凯撒称之为“清洁……，即数据工程师将新数据与旧数据匹配并修复错误的过程……数据越干净，算法就越准确，因此可预测性就越好。” 19凯撒强调所谓的“清洁”让我们想起“处理数据并将其转化为可回收资源用于新形式知识生产所涉及的复杂和物质过程。通过数据化，我们因此发现自己身处垃圾焚烧炉，而不是金矿。” 20就像那些跳进垃圾箱抓起袋子以便稍后分类的飞客和黑客一样，剑桥分析公司收集了大量数据，但他们明白必须对其进行分类才能找到他们心理档案所需的有价值信息。

Like any other big data analysis operation, Cambridge Analytica had to clean the data, echoing the older phone phreak act of sorting through the trash. Cambridge Analytica whistleblower Brittany Kaiser calls this “hygiene-ing . . . , the process by which data engineers match new data to old and fix errors. . . . The cleaner the data, the more accurate the algorithms, and hence, the better the predictability.”19 Kaiser’s highlighting of so-called “hygiene-ing” reminds us of “the complicated and material processes involved in treating data and turning it into recyclable resources for new forms of knowledge production. With datafication we thus find ourselves in the waste incinerator, not the gold mine.”20 Like the phreaks and hackers who would jump in dumpsters and grab bags for later sorting, Cambridge Analytica gathered massive gluts of data but understood that they had to sort it to find the valuable information they needed for their psychographic profiles.

借口

Pretexting

多项分析显示，俄罗斯互联网研究机构扮演着各种各样的角色在 2016 年大选之前、期间和之后，俄罗斯人一直在利用这些借口来操纵美国。这些借口包括黑人活动家和德克萨斯州保守派等角色。这些借口并不神秘或神奇；它们反映了选举前几年非常容易辨认的既有角色，俄罗斯人在完成破坏工作后才意识到这一点。正如前美国国家安全委员会成员菲奥娜·希尔 (Fiona Hill) 所解释的那样，“俄罗斯政府并不直接干预。它委托代理人，这些代理人会扩大我们的分歧并利用我们的政治两极分化。” 21

As multiple analyses show, Russia’s Internet Research Agency engaged in pretexting, masquerading in a wide range of roles before, during, and after the 2016 election. These pretexts included roles such as Black activists and Texas conservatives. These pretexts are not mysterious or magical; they reflect preexisting roles that were highly recognizable in the years immediately preceding the election, apparent to the Russians after they had completed their trashing efforts. As former US National Security Council member Fiona Hill explains, “The Russian state does not meddle directly. It delegates to proxies, who amplify our divisions and exploit our political polarization.”21

俄罗斯人利用的政治两极分化包括种族经历、枪支管制立场和移民改革方面的分歧。正如《2019 年美国黑人状况报告》所指出的，在选举期间，“俄罗斯宣传人员通过广泛的影响力运动专门针对非裔美国人。他们的策略包括冒充合法的激进组织、削弱对民主机构的信任以及传播虚假信息。” 22同样，美国参议院委托撰写的一份报告解释了俄罗斯如何

The political polarizations the Russians exploited included divisions over racial experiences, gun-regulation stances, and immigration reform. As the 2019 State of Black America Report notes, during the election, “Russian propagandists specifically targeted African Americans through a wide-reaching influence campaign. Their tactics included posing as legitimate activist groups, eroding trust in democratic institutions, and spreading disinformation.”22 Likewise, a US Senate-commissioned report explains how

IRA 的帖子 [也] 倾向于模仿反对枪支管制和加强移民监管的保守派观点。在某些情况下，他们使用诸如“寄生虫”之类的词语来指代移民，而其他一些则表达了对极端主义观点的某种容忍。23

IRA posts [also] tended to mimic conservative views against gun control and for increased regulation of immigrants. In some cases, terms such as “parasites” were used to reference immigrants and others expressed some tolerance of extremist views.23

因此，爱尔兰共和军依靠现存的、可识别的分歧和社会刻板印象作为一套可能的网络借口。

Hence, the IRA relied upon existing and recognizable divisions and social stereotypes as a set of possible online pretexts.

这些借口以各种方式部署。一种方法是使用社交机器人，或看起来像人类的自动社交媒体资料。24社交机器人是“力量倍增器”，它“利用机器学习和人工智能进行大规模有针对性的及时信息交易，同时将关键的细微对话留给人类操作员。” 25 IRA使用社交机器人在大规模上巧妙地塑造在线话语。正如穆勒报告所记录的那样，俄罗斯人在 Twitter 上广泛使用机器人：

These pretexts were deployed in a range of ways. One approach was to use socialbots, or automated social media profiles that appear to be human.24 Socialbots are “force multipliers” that “leverage machine learning and artificial intelligence to conduct targeted and timely information transactions at scale while leaving critical nuanced dialog to human operators.”25 The IRA used socialbots to subtly shape online discourse on a mass scale. As the Mueller Report documents, Russians used bots in Twitter extensively:

2018 年 1 月，Twitter 公开确认了 3,814 个与 IRA 有关的 Twitter 账户。据 Twitter 称，在 2016 年美国总统大选前的十周内，这些账户发布了约 175,993 条推文，“其中约 8.4％与选举有关。” 26

In January 2018, Twitter publicly identified 3,814 Twitter accounts associated with the IRA. According to Twitter, in the ten weeks before the 2016 US presidential election, these accounts posted approximately 175,993 tweets, “approximately 8.4% of which were election-related.”26

虽然其分析的重点是瑞典大选，而不是 2016 年美国总统大选，但美国海军情报局赞助的一份报告包含了有关瑞典大选前夕俄罗斯机器人（即很可能但未经证实的社交机器人）在 Twitter 上的行为范围的数据，显示了俄罗斯机器人参与在线辩论的程度。27专注于美国背景的研究人员发现了类似的动态。28

While its analysis focuses on an election in Sweden and not the 2016 US presidential election, a report sponsored by the US Office of Naval Intelligence includes data about the extent of Russian bot-like (i.e., very probably, but not confirmed, socialbot) behavior on Twitter during the run-up to the Swedish election, showing the extent to which Russian bots insinuated themselves into online debates.27 Researchers focusing on the US context find similar dynamics.28

但互联网研究机构不仅仅使用机器人。它还利用人类控制的社交媒体资料作为借口。“虽然媒体对俄罗斯/爱尔兰共和军推特活动的报道往往集中在自动化和机器人上，但该机构运行了人类操作的精确角色，这些角色大致映射到 Facebook 和 Instagram 上观察到的相同的黑人、左派和右派群体。” 29虽然社交机器人可以作为自动发布社交媒体帖子的相对粗略的借口，但人类控制的社交媒体账户可以更灵活，允许更有创意的胡说八道。

But the Internet Research Agency didn’t just use bots. It also utilized human-controlled social media profiles as pretexts. “While media narratives around the Russian/IRA Twitter activity have often focused on automation and bots, the agency ran human-operated precision personas that roughly mapped to the same Black, Left, and Right clusters observed on Facebook and Instagram.”29 While socialbots are useful for relatively crude pretexts that automatically make social media posts, human-controlled social media accounts can be more flexible, allowing for more creative bullshitting.

作为借口，这些行动映射并放大了团体内和团体外的动态：“Facebook 和 Instagram 被用来发展更深层次的关系，创建了一系列实质性的文化媒体页面，致力于不断强化目标受众的团体内和团体外的理想。” 30这些借口的成功之处在于它们得到了真正的美国人的认可，而美国人反过来帮助使借口合法化：“与真正的美国人合作的目标是消除虚假人物被发现和暴露的风险。” 31虽然许多对俄罗斯行动的评论都谴责其“虚假”或“不真实”，但爱尔兰共和军的借口揭示了俄罗斯人在模仿美国文化动态时有多么小心。

As pretexts, these operations mapped onto and amplified in-group and out-group dynamics: “Facebook and Instagram were used to develop deeper relationships, to create a collection of substantive cultural media pages dedicated to continual reinforcement of in-group and out-group ideals for targeted audiences.”30 The success of these pretexts is marked by how well they were recognized by actual Americans, who in turn helped legitimate the pretext: “The goal of working with real Americans is to eliminate the detection and exposure risk of inauthentic personas.”31 While much of the commentary on the Russian operation decries it as “fake” or “inauthentic,” what the IRA pretexts reveal is how careful the Russians were in emulating the dynamics of American culture.

剑桥分析公司也严重依赖借口。剑桥分析公司最广为人知的借口与该公司的破坏活动密切相关。该公司的与剑桥大学的亚历山大·科根博士的合作最初旨在帮助宣传泰德·克鲁兹和唐纳德·特朗普在 2016 年总统竞选中的竞选活动。但这种诋毁是有借口的。科根使用亚马逊的众包平台 Mechanical Turk 招募并付费让参与者参加性格测试，同时还允许他访问他们的 Facebook 个人资料和他们好友的个人资料。然后将性格数据和 Facebook 个人资料数据进行匹配，并用于创建一个预测模型，该模型用于代表公司客户推动政治信息的细分、定位和个性化。所有这些都是以“学术研究”的借口进行的，参与者被告知他们的数据将是匿名的并保密。他们不知道的是，科根并不是以学者的身份行事，而是受剑桥分析公司雇佣，以科根为此目的而成立的 Global Sciences Research 公司的名义收集这些数据。不仅这次数据收集主要不是学术研究，而且科根作为剑桥学术研究员的身份还有其他未公开的层面。《卫报》报道称，科根“之前与一所俄罗斯大学有未披露的联系，并接受俄罗斯的研究资助”，而作为数据收集借口的研究实际上是对两位同事所做工作的复制，目的是让他们和大学无法从与剑桥分析公司签订的合同中获得任何收益。32

Cambridge Analytica also relied heavily on pretexting. The first and most well-known layer of Cambridge Analytica pretexting is closely tied to the company’s trashing activities. The company’s cooperation with Cambridge University’s Dr. Aleksandr Kogan was first aimed at helping promote the campaigns of Ted Cruz and then Donald Trump in their respective 2016 presidential bids. But this trashing was enabled by a pretext. Kogan used Amazon’s crowd-sourcing platform, Mechanical Turk, to recruit and pay participants to take a personality quiz that also gave him access to their Facebook profiles and the profiles of their friends. The personality data and Facebook profile data were then matched and used to create a predictive model deployed to drive the segmentation, targeting, and personalization of political messaging on behalf of the company’s clients. All of this was done under the pretext of “academic research” and participants were told that their data would be anonymous and kept confidential. What they did not know was that Kogan was acting not in his capacity as an academic, but rather, was being paid by Cambridge Analytica to collect this data under the name of Global Sciences Research, a company Kogan established for precisely this purpose. Not only was this data collection not primarily about academic research, but Kogan’s own identity as a Cambridge academic researcher had other, undisclosed layers. The Guardian newspaper reported that Kogan “had previously unreported links to a Russian university and took Russian grants for research” and that the research used as pretext for data collection was actually a replication of work done by two colleagues meant to cut them and the university out of any proceeds for contracted work with Cambridge Analytica.32

除了科根的数据收集之外，剑桥分析公司用于相同目的的各种 Facebook 应用程序——Music Walrus 和 Sex Compass——并没有被描述为数据收集工作，而是娱乐消遣。此外，它们也没有被描述为属于剑桥分析公司。2018 年，前剑桥分析公司员工布列塔尼·凯泽在接受 CBS 记者采访时

Beyond Kogan’s data gathering, the various Facebook apps Cambridge Analytica used for the same purpose—the Music Walrus and the Sex Compass—were not presented as data-collection efforts but as entertaining diversions. Moreover, they were not presented as belonging to Cambridge Analytica. Speaking to CBS reporters in 2018, former Cambridge Analytica employee Brittany Kaiser

向我们展示了 2015 年的一份报告，该报告来自一位数据科学家，他参与了一个名为“Music Walrus”的测验。在一封全公司电子邮件中，他询问同事们与家人和朋友分享，但补充说，“请不要提及这是我们的作品。说是‘你的一个朋友’做的（这是真的……不是吗？）” 33

showed us a 2015 note from a data scientist behind a quiz called “Music Walrus.” In the all-company email, he asked colleagues to share it with family and friends but added, “Please DO NOT MENTION THAT IT IS [OUR CREATION]. Say that a ‘friend of yours’ made it (which is true . . . no?)”33

这些应用程序被设计为朋友和家人无害的娱乐活动——这是收集数据的绝佳借口。

These apps were presented as harmless entertainment for friends and family—a fine pretext for data gathering.

但据报道，该公司使用的借口比误导性应用程序还要恶劣。2018 年，英国第四频道根据剑桥分析公司高管的一系列秘密录音报道，该公司还部署了一系列“肮脏的手段”来收集有关其客户政治对手的不利信息。时任该公司首席执行官的亚历山大·尼克斯 (Alexander Nix) 在一份秘密录音中描述了这些策略，他说：“我们目前有两个项目，涉及对反对派进行深入、深入的研究，并提供来源……真正具有破坏性的源材料，我们可以决定如何在竞选过程中部署。” 34这些项目包括派遣研究人员以游客或学生的借口前往美国等外国。更令人不安的是，它包括使用前英国和以色列间谍帮助该公司雇用妓女来设置美人计、安排假贿赂诱捕等。35

But the company is reported to have used more nefarious pretexts than misleading apps. In 2018, based on a series of secret recordings of Cambridge Analytica executives, the UK’s Channel 4 reported that the company had also deployed a range of “dirty tricks” for collecting damaging information about its clients’ political opponents. Alexander Nix, then the company’s CEO, described these tactics on a secret recording, saying, “We have two projects at the moment, which involve doing deep, deep depth [sic] research on the opposition and providing source . . . really damaging source material, that we can decide how to deploy in the course of the campaign.”34 These projects included sending researchers into foreign countries, like the United States, with the pretexts of being tourists or students. More disturbing still, it included the use of former British and Israeli spies to aid the company in hiring prostitutes to set honey traps, arrange fake bribery stings, and more.35

最后，我们可以更进一步说，剑桥分析公司本身就是一个借口，它建立在借口平台之上或在借口平台内运作。如今，对于一家在线营销公司来说，使用数据来细分和定位个人和小群体并向其发送定制信息并不是什么新鲜事。正如尼克斯在 2017 年的在线营销摇滚明星大会上对观众所说的那样，他们为唐纳德·特朗普竞选所做的工作代表了行为科学、数据分析和可寻址广告技术对在线营销领域日益增长的重要性。36他说得没错。但我们现在知道，剑桥分析公司并不是一家普通的在线营销公司。这是一家专注于政治（尤其是右翼政治）的公司，与史蒂夫·班农和罗伯特·默瑟等美国右翼政治人物有联系。更重要的是，它不仅是一家数字政治营销公司，还是 SCL 集团（前身为战略通信实验室）的子公司。再一次，这听起来像是一家无害的公关或营销公司，但实际上是一家据称参与“选举网络战”的国防承包商。37

Finally, we might go a step further and say that Cambridge Analytica is itself a pretext that is built on top of, or operates within, pretextual platforms. Using data to segment and target individuals and small groups with customized messages is not so out of the ordinary for an online marketing company these days. As Nix told an audience at the Online Marketing Rockstars in 2017, the work they did for the Donald Trump campaign is representative of the growing importance of behavioral science, data analytics, and addressable ad tech for the world of online marketing.36 He is not wrong. But we now know that Cambridge Analytica was no run-of-the-mill online marketing firm. It was a firm focused on politics—right-wing politics in particular—with ties to right-wing American political figures such as Steve Bannon and Robert Mercer. What’s more, it was not just a digital political marketing firm but also a subsidiary of the SCL Group (formerly Strategic Communication Laboratories). Once again, this sounds like an innocuous public relations or marketing firm, but it was really a defense contractor reportedly engaged in “cyberwarfare for elections.”37

简而言之，剑桥分析公司几乎在各个方面都比它所描绘的要多或少有些不同。这种借口是经过精心设计的。正如尼克斯告诉一位卧底记者，“我们习惯于通过不同的媒介，在暗中运作。”剑桥分析公司政治部门董事总经理马克·特恩布尔进一步解释说，该公司的活动“必须在没有人认为这是宣传的情况下进行，因为当你认为‘那是宣传’时，下一个问题就是：‘是谁发布的？’”为了掩盖他们的踪迹，他说，“我们可能不得不以不同的名称签订合同……不同的实体，不同的名称，这样就不会有任何记录与我们的名字有关。” 38

In short, in almost every way, Cambridge Analytica was more, or other, than it portrayed itself to be. And this pretexting was by design. As Nix told an undercover reporter, “We’re used to operating through different vehicles, in the shadows.” The managing director of Cambridge Analytica’s political division, Mark Turnbull, explained further that the company’s activity, “has to happen without anyone thinking it’s propaganda, because the moment you think ‘that’s propaganda’ the next question is: ‘Who’s put that out?’” To cover their tracks, he said, “It may be that we have to contract under a different name . . . a different entity, with a different name, so that no record exists with our name attached to this at all.”38

胡说八道

Bullshitting

回想一下，胡说八道是社会工程学的核心活动。当借口生效时，当社会工程师与目标接触并必须建立融洽关系、谨慎地提出信息和想法，并且不暴露身份时，就会发生胡说八道。此时，社会工程师必须灵活，在借口建立的框架内与目标建立关系。这需要巧妙地结合欺骗、友好和准确，所有这些都是为了渗透目标。如果真相浮出水面，那就无关紧要了——渗透才是最重要的。

Recall that bullshitting is the core activity of social engineering. Bullshitting occurs when the pretext goes live, when the social engineer engages with the target and has to develop rapport, carefully suggest messages and ideas, and not blow their cover. At this point, the social engineer has to be nimble, building a relationship with the target within the framework established by the pretext. This requires a skillful blend of deception, friendliness, and accuracy, all with the goal of penetrating the target. If the truth appears, it’s beside the point—the penetration is what matters.

俄罗斯的胡说八道包括欺骗，这一点显而易见：无论是部署为机器人还是人工控制的账户，互联网研究机构的工作人员实际上都不是“黑人的命也是命”运动的积极分子，也不是支持第二修正案的持枪德克萨斯人。来自符拉迪沃斯托克的弗拉德绝对不是德韦恩来自底特律或哈罗德来自休斯顿。然而，如果分析就此止步，并简单地谴责 IRA 的努力是彻头彻尾的虚假，那么就错过了 IRA 的大部分行动。

That the Russian bullshit included deception should be obvious: whether deployed as bots or human-controlled accounts, the Internet Research Agency operatives were not actually Black Lives Matter activists or gun-toting Texans advocating for the Second Amendment. Vlad from Vladivostok was decidedly not Dewayne from Detroit or Harold from Houston. However, analysis that stops at this point and simply decries the IRA efforts as completely fake misses much of what the IRA was up to.

值得注意的是，谴责 IRA 是假的，忽视了 IRA 帖子的纯粹友好性——看似真诚地希望帮助黑人活动家或德克萨斯保守派建立一个在线社区。穆勒报告指出，Twitter 识别出来自 IRA 账户的推文中，只有 8.4% 与选举有关。同样，对 IRA 推文随机样本的另一项分析发现，其中大多数（52.6%）“与 IRA 议程建设活动没有明确或公开的联系”——即与选举政治无关。39这就引出了一个问题：绝大多数社交媒体帖子的目的是什么？我们不应该将这些非政治性帖子孤立出来，而应该在互联网研究机构活动的更大背景下看待它们。也就是说，我们应该将它们视为胡说八道的“社交”元素，然后研究 IRA 如何将欺骗和准确性混为一谈。

Notably, decrying the IRA as fake ignores the sheer friendliness of the IRA posts—the seemingly earnest desire to help build Black activists or Texas conservatives into an online community. The Mueller Report noted that only 8.4 percent of the Tweets that Twitter identified as coming from IRA accounts had to do with the election. Likewise, another analysis of a random sample of IRA Tweets found that the majority of them (52.6 percent) had “no clear or overt connection to the IRA agenda building activity”—that is, no connection to electoral politics.39 This begs the question: what is the purpose of this large majority of social media posts? Rather than bracketing these apolitical posts off, we have to see them in the larger context of Internet Research Agency activities. That is, we should consider them as the “sociable” element of the bullshitting and then examine how the IRA mixed in deception and accuracy.

一份报告展示了社交成分与其他胡说八道方面共同发挥作用的关键可视化，该报告包括 Instagram 和 Facebook 图像宏风格 meme 的截图，这些 meme 被追溯到 IRA 账户。虽然有尖锐的政治批评，但许多帖子都是良性的，甚至是鼓舞人心的。最能说明问题的是 IRA 运营的 Facebook 群组“Heart of Texas”中以德克萨斯州为主题的图像 meme 集合。这些图片将反移民和德克萨斯州分裂主义（#Texit）言论与德克萨斯州日落和野花的照片集合混合在一起。40

A key visualization of the sociable ingredient working alongside the other aspects of bullshit can be seen in a report which includes screenshots of Instagram and Facebook image macro-style memes that were traced to IRA accounts. While there are pointed political critiques, many of the posts are benign, even inspirational. Most telling is a collection of Texas-oriented image memes from an IRA-run Facebook group called “Heart of Texas.” The images mix together anti-immigrant and Texas secessionist (#Texit) rhetoric with a collection of pictures of Texas sunsets and wildflowers.40

分析师在查看这些帖子时，通常会将其归类为“不直接涉及政治”。41然而，当我们将这些帖子放在更广泛的社会工程背景下时，这些帖子应该被视为更大规模的胡说八道运动的社交方面。在 Heart of Texas Facebook 群组中，源源不断的德克萨斯州日落和野花是放大德克萨斯州自豪感的好方法，而这种自豪感又与反移民情绪或虚假的德克萨斯州脱离美国其他地区后，经济成功的统计数据。同样，俄罗斯特工呈现的黑人骄傲形象也与白人至上主义社会中投票无望的叙述相呼应。将这些帖子脱离背景并严格分析为“不直接涉及政治”，会分散我们对互联网研究机构胡说八道更令人不安的目标的注意力：阻止美国黑人参与选举政治或在德克萨斯州人中煽动#Texit 分裂主义政治。

Very often, analysts who look at these types of posts categorize them as “not directly political.”41 However, when we place posts such as these in the broader context of social engineering, these posts should be seen as the sociable side of a larger bullshitting campaign. In the Heart of Texas Facebook group, a steady stream of Texas sunsets and wildflowers is a fine way to amplify Texas pride, which in turn is articulated with anti-immigrant sentiment or bogus statistics about the economic success of Texas should it secede from the rest of the United States. Likewise, the stream of Black pride images presented by Russian operatives were articulated with narratives about the hopelessness of voting in a white supremacist society. Taking these posts out of context and analyzing them as strictly “not directly political” distracts us from the more disturbing goals of Internet Research Agency bullshitting: to discourage Black Americans from taking part in electoral politics or stoking #Texit secessionist politics among Texans.

至于胡说八道的另一个要素，即准确性，这种社交性是哲学家哈里·法兰克福所说的“精湛技艺的工匠……不知疲倦地致力于使他们制作的每一个[胡说八道]单词和图像都完全正确”的重要组成部分。42这反映在以下事实中：大多数俄罗斯控制的账户“都在模仿与他们所‘欺骗’的社会身份相一致的兴趣和价值观，然后偶尔他们会发送公开的政治内容。” 43互联网研究机构的社交媒体活动旨在创建“真实”和“虚假”账户的网络。44这需要胡说八道的准确性，使用语言和图像的方式会让真正的美国人认识到 IRA 的借口是合法的。这样做会创建真实账户和经过审查的账户的混合，以便

As for the other element of bullshit, accuracy, such sociability is part and parcel of what the philosopher Harry Frankfurt called the “exquisitely sophisticated craftsmen who . . . dedicate themselves tirelessly to getting every [bullshit] word and image they produce exactly right.”42 This is reflected by the fact that the majority of Russian-controlled accounts were “engaged in mimicking the kinds of interests and values coherent with the social identities that they were ‘spoofing,’ and then occasionally they would message avowedly political content.”43 The Internet Research Agency social media campaign was designed to create networks of “authentic” and “inauthentic” accounts.44 This required the accuracy aspect of bullshit, using language and images in a way that would lead real Americans to recognize the IRA pretext as legitimate. Doing so created a mix of actual accounts and vetted ones, so that

关注或点赞某个针对黑人社区的 IRA 页面的个人将会接触到来自其他数十个页面的内容，以及精心策划的真实黑人媒体内容，这些内容在意识形态或主题上与互联网研究机构的信息相一致。45

An individual who followed or liked one of the Black-community-targeted IRA Pages would have been exposed to content from dozens more, as well as carefully curated authentic Black media content that was ideologically or thematically aligned with the Internet Research Agency messaging.45

一旦有人与这种由真人和假人组成的网络进行接触，IRA 就会与他们进行人际互动，其角色“自发且反应灵敏，与真实用户（知名影响者和媒体，以及普通人）互动，参与实时对话，创建民意调查，并玩标签游戏。这些人物与美国公民建立了关系。” 46

Once someone engaged with this networked mixture of real and pretext people, the IRA would interpersonally interact with them, with personas that “were spontaneous and responsive, engaging with real users (famous influencers and media, as well as regular people), participating in real-time conversations, creating polls, and playing hashtag games. These personas developed relationships with American citizens.”46

在这里，想要正确理解美国文化是更大范围的胡说八道过程的一部分。在标签游戏中，社交媒体用户通常会以一种有趣、文化娴熟的方式发布对提示的回应，而成功玩这个游戏就意味着 IRA 的文化参考是正确的。实现这一点，再加上一点社交能力，俄罗斯胡说八道者可以发布几乎任何东西，并让它看起来至少有点可信。毕竟，它来自一个经过审查的真正的美国人。

Here, the desire to get American culture right is part of the larger bullshitting process. Successful play at a hashtag game, where social media users post responses to prompts, often in a playful, culturally adept manner, means the IRA got their cultural references right. With that achieved, and with a bit more sociability, the Russian bullshitter could post just about anything and have it seem at least somewhat credible. After all, it came from a persona who was vetted as a real American.

所有这些都不是要否认 IRA 最终对真相漠不关心的事实。一个例子是“叙事转换”，即有时甚至在同一个账户上突然改变话题。“IRA 不仅从平庸的观点转向亲俄观点，而且根据俄罗斯当前的行动重点，甚至只是为了制造混乱，在不同的政治立场之间突然切换。” 47换句话说，IRA 随着时间的推移尝试了许多不同的话题，甚至使用同一个账户，试图看看哪种胡说八道最有效。当 Internet Research Agency 的员工在新闻评论区进行他们之间的“辩论”时，他们使用了一种非常基本的启发式方法：“我们不说话，因为我们可以亲眼看到其他人在写什么，但事实上你甚至不必真正阅读它，因为那都是胡说八道……而你如何写作并不重要；你可以表扬或责骂。” 48

None of this is to deny the fact that the IRA was, at the end of the day, indifferent towards the truth. One example is “narrative switching,” or the sometimes sudden shifts in topics even on the same accounts. “The IRA not only switched from banal to pro-Russian views but also switched abruptly between different political positions according to current Russian operational priorities, or even just to create confusion.”47 In other words, the IRA tried lots of different topics over time, even with the same account, in an attempt to see what bullshit would work best. And when Internet Research Agency employees were engaged in staged “debates” among themselves, played out in news comment fields, they used a very basic heuristic: “We don’t talk, because we can see for ourselves what the others are writing, but in fact you don’t even have to really read it, because it’s all nonsense. . . . And how you write doesn’t matter; you can praise or scold.”48

至于剑桥分析公司，他们使用的胡说八道比俄罗斯的手段更为复杂。也许这在一定程度上是因为该公司的员工对美国文化有更深的理解。这也因为剑桥分析公司在大规模个人社交工程的迭代中模糊了借口、诋毁、胡说八道和渗透之间的界限。

As for Cambridge Analytica, their use of bullshit is more intricate than the Russian effort. Perhaps this is in part due to the company employees’ deeper understanding of American culture. It is also due to the fact that Cambridge Analytica’s work blurred the boundaries between pretexting, trashing, bullshitting, and penetrating in its iteration of masspersonal social engineering.

我们对剑桥分析公司与其剑桥分析公司的目标是阻止公众报道。当然，部分原因是这些信息被定位为“暗黑广告”，只有社交媒体上某些狭隘的人群才能看到，而包括 Facebook 在内的社交媒体公司并没有提供这些广告的详细信息。如果你不属于这些群体——我们绝大多数人都不属于——那么你很可能从未看到过剑桥分析公司的任何信息。49但我们所知道的广告和活动都是相当令人印象深刻的胡说八道的例子。我们仍然可以访问的少数广告之一是该公司在Politico上投放的广告。剑桥分析公司的员工 Molly Schweickert 称这则广告比传统的 30 秒商业广告更友善、更友好：广告“好看又漂亮”。50这则广告确实很人性化：只需点击几下即可提供克林顿基金会令人震惊的财务细节，主要依靠新闻文章中的突出显示引述，并附有原始来源的链接。然而，多个事实核查组织一再发现特朗普阵营对克林顿基金会的说法是错误的。51但正如剑桥分析公司的马克·特恩布尔所解释的那样，“用事实来打竞选活动是没有用的，因为实际上一切都关乎情感。” 52

We do not know as much as we would like about the actual messaging and interactions between Cambridge Analytica and its targets from public reporting. Part of the reason, of course, is that the messages were targeted as “dark ads” visible only to certain narrow segments of people via social media, and social media corporations, including Facebook, are not providing details about these ads. If you were not part of these segments—the vast majority of us were not—then you very likely never saw any of Cambridge Analytica’s messages.49 But the ads and campaigns we know about are quite impressive examples of bullshit. One of the few we can still access is an ad the company ran in Politico. Cambridge Analytica employee Molly Schweickert referred to this ad as a kinder, friendlier alternative to the traditional, blanket 30 second commercial: the ad was “nice-looking and pretty.”50 The ad is indeed user-friendly: a few clicks or taps provides startling financial details about the Clinton Foundation, relying heavily on highlighted quotes from news articles and complete with links to the original sources. However, multiple fact-checking organizations have repeatedly found Trump camp claims about the Clinton Foundation to be false.51 But, as Cambridge Analytica’s Mark Turnbull explains, “it’s no good fighting an election campaign on the facts, because actually it’s all about emotions.”52

由于第四频道的刺​​探，我们还知道剑桥分析公司的高管声称他们创造了“打败骗子希拉里”的口号，其中的“OO”看起来像手铐。53告密者克里斯托弗·怀利 (Christopher Wylie) 报告说，“建墙”和“抽干沼泽”正是剑桥分析公司在特朗普宣布参选之前就测试过的短语，并包含在发送给 [史蒂夫] 班农 (Steve Bannon) 的报告中。54当然，在每一起案件中，剑桥分析公司都对这些信息背后的真相漠不关心。希拉里·克林顿是否真的犯了应该被关起来的罪行，边境墙作为对移民问题的回应是否有意义，特朗普是抽干沼泽的人还是沼泽居民，这些都不是重点，重点只是为了为客户实现结果。怀利说甚至将剑桥分析公司的做法描述为“一种非动能武器，旨在大规模地抹杀观点——主动解构和操纵大众的看法。” 55剑桥分析公司用于从事“抹杀观点”的其他技术包括“在 Facebook 和其他平台上建立看起来像真实论坛、群组和新闻来源的虚假页面”，例如专注于当地的“右翼页面，名字模糊，如 Smith County Patriots 或 I Love My Country” 。56

Thanks to Channel 4’s sting, we also know that Cambridge Analytica executives claimed to have created the “Defeat CrOOked Hillary” slogan with the “OO” looking like handcuffs.53 Whistleblower Christopher Wylie reports that “Build the Wall” and “Drain the Swamp” “were the exact phrases Cambridge Analytica had tested and included in reports sent to [Steve] Bannon well before Trump announced” his candidacy.54 In each case, of course, Cambridge Analytica was indifferent to the truth behind such messages. Whether Hillary Clinton had actually committed crimes for which she should be locked up, whether a border wall made any sense as a response to immigration, and whether Trump was the man to drain the swamp or, rather, a swamp dweller himself, were all beside the point, which was merely to achieve results for the client. Wylie goes so far as to characterize the Cambridge Analytica practices as “a non-kinetic weapon designed for scaled perspecticide—the active deconstruction and manipulation of popular perception.”55 Other techniques used by Cambridge Analytica to engage in “perspecticide” include “fake pages on Facebook and other platforms that looked like real forums, groups, and news sources,” such as locally focused “right-wing pages with vague names like Smith County Patriots or I Love My Country.”56

剑桥分析公司试图破坏观点并不意味着他们对此不友好。当然，“友好”可以指善良或友好。这当然是我们在前几章中讨论过的胡说八道的一部分。但要求逮捕克林顿的挑衅性呼吁表明了一种不同的友好，一种强烈的“我们”与“他们”的对立感。剑桥分析公司的内容旨在通过与目标受众的个性和世界观产生共鸣或具有相似性来“友好”地对待目标受众，正如剑桥分析公司对他们的分析所推断的那样。也就是说，剑桥分析公司的胡说八道是故意针对那些被认为对所发送的信息持赞成态度或倾向于支持的人而编写和针对的。怀利描述了他们是如何做到这一点的，他们“瞄准具有特定心理弱点的人”，然后用“一些突出的信息”来“引导”他们，以影响他们的感受、想法和行为。57剑桥分析公司针对的特定“心理弱点”是“具有神经质或阴谋论倾向的人”。58因此，我们可以说，剑桥分析公司的特定品牌的胡说八道是对神经质或阴谋论“友好的”。

Just because Cambridge Analytica sought to destroy perspective doesn’t mean they weren’t friendly about it. Of course, “friendly” can refer to being kind or amicable. This is certainly a part of bullshitting that we have discussed in previous chapters. But the belligerent calls to arrest Clinton indicate a different sort of amicability, a heightened sense of us-versus-them. Cambridge Analytica content was meant to be “friendly” to its target audience by being resonant or sharing an affinity with the targets’ personalities and worldviews as inferred by Cambridge Analytica’s profiling of them. That is, Cambridge Analytica’s bullshit was created and targeted deliberately at those deemed to be favorably disposed to, or inclined to support, the messages being sent. Wylie describes how this was done by “targeting people with specific psychological vulnerabilities” and then “priming” them with “bits of salient information” in an effort to affect how they feel, think, and act.57 The specific “psychological vulnerabilities” that Cambridge Analytica targeted were “people with neurotic or conspiratorial predispositions.”58 We might say, then, that Cambridge Analytica’s particular brand of bullshit was neurotic- or conspiracy-“friendly.”

但正如怀利关于“观点杀戮”的观点所表明的那样，剑桥分析公司的总体目标远不止针对所谓的神经质。它试图传播对真相的漠不关心，而这正是它与目标互动的核心。例如，怀利认为史蒂夫·班农在他的另类右翼文化战争叛乱中故意将剑桥分析公司用作心理战工具针对美国人，造成“混乱、操纵和欺骗。真相被替代的叙述和虚拟现实所取代，”怀利说。59怀利解释说，对于班农来说，重塑社会始于故意造成“混乱和破坏”。破坏真相并用胡说八道取而代之是实现这一目标的关键工具。60简而言之，剑桥分析公司的胡说八道的最终目标不仅仅是直接宣传特朗普，而且是破坏真相和确定性的概念，转而向我们中间神经质和阴谋论者宣传持续的不确定性，从而造成混乱，特朗普和另类右翼可以利用这种混乱。当然，这种策略与俄罗斯通过“虚假的消防水带”制造“不现实”相吻合，俄罗斯大规模的个人胡说八道就是如此。61

But as Wylie’s point about “perspecticide” indicates, Cambridge Analytica’s overall goal was grander than targeting so-called neurotics. It sought to spread the very indifference to truth that lay at the heart of its interactions with its targets. For example, Wylie argues that Steve Bannon was using Cambridge Analytica as a psychological warfare tool in his alt-right, culture war insurgency, deliberately targeting Americans to cause “confusion, manipulation, and deception. Truth was replaced,” Wylie said, “by alternative narratives and virtual realities.”59 For Bannon, Wylie explained, the remaking of society starts with deliberately causing “chaos and disruption.” The undermining of truth and its replacement with nonsense was a key tool towards that end.60 In short, the ultimate goal of Cambridge Analytica’s bullshit was not merely to promote Trump directly, but also to undermine the very notions of truth and certainty, to instead promote consistent uncertainty to the neurotic and conspiratorial among us and thereby cause chaos that could be exploited by Trump and the alt-right. Of course, such tactics dovetail with the production of “unreality” through a “firehose of falsehood” found in the Russian iteration of masspersonal bullshitting.61

恐惧诉求可能看起来并不完全友好和善意，但剑桥分析公司的员工也非常善于交谈。怀利回忆起电话飞客的胡说八道，他、当时的首席执行官亚历山大·尼克斯、班农和其他人利用他们收集的数据给美国个人打电话。这些人以剑桥大学的调查研究人员为借口，继续问一些他们已经根据受害者的资料知道答案的特定问题，包括关于他们最喜欢的电视节目和宗教信仰的愉快玩笑。这些电话是对资料中收集的数据的一种非正式验证，但正如怀利所说，也很有趣。他写道，这些电话让班农很高兴：“当我看向班农时，他脸上挂着灿烂的笑容。” 62

Fear appeals may not seem entirely friendly and kind, but Cambridge Analytica employees were also quite good at conversation. In a throwback to phone phreak bullshitting, Wylie recalls that he, then-CEO Alexander Nix, Bannon, and others made calls to individual Americans using the data they had collected. Using the pretext of being survey researchers from the University of Cambridge, the men would proceed to ask particular questions to which they already knew the answers based on the profiles they had compiled about their victims, including jovial banter about their favorite TV shows and religious beliefs. The calls served as a kind of informal validation of the data collected in the profiles but also, as Wylie recounts, good fun too. He writes that the phone calls pleased Bannon: “When I looked over at Bannon, he had a huge grin on his face.”62

如果说剑桥分析公司的“胡说八道”团队有队长的话，那一定是尼克斯。记者和学者分析了尼克斯为剑桥分析公司所做的推销，讨论了从谎言中找出真相的难度。正如英国第四频道的报道所说，我们永远无法确定尼克斯提供的是“真实的背景，还是虚张声势”。63但在与潜在客户的友好晚餐中，尼克斯提出了一套关于胡说八道的理论，认为剑桥分析公司所发布的信息“不一定是真实的，只要人们相信就行”。64不仅适用于剑桥分析公司的信息，也适用于该公司关于自身有效性的主张。尼克斯最喜欢的有效沟通例子之一就是胡说八道。这位富有的英国人提出了两条信息来阻止人们进入私人海滩。一条是标志牌上写着“此处以外为私人财产”。与这个仅仅是信息性的标志牌相反，尼克斯提出了一条旨在改变行为的信息：“警告：发现鲨鱼——禁止进入”。65在禁区内有鲨鱼吗？谁知道呢？尼克斯对此漠不关心。他这么做的目的是改变潜在游泳者的行为，而不是告知他们。

If there is a captain of Cambridge Analytica’s Bullshit Team, it has to be Nix. Reporters and academics analyzing his sales pitches for Cambridge Analytica discuss the difficulty in picking out truth from deception. As the UK’s Channel 4 report puts it, we are never sure if Nix is offering “true backdrop, or just bravado.”63 But over a friendly dinner with a prospective client, Nix offers up a theory of bullshit, arguing that the messages that Cambridge Analytica produces “don’t necessarily need to be true, as long as they’re believed.”64 Such can be said not only of Cambridge Analytica’s messages but also of the company’s claims about its own effectiveness. One of Nix’s favorite examples of effective communication is pure bullshit. The wealthy Briton offers two messages to keep people off of a private beach. One is a sign that says, “Private Property Beyond This Point.” In contrast to this merely informational sign, Nix offers one meant to change behaviors: “Warning: Shark Sighted—Keep Out.”65 Are there sharks in the restricted part of the ocean? Who knows? Nix is indifferent. The point is to change behaviors of would-be swimmers, not to inform them.

尼克斯最令人印象深刻的胡说八道或许就是他追求班农的时候。怀利描述了尼克斯通常的吸引客户的方式，即带他们去伦敦的高档餐厅和私人俱乐部，但这种方式对班农不起作用。尼克斯意识到“包括班农在内的每个人都渴望一个未实现的秘密自我。”班农认为自己不仅仅是一个网站编辑或政治顾问，还是一个哲学家和新版右翼政治的知识分子。怀利写道：“为了赢得他的支持，尼克斯需要帮助他实现成为伟大思想家的梦想。”因此，尼克斯没有在班农访问期间在剑桥分析公司的伦敦办公室与他会面，而是提议他们在剑桥大学附近的公司办公室见面，那里的“哥特式大厅和广阔的绿地”对班农更有吸引力，而不是尼克斯通常为伦敦的潜在客户提供的“豪华俱乐部、昂贵的葡萄酒和粗雪茄”。唯一的问题是，剑桥分析公司在剑桥没有办公室。所以尼克斯租了一个地方，自己建了一个。每当班农来的时候，一队剑桥分析公司的员工——以及一些临时雇来的替身——就会搬到剑桥分析公司的剑桥办公室，在那里他们会为班农上演一场精彩的表演，而班农似乎并不注意到有些电脑甚至没有插上电源，有些临时员工不会说英语。怀利总结说，这个“波将金遗址”

Perhaps the most impressive example of Nix’s bullshit came when he wooed Bannon. Wylie describes how Nix’s usual approach to wooing clients by taking them to posh restaurants and private clubs in London was not working with Bannon. Nix realized “that everyone, including Bannon, suffers the yearning of an unfulfilled secret self.” Bannon thought of himself not merely as a website editor or political advisor but as a philosopher and an intellectual of a new version of right-wing politics. “To win him over,” Wylie writes, “Nix would need to help him achieve his fantasy of becoming a thinker of big thoughts.” So instead of meeting Bannon at Cambridge Analytica’s London office during his visits, Nix proposed that they meet instead at the firm’s office just down the road from Cambridge University, whose “Gothic halls and sprawling greens” were more appealing to Bannon than the “fancy clubs, expensive wines, and fat cigars” that Nix usually trotted out for would-be clients in London. The only problem? Cambridge Analytica did not have an office in Cambridge. So, Nix rented out a space and created one. Whenever Bannon came to town, a contingent of Cambridge Analytica workers—along with some stand-ins hired just for the day—would relocate to Cambridge Analytica’s Cambridge office where they would put on a great show for Bannon, who didn’t seem to notice that some of the computers weren’t even plugged in and some of the stand-in employees didn’t speak English. This “Potemkin Site,” Wylie concludes,

完美体现了剑桥分析公司的核心和灵魂，它完美地向人们展示了他们想看到的东西，无论真实与否，以此来塑造他们的行为——这一策略非常有效，甚至像史蒂夫·班农这样的人也可能被亚历山大·尼克斯这样的人愚弄。66

perfectly encapsulated the heart and soul of Cambridge Analytica, which perfected the art of showing people what they want to see, whether real or not, to mold their behavior—a strategy that was so effective, even a man like Steve Bannon could be fooled by someone like Alexander Nix.66

穿透

Penetrating

对俄罗斯 IRA 的调查报道揭示了一些相当无聊但极其重要的事情：在那里工作是一份工作。和许多工作一样，那里也有绩效指标。这些指标揭示了短期和长期的渗透目标。

Investigative reporting on Russia’s IRA revealed something quite boring, but extremely important: working there was a job. And like many jobs, there are performance metrics. Such metrics reveal short-term and long-term penetration goals.

短期内，IRA 员工必须达到一定的绩效指标：管理一定数量的账户，获得社交媒体粉丝，在媒体上发表一定数量的评论。就像搭讪艺术家讨论的“游戏”一样，目标是尽可能多地吸引漂亮女性，IRA 员工必须通过一定数量的帖子传达他们的信息。一份讨论互联网研究机构工作条件的报告显示，员工“每 12 小时轮班必须在互联网论坛上发表 135 条评论，并且会为他们提供五个关键词，以增加搜索引擎的关注度。” 67一些 IRA 员工负责少数几个 Facebook 群组，目标是在一个月内获得 500 名粉丝。其他人必须维护 10 个 Twitter 帐户并管理这些帐户的粉丝，有时粉丝数量多达数万。

In the short term, the IRA employees had to achieve certain performance metrics: manage a number of accounts, gain social media followers, post a certain number of comments to media outlets. Like the “game” that pickup artists discuss, where the goal is to get in front of as many attractive women as possible, the IRA employees had to get their messages out in a specified number of posts. A report discussing work conditions at the Internet Research Agency reveals that employees “were required to make 135 comments per twelve-hour shift, working in internet forums and that they would be provided with five keywords to feature in all posts to encourage search engine pickup.”67 Some IRA employees were responsible for a handful of Facebook groups, with the goal of gaining five hundred followers in a month. Others had to maintain ten Twitter accounts and manage those accounts’ followers, sometimes numbering in the tens of thousands.

除了增加社交媒体的关注者之外，渗透的标志是让人们采取行动。美国司法部对互联网研究机构的起诉书详细说明了 IRA 如何成功说服一些个人和团体在佛罗里达州支持特朗普竞选活动的人士，包括多名特朗普竞选官员，在现实世界中采取行动，例如策划和举行政治集会。68此外，美国参议院情报特别委员会发现，俄罗斯人还能够说服美国黑人开设自卫课程：

Beyond increasing followers on social media, a marker of penetration is getting people to take actions. The US Department of Justice indictment against the Internet Research Agency details how the IRA successfully convinced a number of individuals and groups who supported the Trump campaign in Florida, including several Trump campaign officials, to take action in the real world, such as planning and holding political rallies.68 In addition, the US Senate Select Committee on Intelligence found that the Russians were also able to convince Black Americans to set up self-defense courses:

IRA 特工还牵头并资助了一项自卫计划，该计划要求非裔美国培训师在他们的社区教授课程，并收取报酬。作为这项行动的一部分，一名非裔美国活动家获得了大约 700 美元的报酬，在 IRA 管理的“BlackFist”Facebook 页面的支持下，在当地公园教授 12 节自卫课程。69

IRA operatives also spearheaded and funded a self-defense program that entailed African-American trainers being paid to teach courses in their communities. As part of this operation, an African-American activist was paid roughly $700 to teach 12 self-defense classes in a local park under the auspices of the IRA-administered “BlackFist” Facebook page.69

说服美国人在选举后继续采取实际行动。据Politico报道，爱尔兰共和军特工成功说服反特朗普活动人士将 Facebook 活动页面的控制权交给他们，以换取他们在特朗普上任后赞助一场现场抗议活动。70

Convincing Americans to take real world actions continued after the election. As a Politico story reports, IRA operatives were able to convince anti-Trump activists to give them control of their Facebook events pages in exchange for sponsoring a live protest against Trump after he took office.70

但是，当然，除了获得更多的追随者或说服人们采取行动之外，俄罗斯行动的长期目标是影响美国的民主进程。2016 年，这意味着破坏克林顿的竞选活动（以及任何其他反俄政治候选人）。71关于俄罗斯行动影响程度的争论仍在继续（我们将在下一章讨论影响问题），但至少，美国情报官员发现俄罗斯行动产生了一些影响。“我们评估俄罗斯情报部门会认为他们的选举影响活动至少是一次合格的成功，因为他们被认为有能力影响公众讨论。” 72合格程度需要数年时间才能弄清楚，但就爱尔兰共和军作为美国社会的一面镜子而言，它成功地让人们对美国的选举进程、政府官员的动机以及缓解该国有时暴力紧张局势的可能性产生了怀疑。至少，如果俄罗斯社会工程的目标是破坏真相、知识、专业知识，机构，最重要的是制造一场混乱的废话风暴，以便日后利用来促进俄罗斯的利益，那么渗透就成功了，其后果一直持续到今天。

But, of course, beyond gaining more followers or convincing people to take actions, the long-term goal of the Russian operation was to affect the democratic process in the United States. In 2016, that meant undermining the Clinton campaign (as well as any other anti-Russia political candidates).71 The debate about the extent of the Russian operation’s effects is still ongoing (and we will address the question of effects in the next chapter), but at the very least, US intelligence officials found that the Russian operation had some effect. “We assess the Russian intelligence services would have seen their election influence campaign as at least a qualified success because of their perceived ability to impact public discussion.”72 The extent of the qualification will take years to figure out, but insofar as the IRA held up a mirror to American society, it succeeded in casting doubt on American electoral processes, the motives of government officials, and on the possibilities of easing the sometimes violent tensions in the country. At the very least, if the goal of Russian social engineering is to undermine truth, knowledge, expertise, institutions, and above all to create a chaotic bullshit-storm that can be exploited later to promote Russia interests, then the penetration was successful, with the consequences continuing to play out to this day.

至于剑桥分析公司，其最臭名昭著的说法是其能够“微观定位”具有社会影响的个人。该公司声称，这种定位得益于对受众思想的深入渗透，这是一种称为心理统计学的受众细分方法。正如亚历山大·尼克斯所说，剑桥分析公司的深入欲望是“探究比简单的信息搜索更深层次的动机”。73它的目标不是理性的辩论，而是引发情绪，尤其是恐惧。尼克斯的同事马克·特恩布尔声称：“我们的工作是比任何人都更深入地了解那些真正根深蒂固的潜在恐惧[和]担忧是什么。” 74该公司通过各种破坏性努力收集的数据被分析用于心理定位，根据开放性或神经质等共同特质将人们划分开来。75

As for Cambridge Analytica, its most notorious claim was about its ability to “microtarget” individuals with societal-level implications. Such targeting was aided by what the company claimed was a deep penetration into the minds of audience members, a method of audience segmentation called psychographics. As Alexander Nix put it, Cambridge Analytica’s penetrating desire was “to probe an altogether deeper motivation” than simple information-seeking.73 Rather than rational debate, its goal was to trigger emotions, particularly fear. “Our job,” claimed Nix’s colleague Mark Turnbull, “is to drop the bucket further down the well than anybody else, to understand what are those really deep-seated, underlying fears [and] concerns.”74 The data the company gathered through its various trashing efforts were analyzed for the purposes of psychographic targeting, dividing people up by shared qualities such as openness or neuroticism.75

剑桥分析公司的销售人员声称，这种分析可以实现高精度信息传递。正如举报人布列塔尼·凯泽回忆的那样，她向潜在客户的宣传结束时说：“剑桥分析公司提供的是，在正确的时间，从正确的渠道，向正确的目标受众传递正确的信息。这就是你取胜的秘诀。” 76她回忆说，尼克斯在向尼日利亚政党的宣传中详细说明了这些做法，承诺剑桥分析公司可以“针对个别村庄或公寓楼，甚至直接针对特定人群”，向目标受众发送专门设计的政治信息。77

Such profiling, Cambridge Analytica sales staff claimed, leads to high precision messaging. As the whistleblower Brittany Kaiser recalls, her pitch to potential clients ended: “what Cambridge Analytica offers is the right message for the right target audience from the right source on the right channel at the right time. And that’s how you win.”76 As she recalls, Nix specified these practices in their pitch to a Nigerian political party, promising that Cambridge Analytica could “address individual villages or apartment blocks, even zoom right down to particular people” with political messages designed specifically for the intended targets.77

就像之前的大规模社会工程师一样，剑桥分析公司用子弹的比喻来解释其渗透能力，将其数据科学家描述为一支“内部军队”，拥有“数据军火库”，使他们能够“激光瞄准”他们的精确“目标”。78该论文昔日的子弹似乎被聚焦光所取代——也许更适合我们这个光纤网络和 LED 屏幕的时代。然而，尼克斯也经常使用男性的性征服隐喻。据怀利说，尼克斯用性征服来描述一切：在谈判的早期阶段，双方“互相摸索”或“把手指伸进去”。当交易达成时，他会大喊，“现在我们做爱了！” 79无论沟通的是子弹还是阴茎，剑桥分析公司都表现出与旧式大众社会工程师相同的渗透欲望，再加上黑客社会工程师更有针对性的关注。

Like the mass social engineers before it, Cambridge Analytica used bullet metaphors to explain its penetration, describing its data scientists as an “in-house army” armed with an “arsenal of data” that allowed them to “laser in” on their exact “targets.”78 The paper bullets of yesteryear are replaced, it seems, with focused light—perhaps more fitting for our time of fiber-optic networks and LED screens. However, Nix also often used the male, sexual conquest metaphor. According to Wylie, Nix described everything in terms of sexual conquest: in the early stages of negotiations, the two sides were “feeling each other up” or “slipping in a finger.” When a deal closed, he’d exclaim, “now we’re fucking!”79 Regardless of whether the communication was a bullet or a penis, Cambridge Analytica demonstrates the same desire to penetrate that the older mass social engineers had, coupled with the more targeted focus of hacker social engineers.

而且，与大众社会工程师和专业社会工程渗透测试人员一样，剑桥分析公司必须报告结果。在特朗普赢得 2016 年总统大选后，该公司的员工成为广告和技术会议中备受追捧（尽管存在争议）的演讲者。2017 年，剑桥分析公司数字部门负责人 Molly Schweickert 向 d3con 介绍了他们的特朗普竞选策略摘要，Nix 则在在线营销摇滚明星大会上发表了演讲。80这两次演讲都在德国——一个拥有强大数据保护法的国家——因此观众似乎对剑桥分析公司处理的海量数据感到吃惊，并向这两名员工提出了至关重要的问题。然而，Schweickert 和 Nix 当时都沉浸在胜利的喜悦中，因此他们顶住了批评，自豪地报告了他们的渗透成功。

And, like both the mass social engineers and professional social engineer penetration testers, Cambridge Analytica had to report results. After Trump’s victory in the 2016 presidential election, the company’s employees were highly sought after—if controversial—speakers at advertising and technology conferences. In 2017, Cambridge Analytica Head of Digital Molly Schweickert presented a summary of their Trump campaign strategy to d3con, and Nix presented at the Online Marketing Rockstars conference.80 Both of these presentations were in Germany—a state with strong data protection laws—so the audience members seemed taken aback by the sheer glut of data Cambridge Analytica was working with, and they had critical questions for the two employees. However, both Schweickert and Nix were at the time basking in the glow of victory, so they fended off the criticisms and proudly reported on their penetration successes.

自 2016 年以来大规模个人社会工程

Masspersonal Social Engineering since 2016

我们关注互联网研究机构和剑桥分析公司在 2016 年大选中的所作所为，因为它们有据可查。尽管这些案例很重要，但面对过去六年多年来，这些方法似乎已经过时了。在这里，我们指出一些近期潜在的大规模个人社会工程学的例子。我们说“潜在”是因为我们还没有 2016 年后的所有数据，但我们怀疑其中存在大规模个人社会工程学的所有元素（破坏、借口、胡说八道和渗透，以及人际和大众传播的灵活组合）。考虑到我们的启发式方法，让我们考虑一些近期潜在的大规模个人社会工程学实例。

We focused on the 2016 election efforts by the Internet Research Agency and Cambridge Analytica because they are well documented. As important as those cases are, in the face of the past six years, they may seem dated. Here, we point to more recent examples of potential masspersonal social engineering. We say “potential” because we do not yet have all the data on the post-2016 efforts, but we suspect all the elements of masspersonal social engineering (trashing, pretexting, bullshitting, and penetrating, with a fluid mix of interpersonal and mass communication) are present in them. With our heuristic in mind, let’s consider some more recent, potential instances of masspersonal social engineering.

俄罗斯

Russia

首先，俄罗斯似乎在 2016 年大选后继续进行大规模个人社会工程活动。美国国家情报总监办公室 2018 年 12 月的一份报告详细介绍了俄罗斯旨在影响 2018 年中期选举结果的“影响活动”和“信息宣传活动”。81俄罗斯的行动遵循了上述相同的策略，包括使用借口（空壳公司网络来掩盖其参与，数千个虚假社交媒体资料）和针对特定群体发送旨在激起政治、种族和文化分歧的信息。根据国家情报总监的报告，2018 年的不同之处在于，俄罗斯人没有像 2016 年支持唐纳德·特朗普那样试图在选举中支持一方或另一方，而是在政治光谱的各个方面都采取立场，试图制造普遍的政治混乱、困惑和分裂。82虽然我们不知道这些行动的影响程度，但我们知道“俄罗斯在 2018 年对民主对话的干扰似乎比 2016 年更多，而不是更少”，而且这种威胁被认为严重到足以让美国军方的网络司令部采取行动，以破坏爱尔兰共和军针对 2018 年大选的行动。83

First, the Russians appear to have continued their masspersonal social engineering efforts after the 2016 election. A December 2018 report from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence detailed Russian “influence activities” and “messaging campaigns” meant to sway the 2018 mid-term election results.81 The Russian operations followed much the same playbook detailed above, including using pretexts (a network of shell companies to hide their involvement, thousands of fake social media profiles) and efforts to target particular groups with messages meant to inflame political, racial, and cultural divisions. The difference in 2018, according to the DNI report, was that instead of trying to support one side or the other in the election, as they had in 2016 with their support for Donald Trump, the Russians took positions on all sides of the political spectrum in an attempt to sow general political chaos, confusion, and division.82 While we do not know the full extent of the impact of these operations, we do know that “Russia appears to have engaged in more disruptions to democratic dialogue in 2018 than in 2016, not fewer” and that the threat was perceived as serious enough for the military’s US Cyber Command to undertake operations to disrupt IRA operations targeting the 2018 election.83

俄罗斯的行动持续到了 2020 年。在 2020 年美国总统大选前不到两个月，美国财政部对“四名与俄罗斯有联系的个人实施制裁，原因是他们试图影响美国选举进程。”其中最引人注目的是安德烈·杰尔卡奇，美国称他为“乌克兰议会议员”和“十多年来活跃的俄罗斯特工，与俄罗斯情报部门保持密切联系”。美国指控杰尔卡奇“开展了一场秘密的影响运动，主要是在即将到来的 2020 年总统大选中散布有关美国官员的虚假和未经证实的叙述”，并且“几乎肯定以美国投票民众、美国知名人士和美国政府成员为目标。” 84

The Russian effort continued into 2020. Less than two months before the 2020 US presidential election, the US Treasury Department sanctioned “four Russia-linked individuals for attempting to influence the US electoral process.” Most prominent among them was Andrii Derkach, whom the US described as “a member of the Ukrainian Parliament” and “an active Russian agent for over a decade, maintaining close connections with the Russian Intelligence Services.” The US alleged that Derkach had “waged a covert influence campaign centered on cultivating false and unsubstantiated narratives concerning US officials in the upcoming 2020 presidential election” and had “almost certainly targeted the US voting populace, prominent US persons, and members of the US government.”84

德尔卡奇的目标是当时的总统候选人乔·拜登和他的儿子亨特。政府声称，德尔卡奇和他的同伙通过“美国媒体、美国社交媒体平台和有影响力的美国人士”进行胡说八道，散布“误导性和毫无根据的指控，称美国现任和前任官员在乌克兰从事腐败、洗钱和非法政治影响”。德尔卡奇和他的同伙以“媒体幌子公司”的形式为借口，例如 Nabu Leaks、Era-Media TOV、Skeptic TOV 和 Only News。85德尔卡奇利用这些幌子，部分是为了帮助“公开泄露的电话”，作为拜登涉嫌腐败的证据。86德尔卡奇后来还与亨特·拜登笔记本电脑故事有关，该故事似乎是特朗普竞选团队在 2020 年大选期间的“十月惊喜”。人们不禁注意到，此次事件与 2016 年窃取克林顿竞选邮件和维基解密的“黑客泄密”行动有相似之处，只是这一次，所谓的“地狱硬盘”才是美国右翼媒体关注的焦点。87

The targets of Derkach were then-presidential candidate Joe Biden and his son, Hunter. The government claimed that Derkach and his associates engaged in bullshitting through “US media, US-based social media platforms, and influential US persons,” spreading “misleading and unsubstantiated allegations that current and former US officials engaged in corruption, money laundering, and unlawful political influence in Ukraine.” Derkach and his associates used pretexts in the form of “media front companies” such as Nabu Leaks, Era-Media TOV, Skeptic TOV, and Only News as part of their effort.85 Derkach used these fronts, in part, to help in “publicizing leaked phone calls” meant to serve as evidence of the Bidens’ alleged corruption.86 Derkach was also later linked to the Hunter Biden laptop story that seemed meant to serve as the Trump campaign’s “October surprise” during the 2020 election. One cannot help but notice the similarities to the 2016 “hack and leak” operation involving stolen Clinton campaign emails and WikiLeaks, only this time it was the so-called “hard drive from hell” that was the focus of American right-wing media.87

这次最新行动的总体影响仍然难以评估。可以肯定地说，它确实产生了重大影响。但这种影响可能与俄罗斯人的意图相反。此次行动针对的知名人士和政府官员包括特朗普总统的私人律师鲁迪·朱利安尼，以及两位共和党参议员，爱荷华州的查克·格拉斯利和威斯康星州的罗恩·约翰逊。据报道，朱利安尼于 2019 年 12 月与德尔卡奇及其一名同伙会面，试图找到拜登父子的罪证。据报道，德尔卡奇的同伙引发了格拉斯利和约翰逊领导的参议院对拜登父子在乌克兰交易的调查。88美国财政部在 2020 年 9 月声称，该调查以及在乌克兰进行的平行调查“旨在在选举日之前完成”，目的是破坏候选人拜登的当选机会。89当然，特朗普总统推动乌克兰调查拜登父子是他于 2020 年 1 月首次被弹劾的理由之一。90无论是乌克兰调查还是参议院调查，都没有发现拜登父子有任何不当行为的实质性证据。91当然，亨特·拜登笔记本电脑事件几乎立即就失败了，在主流媒体中几乎没有引起关注，而主要社交媒体平台一度禁止用户分享该事件的链接。92最终，获得当时总统私人律师的合作以及美国参议院的调查产生了重大影响。它们是否最终损害了特朗普 2020 年的连任前景尚不得而知。但它们似乎肯定没有帮助：尽管俄罗斯做出了努力，但特朗普还是输掉了大选。

The overall impact of this most recent campaign is still difficult to assess. It seems safe to say that it did indeed have a significant impact. But that impact was likely the opposite of what the Russians had intended. The prominent persons and government officials targeted in the operation included President Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, as well as two GOP Senators, Chuck Grassley of Iowa and Ron Johnson of Wisconsin. Giuliani is reported to have met in December 2019 with Derkach and one of his associates in an effort to find incriminating evidence on the Bidens. Derkach’s associate is reported to have sparked a Senate investigation led by Grassley and Johnson into the Bidens’ dealings in Ukraine.88 The US Treasury claimed in September 2020 that that investigation, along with a parallel investigation carried out in Ukraine, was “designed to culminate prior to election day” with the intended effect of undermining candidate Biden’s election chances.89 Of course, President Trump’s push for Ukraine to investigate the Bidens was one of the grounds for his first impeachment in January 2020.90 Neither the Ukraine investigation, nor the Senate investigation, uncovered any substantial evidence of wrongdoing on the part of the Bidens.91 And, of course, the Hunter Biden laptop story fizzled almost immediately, gaining little traction in the mainstream press while major social media platforms for a time blocked users from sharing links to it.92 In the end, getting the cooperation of the then-president’s personal lawyer and an investigation out of the US Senate are significant impacts. Whether they ended up hurting Trump’s 2020 prospects for reelection is unknown. But they certainly seem not to have helped: despite the Russian efforts, Trump lost the election.

伊朗

Iran

俄罗斯并不是唯一一个被指控试图干预 2020 年美国大选的外国国家行为者。2020 年 8 月，国家情报总监还警告称，中国和伊朗正试图利用网络影响力活动来制造分裂，破坏人们对即将举行的大选的信心。93在这两者中，我们对伊朗的努力了解最多，因为坦率地说，他们被抓了两次。在这两起案件中，美国政府都指责伊朗传播胡说八道的信息，包括“恐吓选民的电子邮件和传播与美国大选有关的宣传”。94

Russia was not the only foreign state actor accused of attempting to interfere in the 2020 US election. In August 2020, the DNI also warned that China and Iran were attempting to use online influence campaigns to sow division and undermine confidence in the upcoming election.93 Of the two, we know the most about the Iranian efforts because, quite frankly, they got caught. Twice. In both cases, the US government accused Iran of spreading bullshit messages, including “voter intimidation emails and dissemination of US election-related propaganda.”94

第一起事件发生在 10 月中旬，即选举前几周，佛罗里达州和阿拉斯加州的登记民主党人开始收到伊朗特工发来的电子邮件，他们假装是支持特朗普的“骄傲男孩”。电子邮件告诉这些选民，“骄傲男孩”已经获得了投票基础设施的访问权限，知道收件人是民主党人，并威胁说，如果收件人不改党派为共和党并投票给特朗普，“我们就会找上你”。95据称，这些伊朗人从事破坏活动，从公共网络、私人供应商处获取选民登记信息，并利用选举相关网站的漏洞。96这引发了联邦调查局的调查，几天之内就发现，这些电子邮件的背后是代表伊朗工作的黑客，而不是“骄傲男孩” 。97

In the first instance, beginning in mid-October, only a few weeks before the election, registered Democrats in Florida and Alaska began receiving emails from Iranian operatives pretexting as Trump-supporting “Proud Boys.” The emails told these voters that the Proud Boys had gained access to voting infrastructure, knew that the individual was a Democrat, and threatened “we will come after you” if the recipient didn’t change their party affiliation to Republican and vote for Trump.95 The Iranians allegedly engaged in trashing, obtaining voter registration information from the public web, from private vendors, and through exploitation of vulnerabilities in election-related websites.96 This sparked an FBI investigation that within a couple of days revealed that hackers working on behalf of Iran had been behind the emails, not the Proud Boys.97

在第二起案件中，联邦调查局指控伊朗在选举后发起了针对联邦和州执法部门、网络安全和选举官员以及投票机制造商高管的在线威胁和恐吓活动。在本案中，12 月中旬出现了一个名为“人民的敌人”的网站，该网站列出了一份名单，这些名单上的人员被指控帮助扭转了当时的总统特朗普的选举结果。该网站包括这些人的照片，照片上叠加了十字准线，一些人认为这是在呼吁暴力。华盛顿邮报称，这份“黑名单”在社交媒体上被分享，使用了#remembertheirfaces 和#NoQuarterForTraitors 等标签。98我们也看到了这起案件中的借口。除了现在标准的虚假社交媒体角色外，伊朗黑客还被指控“创建了虚构的媒体网站并欺骗了合法的媒体网站”。99人民公敌名单被发布在多个网站上，并由至少十个社交媒体账户在多个平台上推广。技术分析显示，创建这些网站并发布信息的人“竭尽全力掩盖自己的身份”。100

In the second instance, the FBI accused Iran of being behind a post-election campaign of online threats and intimidation targeted at federal and state law enforcement, cybersecurity, and election officials, as well as executives of voting machine manufacturers. In this case, in mid-December a website titled, “Enemies of the People,” appeared that identified a list of individuals who were accused of having helped swing the election results against then-President Trump. The site included pictures of the individuals with crosshairs superimposed over them, which was interpreted by some as a call for violence. This “hit list,” as the Washington Post called it, “was shared on social media using the hashtags, #remembertheirfaces and #NoQuarterForTraitors.”98 We see pretexting in this case as well. In addition to the now-standard fake social media personas, the Iranian hackers are alleged to have “creat[ed] fictitious media sites and spoof[ed] legitimate media sites.”99 The Enemies of the People list was posted to several websites and promoted by at least ten social media accounts across multiple platforms. Technical analysis revealed that those who created the websites and posted the information “had gone to great lengths to mask their identity.”100

由于这两个组成部分的行动很快被识别并公开，因此这场运动是否对选举结果产生了重大影响仍不清楚。无论影响如何，伊朗的案例都具有重要意义，因为它使我们能够观察到俄罗斯以外的国家行为者对大规模个人社会工程元素的使用。它还表明这些元素有时是多么紧密地相互关联。每起事件都依赖于破坏、渗透和借口的复杂组合来传播废话信息。渗透与选举相关的网站使选民遭到破坏成为可能，而渗透骄傲男孩的电子邮件账户可能使选民发送借口恐吓信息成为可能。101 这些事件中的废话是通过大规模和有针对性的手段相结合的方式传播的。人民公敌名单是一个任何人都可以访问的网站，并使用多个域名和社交媒体账户进行放大，而借口骄傲男孩的电子邮件则更具针对性。最后，第一起事件表明，有时要理清行动的各个要素并真正了解正在发生的事情是多么困难。虽然美国政府最初认为一段宣传视频是假的，视频描述了黑客入侵选举相关网站以获取选民数据，但官员们后来得出结论，黑客确实入侵了这些网站。102入侵可以制造谎言。但有时，正如政府的初步评估应该提醒我们的那样，即使是一个声称入侵系统的谎言也可能和真正的入侵一样具有破坏性。

Whether this campaign had any significant impact on the outcome of the election remains unclear as these two component operations were quickly identified and outed publicly. Whatever the impact, the Iranian case is significant because it allows us to observe the use of the masspersonal social engineering elements by a state actor other than Russia. It also demonstrates how tightly interconnected those elements can sometimes be. Each incident relied on a complex combination of trashing, penetrating, and pretexting to spread bullshit messages. Penetration of election-related websites enabled the trashing of voters, while penetration of a Proud Boys email account may have enabled the sending of pretextual voter intimidation messages.101 The bullshit in these incidents was spread through a combination of mass and targeted means. The Enemies of the People list was a website accessible to anyone and amplified using multiple domains and social media accounts, while the pretextual Proud Boys emails were more individually targeted. Finally, the first incident indicates how difficult it can sometimes be to disentangle the elements of an operation and truly understand what is going on. While the US government initially thought a propaganda video depicting the hacking of election-related websites to obtain voter data was fake, officials later concluded that the hackers had indeed breached those sites.102 Penetration can enable bullshitting. But sometimes, as the government’s initial assessment should remind us, even a bullshit claim to have penetrated a system might be as damaging as a real breach.

国内大规模个人社会工程学

Domestic Masspersonal Social Engineering

剑桥分析公司可能不复存在，但它的策略仍然存在于当代政治传播公司和运营中。

Cambridge Analytica may be no more, but its tactics live on in contemporary political communication firms and operations.

2020 年，斯坦福互联网观察站根据 Facebook 的数据，发布了一份对位于德克萨斯州奥斯汀的政治咨询公司 Rally Forge 的分析报告。103当年，Facebook 删除了与该公司相关的账户，原因是这些账户使用了以下借口：包括由假人设立的页面。正如《华盛顿邮报》报道的那样，“Facebook 得出结论，Rally Forge ……正在‘代表’ Turning Point Action 工作，而 Turning Point Action 是 Turning Point USA 的附属机构，Turning Point USA 是一家总部位于凤凰城的著名保守派青年组织。” 104

In 2020, based on data from Facebook, the Stanford Internet Observatory released an analysis of the Austin, Texas-based political consulting firm Rally Forge.103 That year, Facebook had removed accounts associated with that firm due to their use of pretexts, including pages set up by fake persons. As the Washington Post reported, “Rally Forge . . . was ‘working on behalf’ of Turning Point Action, an affiliate of Turning Point USA, the prominent conservative youth organization based in Phoenix, Facebook concluded.”104

斯坦福互联网观察站利用 Facebook 数据，追踪了 Facebook、Instagram 和 Twitter 上运营的账户网络。他们的分析显示，Rally Forge 账户使用借口和胡说八道，目的是通过营造保守草根运动的假象来渗透。正如报告所述，Rally Forge 的借口制造的信息“看似由真正的草根力量驱动，实际上是由一个未公开的组织赞助的，目的是影响公众舆论。” 105 Rally Forge 的胡说八道包括家庭友好的信息，如“带你的孩子去打猎”，以及否认气候变化、将国会众议员亚历山大·奥卡西奥·科尔特斯称为“入侵物种”或嘲笑素食主义的信息。该报告还表明，Rally Forge 在渗透方面取得了一些成功，“截至 2020 年 10 月 10 日，36 个 Facebook 页面共有 300,161 名粉丝。” 106

The Stanford Internet Observatory took the Facebook data and traced a web of accounts operating across Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Their analysis reveals that Rally Forge accounts used pretexts and bullshitting with the goal of penetrating in the form of building the appearance of conservative grassroots movements. As the report states, Rally Forge’s pretexts created messaging “that appears to be driven by authentic grassroots energy is in fact sponsored by an undisclosed organization looking to sway public opinion.”105 The bullshitting on the part of Rally Forge included family-friendly messages, like “Take your kids hunting,” alongside messages denying climate change, labeling Congressional Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez an “invasive species,” or mocking veganism. The report also indicates some success in penetration, with the “combined 36 Facebook Pages [having] 300,161 followers as of October 10, 2020.”106

保守派团体并不是唯一参与潜在大规模个人社会工程的团体。人们也发现左翼团体使用这些策略。《纽约时报》和《华盛顿邮报》都报道过，阿拉巴马州的几个进步活动家团体利用借口破坏共和党参议员候选人罗伊·摩尔的候选资格。107网络安全公司 Yonder（前身为 New Knowledge）利用了它在分析 2016 年俄罗斯活动时学到的知识，并将其应用于阿拉巴马州的小规模活动。Yonder 创建了一个 Facebook 页面，借口是：“他们假扮为保守的阿拉巴马人，试图利用它分裂共和党人，甚至支持一位候选人来吸引摩尔先生的选票。” 108另一名活动家马特·奥斯本（Matt Osborne）以另一个借口创建了一个 Facebook 页面。这个名为“Dry Alabama”的页面将摩尔的竞选活动与禁止阿拉巴马州禁止酒精饮料，希望这样的联系能吓倒支持商业的共和党选民。109

Conservative groups aren’t the only ones engaging in potential masspersonal social engineering. Left-leaning groups have also been discovered using these tactics. Both the New York Times and the Washington Post have reported that several groups of progressive activists in Alabama used pretexts to undermine the candidacy of Roy Moore, a Republican candidate for the Senate.107 The cyber security firm Yonder (formerly named New Knowledge) took what it learned when it analyzed the 2016 Russian efforts and applied it on a smaller scale in Alabama. Yonder created a Facebook page with a pretext: “they posed as conservative Alabamians, using it to try to divide Republicans and even to endorse a write-in candidate to draw votes from Mr. Moore.”108 Another activist, Matt Osborne, created a Facebook page based on another pretext. The page, “Dry Alabama,” associated Moore’s campaign with a campaign to ban alcohol in Alabama, hoping that such an association would frighten pro-business Republican voters.109

这些努力可能是由伯明翰计划协调的，该计划旨在将俄罗斯式的虚假信息策略应用于美国政治。110正如老一代大众社会工程师和当代黑客社会工程师所认为的那样，活动家使用这些策略的理由是共和党人从大众个人社会工程中获益，因此民主党人也可能受益。正如奥斯本对《纽约时报》所说， “如果你不这样做，你就是在徒劳无功。你有道德义务这样做——不惜一切代价。” 111

These efforts may have been coordinated by Project Birmingham, an overarching effort to apply Russian-style disinformation tactics in American politics.110 Much as the older mass social engineers and more recent hacker social engineers argue, the justification by the activists using these tactics is that the Republicans are benefiting from masspersonal social engineering, so the Democrats may as well, too. As Osborne argued to the Times, “If you don’t do it, you’re fighting with one hand tied behind your back. You have a moral imperative to do this—to do whatever it takes.”111

有关 Rally Forge 或 Project Birmingham 的报告并未透露太多有关 masspersonal 社会工程破坏阶段的信息。我们无法确认，但可以假设这些行动收集了目标数据。在 Phunware 的案例中，这家软件公司被聘请开发特朗普/彭斯 2020 手机应用程序，我们对 masspersonal 社会工程式破坏实践有了很多了解。112秉承剑桥分析公司的精神，Phunware 破坏实践非常激进，沉迷于网上大量数据并收集了超过 10 亿个智能手机设备 ID 号。

The reports about Rally Forge or Project Birmingham do not reveal much about the trashing phase of masspersonal social engineering. We can’t confirm, but we can assume, that those operations gathered data on their targets. In the case of Phunware, a software company that was hired to develop the Trump/Pence 2020 mobile phone applications, we have a great deal of insight into masspersonal social engineering-style trashing practices.112 Carrying on in the spirit of Cambridge Analytica, Phunware trashing practices were aggressive, wallowing in the glut of data available online and collecting over a billion smartphone device ID numbers.

据《纽约客》报道，这些 ID 号“是从使用 Phunware 软件的手机和平板电脑中收集的”。然而，Phunware 还通过在线广告企业进行破坏，甚至在无法向互联网用户投放广告的情况下收集数据：

As the New Yorker reported, these ID numbers “were collected from phones and tablets that use Phunware’s software.” However, Phunware also trashed via online advertising ventures, gathering data even in cases where it was not able to serve ads to internet users:

据曾与该公司合作过的人士称，除了通过其软件获取的数据外，Phunware 还一直将其广告投放业务用作批发数据挖掘业务。通过收集和存储这些信息，该公司能够对这些设备上下载的每个应用程序以及用户为使用该应用程序而共享的任何注册数据进行相当全面的描述。113

According to people who have worked with the company, in addition to the data it obtains through its software, Phunware has been using its ad-placement business as a wholesale data-mining operation. . . . By collecting and storing this information, the company is able to compile a fairly comprehensive picture of every app downloaded on those devices, and any registration data a user has shared in order to use the app.113

此类诋毁与剑桥分析公司一样，都是为了追求微定位和深入洞察。Phunware 的宣传材料吹嘘其“拥有 1000 多个移动设备细分市场，营销人员可以利用这些细分市场在自己选择的平台内创建自定义受众。Phunware 细分市场分为六个配置文件维度，使营销人员能够快速创建受众。” 114

Such trashing is geared towards the same microtargeting, penetrating vision that Cambridge Analytica held. Phunware’s promotional materials boasted about its “1000+ mobile device segments that marketers can leverage to create custom audiences within the platform of their choice. Phunware segments are organized into six profile dimensions that enable marketers to quickly create audiences.”114

无论微目标定位是否有效，它无疑是 Phunware 等公司及其雇佣的政治运动的卖点。115有迹象表明，不仅是微目标定位，而且更广泛的大规模个人社交工程策略将在未来几年继续激增。记者、网络安全公司和学者最近的调查都指出，越来越多地被称为“雇佣虚假信息”的市场正在增长。例如，威胁情报公司 Recorded Future 的子公司 Insikt Group 在 2019 年的一项调查报告了俄罗斯地下论坛上虚假信息服务的可用性和可负担性。116但不仅仅是互联网角落里的俄罗斯网络犯罪分子愿意提供此类服务。越来越多的公关和营销公司也加入了这一行动。2021 年 1 月，“BuzzFeed 新闻评论……发现自 2011 年以来，至少有 27 项在线信息操作部分或全部归因于公关或营销公司。其中，仅 2019 年就发生了 19 起。” 117

Whether or not microtargeting works, it is certainly a selling point for firms like Phunware and the political campaigns that hire them.115 There is every indication that not just microtargeting, but the broader suite of masspersonal social engineering tactics will continue to proliferate in the years ahead. Recent investigations by journalists, cybersecurity companies, and academics all point to a growing market for what is increasingly being referred to as “disinformation for hire.” For example, a 2019 investigation by the Insikt Group, an arm of the threat intelligence company Recorded Future, reported on the availability and affordability of disinformation services on Russian underground forums.116 But it’s not just Russian cyber criminals in obscure corners of the internet willing to provide such services. There are an increasing number of public relations and marketing firms getting in on the action, too. In January 2021, “A BuzzFeed News review . . . found that since 2011, at least 27 online information operations have been partially or wholly attributed to PR or marketing firms. Of those, 19 occurred in 2019 alone.”117

虽然这听起来很糟糕，但牛津互联网研究所计算宣传项目同月发布的一份报告发现，问题可能更加普遍：

While that sounds bad, a report released that same month by the Computational Propaganda Project at the Oxford Internet Institute found that the problem might be even more widespread:

私营公司越来越多地提供操纵活动。去年，我们发现了 48 起私营公司代表政治参与者部署计算宣传的案例。自 2018 年以来，已有 65 多家公司提供计算宣传服务。总的来说，我们发现自 2009 年以来，雇用这些公司已花费近 6000 万美元。118

Private firms increasingly provide manipulation campaigns. Over the last year, we found forty-eight instances of private companies deploying computational propaganda on behalf of a political actor. Since 2018 there have been more than 65 firms offering computational propaganda as a service. In total, we have found almost US $60 million was spent on hiring these firms since 2009.118

他们将这种趋势称为“工业化虚假信息”。

It is a trend that they called “industrialized disinformation.”

结论

Conclusion

俄罗斯人或剑桥分析公司进行的社会工程是大规模个人化的。它利用了企业社交媒体的大规模个人化交流功能，从针对个人（史蒂夫·班农或约翰·波德斯塔）转向针对德克萨斯州选民或美国黑人等群体。下一刻，这些社会工程师会再次与个人接触，这次是在 Facebook、Twitter 或 Instagram 上，说服他们安排抗议或会议，从而利用他们作为代理人来建立更多的人群。交流在针对数千名受众的群发信息和针对较小目标群体的定制和个性化信息之间交替进行。

The social engineering conducted by the Russians or Cambridge Analytica was masspersonal. It took advantage of the masspersonal communicative affordances of corporate social media, moving from targeting an individual (Steve Bannon or John Podesta) to targeting crowds like voters in Texas or Black Americans. The next moment, these social engineers would engage with individuals again, this time on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram, convincing them to arrange protests or meetings, and thus using them as proxies to build even more crowds. The communication alternated between mass messages meant for audiences of thousands and customized and personalized messages for a smaller pool of targets.

这些策略直接来自黑客或电话飞客的剧本——垃圾、借口、胡说、渗透——经过数十年的人际欺骗技巧磨练。但这些野心当然让人想起了大众社会工程师，因为他们的目标是控制人群。

The tactics were straight out of the hacker or phone phreak playbook—trash, pretext, bullshit, penetrate—honed over decades of interpersonal con artistry. But the ambitions were, of course, redolent of the mass social engineers, aimed as they were at mastering crowds.

互联网研究机构和剑桥分析公司的活动提醒我们，在某种程度上，我们以前也经历过这种情况。正如我们在前几章中看到的，宣传、宣传、公共关系和同意工程都与国家安全有着深厚的联系，无论是在战时为国家服务，如两次世界大战，还是在冷战期间为保护民主免受邪恶外来者的入侵而做出的努力。剑桥分析公司对精确性的主张与爱德华·约翰逊在上世纪初基于详细的个人数据和“科学民意调查”对未决选民进行精确定位的梦想并无太大不同。豪斯是伍德罗·威尔逊的长期政治顾问。119爱尔兰共和军和剑桥分析公司的活动也让我们想起了俄罗斯和苏联数十年的“主动措施”。120但它们也应让我们想起我们现在所说的“战略沟通”与战时宣传的长期交织；美国在冷战期间的政治战争经历，包括干涉欧洲盟友的国内政治和选举；以及最近对利用社交媒体进行信息战的兴趣。121例如， 2010年，黑客组织匿名者窃取并公开发布了国防承包商 HBGary 的数万封电子邮件，使我们对军事承包商参与在线宣传和诽谤活动的情况有了一点了解。122第二年，我们了解到美国军方有兴趣开发他们所谓的“角色管理”技术，这种技术可以让一个操作员控制数十个社交媒体账户，目的都是操纵在线讨论。123正如我们所论证的那样，俄罗斯的行动和类似剑桥分析公司的努力很可能仍在发生，伊朗和 Phunware 现在也在开展类似的活动。事实上，随着新冠疫情造成的死亡人数不断上升，以及我们目睹特朗普及其支持者煽动的叛乱企图，情况现在可能会变得更糟。影响人们（无论是个人还是集体）听从自己命令的梦想由来已久——而且它不会很快消失。只要这些技术被描述为有效的，不管对错，其他人可能会继续采用和部署它们。

The Internet Research Agency and Cambridge Analytica activities remind us that, to a degree, we’ve been here before. As we saw in previous chapters, publicity, propaganda, public relations, and consent engineering all have deep ties to the national security state, whether in service to the state during wartime, as in the two world wars, or in efforts to safeguard democracy against incursions of nefarious outsiders during the Cold War. Cambridge Analytica’s claims to precision are not so different from the dreams of precision targeting of undecided voters based on detailed personal data and “scientific polling” held at the start of the last century by Edward M. House, Woodrow Wilson’s long-time political advisor.119 The IRA and Cambridge Analytica activities remind us too of decades of Russian and Soviet “active measures.”120 But they should also remind us of the longstanding intersections of what we now call “strategic communication” with wartime propaganda; the United States’s own experience with political warfare during the Cold War, including interference in the domestic politics and elections of European allies; and more recent interest in the weaponization of social media for information warfare.121 For example, in 2010, we got a small glimpse into the world of military contractor involvement in online propaganda and smear campaigns as a result of the hacker collective, Anonymous, exfiltrating and publicly releasing tens of thousands of emails from the defense contractor HBGary.122 The following year, we learned about the US military’s interest in developing technology for what they called “persona management,” which would allow one operator to control potentially dozens of social media accounts, all with the aim of manipulating online discussion.123 And as we have argued, Russian operations and Cambridge Analytica–like efforts are very likely still happening, with Iran and Phunware now operating similar campaigns. Indeed, things may well be worse now as the death toll from the COVID-19 pandemic rises and as we witness an attempted insurrection fomented by Trump and his supporters. The dream of swaying people, individually or collectively, to do one’s bidding is an old one—and it’s not going away anytime soon. To the degree that such techniques are portrayed, rightly or wrongly, as effective, others will likely continue to adopt and deploy them.

因此，剑桥分析公司和 IRA 只是社会工程学旧问题的一个新阶段，而他们的同类似乎正在获得力量。如何应对大规模个人社会工程学？我们接下来将讨论这个问题。

So, Cambridge Analytica and the IRA represent only a new phase of the old problems of social engineering, and their ilk appear to be gaining power. What is to be done about masspersonal social engineering? We turn to that question next.

8

8

结论：改善大规模个人社会工程

Conclusion: Ameliorating Masspersonal Social Engineering

在本书中，我们采纳了几位人士的呼吁，将新兴的操纵性沟通形式视为社会工程学。在此过程中，我们认为，社会工程学的概念与电子邮件黑客、模因制作和分享、试图微定位选民以及社交媒体借口等做法的混合之间确实存在着很强的亲和力。这些做法不仅是 20 世纪初发展起来的大规模社会工程学和宣传的产物，而且还与黑客的人际欺骗行为有关。

In this book, we took up the call from several people to consider emerging forms of manipulative communication as social engineering. In doing so, we argued that there is, indeed, a strong affinity between the concept of social engineering and the mixture of practices such as email hacks, meme production and sharing, attempts to microtarget voters, and social media pretexts. Not only are these practices the descendants of mass social engineering and propaganda developed in the early twentieth century, they are also related to the hacker practice of interpersonal con artistry.

我们运用从黑客研究中衍生的概念，部署了一种批判性战略沟通方法。这让我们对当代数字媒体环境有了新的认识。在追踪大众和黑客人际社会工程之间的线索后，我们的第二个目标是揭示两件关键事件中破坏、借口、胡说八道和渗透的元素：俄罗斯干预选举活动和剑桥分析公司利用心理数据左右公众政治舆论。这些迹象表明安全研究员托马斯·里德 (Thomas Rid) 称之为“战略层面的政治工程、社会工程”。1这些事件——以及许多类似的事件我们至今仍在经历着这种现象——黑客社会工程学扩大到社会层面，从而接近旧式大众社会工程师渗透媒体市场或大型社会机构的野心。

We have deployed a critical approach to strategic communication through the use of concepts derived from hacker studies. This leads to a new understanding of our contemporary digital media environment. After tracing the threads between mass and hacker interpersonal social engineering, our penultimate ambition was to reveal elements of trashing, pretexting, bullshitting, and penetrating in two key events: the Russian election interference campaign and the use of psychographics by Cambridge Analytica to sway public political opinion. These were indications of what security researcher Thomas Rid calls “political engineering, social engineering on a strategic level.”1 These events—and many others like them that we still experience—saw hacker social engineering scaled up to societal level, and thus approaching the ambitions of the older mass social engineers to penetrate media markets or large-scale social institutions.

我们希望我们的工作表明，有针对性的人际社会工程和大众社会工程之间的关系是流动的。这可能有助于我们克服当前对操纵性沟通实践的分析中的僵局，包括对剑桥分析公司等公司的分析。有针对性的人际技术有效吗？还是我们应该更关注大众信息传递？2020 年，两位重要的政治传播学者 Emma Briant 和 David Karpf 进行了一场辩论，将这两种观点对立起来，Briant 提出了这样的论点：针对个人的心理定位是对民主审议的严重威胁，而 Karpf 则对大众信息传递表达了更多的担忧。公平地说，这场辩论的结构使他们不得不通过采取这些对立的立场来简化自己的立场。然而，如果辩论的目的是为了解决僵局，那么它并没有。Briant 坚持认为，精准定位是近年来政治传播中最危险的发展，而 Karpf 则认为大众传播在政治传播中仍然占主导地位。2

We hope that our work shows that the relationship between targeted, interpersonal social engineering and mass social engineering is fluid. This may help us overcome impasses in current analyses of manipulative communication practices, including those of firms like Cambridge Analytica. Do targeted, interpersonal techniques work? Or should we be more concerned about mass messaging?
